Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. div.head: The EpiÅ¿tle to the READER.
div.p:
THIS following Narrative is a Theme Å¿o Å¿adly copious, that if thou art a true ProteÅ¿tant, thou canÅ¿t not but bewail the Å¿ad fate of many thouÅ¿and innocent ChriÅ¿tians whoÅ¿e Å¿ufferings, and their enemies cruelty Å¿trove for preheminence, who died not Å¿o much like Martyrs, as murthered like Å¿heep; being not overcome by force, but betrayed by Treachery, and perjury. Who can but from the depth of Å¿adneÅ¿s turn his Å¿orrow into tears, forcing open the bowels of his compaÅ¿sion, through
the flood-gates of his eyes; when we Å¿hall conÅ¿ider, Å¿o many Lords and Gallant Commanders breath their laÅ¿t, by an ignominous and baÅ¿e death, not to be compared for cruelty, perjury and treachery, in any age or HiÅ¿tory; for indeed theÅ¿e Å¿ad calamities challenge the Tribute of a bleeding heart; Å¿o that if the Readers underÅ¿tanding be not already garriÅ¿oned with prejudice, or if the times be but patient of hearing truth this Book may prove of Å¿ome uÅ¿e to this Nation.

The ruins of Truth is often envelloped in the Å¿able clouds of Oblivion. Nimium altercando amittitur, Truth may be loÅ¿t in a crowd; therefore my induÅ¿try to preÅ¿erve antiquity, may Å¿tand as an argument againÅ¿t calumny; for each Book preÅ¿t into the world, is as a Bark at Sea; the firÅ¿t as Å¿ubject to cenÅ¿ure, as the laÅ¿t to Å¿torms; therfore I cannot but expect a Å¿hower of cenÅ¿ures; yet, as
Mr. Feltham Å¿aies, It is the eaÅ¿ieÅ¿t part to cenÅ¿ure; and though men think thereby to be accounted wiÅ¿e, yet (Å¿ayes he) there is nothing diÅ¿covers a Fool more; for he that knows leaÅ¿t cenÅ¿ures moÅ¿t; Ignorance gives diÅ¿paragementâª a lowder tongue than knowledge; like Rats that love to eat Books they cannot read, and however I may Å¿uffer the venome of AÅ¿ps, which grow on Å¿ome mens tongues, yet have I done without crime, what I ought to do in conÅ¿cience; and the more impetuous the Å¿torms, and rapid torrents of calumny aÅ¿Å¿ault and beat upon my endeavours, the more Å¿hall I, like the Traveller in the Fable, hug my Å¿elf in the Cloak of my own Innocency and Integrity; that though the Å¿ucceÅ¿s of my Labour prove abortive to Å¿ome, yet Å¿hall I enjoy the fredom of my own deÅ¿ire, and reward my Å¿elf with that content, that the envious World can
neither give, nor take from me.

It is not unknown to the World that Å¿omething of this nature is extant, yet may I humbly and truly Å¿ay, is Å¿hort of this: for the Original Structures and compoÅ¿ure of this Narrative, fetches his Materials from Å¿undry Authors, both Modern and Antient; and being cul'd from the Reliques of Antiquity, by a careful gleaning out of many into one, may therefore challenge the privilege to Å¿ay, that all others want Å¿omewhat of this; being an exact Epitomy of the moÅ¿t remarkable paÅ¿Å¿ages of the Civil Wars, during this Kings Reign; yet as Å¿uccinct as an orderly proceeding can admit. And Courteous Reader, that thou mayeÅ¿t be perÅ¿waded to go further then the Entrance, I do aÅ¿Å¿ure thee, that the body of this HiÅ¿tory is collected from the beÅ¿t Writers of both Å¿ides, whoÅ¿e tinctures of reflection according to their ByaÅ¿Å¿es, is
Å¿o ballanced, that the Narrative Å¿tands free from the prejudicate part of either, being as impartial as pen can collect from the Original of antient Records; and as well diÅ¿tanced from the gaÅ¿hes of a partial Pen, as the two Poles from one another, or the Antipodes from us. For I find what any ProteÅ¿tant writer inÅ¿erts of the worÅ¿t part, is no leÅ¿s publiÅ¿hed, than known by the Catholicks themÅ¿elves, for they cannot deny the act, only they excuÅ¿e the manner. And this advantage will come by this collection, that whereas it was in large volumes, now it is reduced and fitted to the time, and purÅ¿es of thoÅ¿e that had no occaÅ¿ion, and leÅ¿s abilities to accompliÅ¿h the peruÅ¿al or purchaÅ¿ing of large Folio's, which I think was the grand reaÅ¿on of Å¿tifling the knowledge hereof to many of this age.

Reader, thou art here preÅ¿ented
with the moÅ¿t horrid Rapes, Murthers, Perjury, and Treacherous Cruelty of a Prince and Court, that ever landed on European Å¿hore, for in few daies all the ProteÅ¿tant Nobility and Gentry, with Ladies and innocent Gentlewomen and children to the number of fourty thouÅ¿and, were inhumanely butchered, and cut off by the Kings Å¿pecial Commandment. Here thou mayeÅ¿t Å¿ee a Prince beÅ¿mearing himÅ¿elf with the Goar blood of his own Subjects, and at laÅ¿t wallowing in his own; we Å¿hall here Å¿ee Religious Vows and PromiÅ¿es, no Å¿tronger ties to the King, and Court, than a Rope of Å¿and to a wild beaÅ¿t; being gone Å¿o far in perjury, that the Kings faith was accounted like the Greeks, whoÅ¿e unfaithfulneÅ¿s to their promiÅ¿es, is become Proverbial, that when one would expreÅ¿s perjury, they termed it Greca fides, for though a Creditor had ten bonds, and as many
Sureties and Seals, yet will he find it extreme hard to accompliÅ¿h his debt: Å¿o when a Jew is to deal with a Genoa, he puts his finger in his eye fearing his Treachery. They reÅ¿olve to have no other virtue rampant than perjury and cruelty; Abandoning that part of Religion, which ties to a Å¿trict obÅ¿ervance of Duty. Omnia ReligioÅ¿a nunc ridentur; they will wade no further in Religion than may Å¿erve their cruel ends; inÅ¿omuch, that in one Town which the ProteÅ¿tants kept, they engraved on the gate this Motto, Roy Å¿ans foy, ville Å¿ans peur, the King had no faith, nor they no fear. And as the Roman Emperor Caligula, Å¿aid of Seneca's Works, they were Arena Å¿ine calce, Å¿and without lime, having no connexion, Å¿o was the King of France his Solemn Oaths, and PromiÅ¿es. argument.head: The Contents.
argument.p:
THe Reign of Charls the ninth, A Parliament called, the Government committed to the Queen Mother during the Kings minority, the names of Hugonet and PapiÅ¿t forbid on pain of death, Prince of Conde and King of Navar in diÅ¿content departs the Court, the King of Nevar made Lieutenant General, and joyntly intereÅ¿Å¿ed in the Government with the Queen Mother, the Princes deÅ¿ire a Toleration of Religion for the ProteÅ¿tants, which is privately granted, the ProteÅ¿tants multiply, and the Princes protect them, demanding the Queens promiÅ¿e for Toleration, the ProteÅ¿tants that were in PriÅ¿on for Religion freed by a Decree of the Council, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e Å¿urrenders the Keys of the Palaces to the King of Navar, the King crowned, the Princes of the Bloud, and Duke of GuiÅ¿e contends at the Coronation about precedency, the King gives it to the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, the ConÅ¿table forÅ¿akes the ProteÅ¿tants, and cleaves to the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, the Queen Mother for her own advantage joyns with the King of Navar, and gives Å¿ome liberty to the ProteÅ¿tants, which Å¿o enrages the Catholick party as preÅ¿ently all former Edicts in behalf of the ProteÅ¿tants were broken by a contrary
Edict that no Religion Å¿hould be Å¿uffered in the Kingdom but the RomiÅ¿h, the King and Queen Mother Å¿ubÅ¿cribes thereunto, the ProteÅ¿tants at their requeÅ¿t have a Conference granted, they meet, and confer in a hot Dispute, but agree not; the Catholicks murder many ProteÅ¿tants in Paris, the eight Parliaments of France aÅ¿Å¿embles, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e diÅ¿approved of it, and Å¿o in a fury departs the Court, and goes for Spain; the ProteÅ¿tants deluded by the Queen Mother, gives her a LiÅ¿t of all their Forces; the King of Navar turns Catholick; the eight Parliaments meet, and with the conÅ¿ent of the King and Queen Mother do decree a free and publick Toleration of the ProteÅ¿tant Religion, but Å¿peedily a Å¿ad and cruel MaÅ¿Å¿acre; the Duke of GuiÅ¿e furiouÅ¿ly aÅ¿Å¿aults the ProteÅ¿tants at a Sermon, and murders two hundred of them; the ProteÅ¿tants complain to the Prince of Conde of breach of Covenant and Edict; the Duke of GuiÅ¿e Å¿eiÅ¿es on the King, and carries him to Paris; the Queen Mother writes to the Prince of Conde for aid againÅ¿t the Duke of GuiÅ¿es Attempt; the Prince in his journey to Court Å¿uddenly retires to Orleance, and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿es it; the firÅ¿t Civil War begins.

div.p:
The death of King Francis, and Reign of King Charls.
FRancis Å¿econd King of that name, dying the fourteenth of December, 1560. made entrance for the Reign of Charls the ninth; and as the firÅ¿t died of a Feaver, Å¿o the laÅ¿t reigned in a FrenÅ¿ie; the legitimate off-Å¿pring of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿ours diÅ¿eaÅ¿e: whoÅ¿e Å¿hort Reign was thought too much lengthened, by the train of all Å¿orts of bloudy cruelties, which filled this poor diÅ¿tracted Nation of France: whoÅ¿e wicked Reign
was alÅ¿o attended with the Å¿able clouds of Flagellum Dei, which Å¿wept both Field and City. The beginning of his wicked Reign had a bloudy ending to the poor Kingdom, and himÅ¿elf; for the bodies of the murthered ProteÅ¿tants was a Prey to the Birds of the Air, and BeaÅ¿ts of the Fields; the whole Nation wearing the PenÅ¿ive Weeds of a Ruinous DiÅ¿traction; for through the Lords juÅ¿t Judgments on the Nation, they Å¿uffer nothing leÅ¿s than all Roberies, Rapes, and all Å¿orts of Cruelties, with horrid MaÅ¿Å¿acres for the Å¿pace of twelve years. And as the Prologue of his Reign was Perjury and Treachery, Å¿o was the Epilogue Bloudy to himÅ¿elf, and poor Nation, eÅ¿pecially to the poor innocent ProteÅ¿tants.

A Parliament Å¿its, and the Government committed to the Queen Mother during the Kings minority.A Parliament being called, they begin the 23. of December. Now at this time in the Court of France, was Katherine de Medices, Pope Clements Brothers Daughter, and this Kings Mother, who being born in Florence a City of Italy, had conferr'd upon her the Government of this Kingdom in the Kings minority; for it is well known that according to the Laws of this Nation, neither the AdminiÅ¿tration nor Inheritance thereof, can juÅ¿tly be caÅ¿t on the Å¿houlders of a Woman; and yet againÅ¿t this Law, and through the negligence of the King of Navar, the Å¿aid Queen Mother was joyned with him in the Office of ProtectorÅ¿hip; the confirmation of her Regency being allowed of by the Chancellour; was afterwards confirmed by the Speakers.

Now in this AÅ¿Å¿embly of Parliament, one John Quintin (a Doctor of the Common Law at Paris for the Clergy) pleads that none of the
Religion Reformed (for Å¿o they called the ProteÅ¿tants) Å¿hould any more be tolerated or Å¿uffered, and deÅ¿ired that the Laws in that caÅ¿e provided, might be put in Å¿peedy execution; but the day following, that brave Commander and good ChriÅ¿tian, Gasper de Coligni the Admiral of the ProteÅ¿tants, complained to the Queen Mother againÅ¿t the Å¿aid Quintin, who preÅ¿ently excuÅ¿es himÅ¿elf, and in his Å¿econd Speech moderates his Plea to the Admirals content.

The Parliament a little enlarges the ProteÅ¿tants privileges.Now the EÅ¿tates proceeds in their conÅ¿ultations, making themÅ¿elves and the beginning of this year Å¿omewhat happy, by Å¿ome moderation in matters of Religion, whereby the reproachfull names of PapiÅ¿t and Hugenot was forbidden upon pain of Death: which name Hugenot they fixed in diÅ¿dain and deriÅ¿ion to the ProteÅ¿tants, and was derived from a Gate-houÅ¿e in Tours, called St. Hughs Gate, where they met in AÅ¿Å¿emblies.

Many good and neceÅ¿Å¿ary Laws were then publiÅ¿hed, but with more confuÅ¿iom than advantage; for Laws though good and many, yet through want of a due execution by the MagiÅ¿trates power, makes the good intent thereof to be perverted and turned into an indirect Channel, giving the people cauÅ¿e to Å¿light Å¿uch wholeÅ¿om Laws, and grow bad under a good Government.

Great contentions and private animoÅ¿ities aroÅ¿e between the Princes of the Bloud (that is, the Prince of Conde and King of Navar, who were ProteÅ¿tants) and Francis Duke of GuiÅ¿e, who was deÅ¿cended of the HouÅ¿e of Lorain, and now Grand MaÅ¿ter of the Kings
HouÅ¿e; who being a Å¿trong Catholick, was no leÅ¿s a bitter Enemy to the poor ProteÅ¿tants: the Queen Mother in her affections did Å¿ecretly incline to the Duke of GuiÅ¿e; yet to Å¿ecure her own intereÅ¿t and power in the Kings minority, carried fair to both:The Princes of the Bloud being ProteÅ¿tants in diÅ¿content abÅ¿ent from Court. but the King of Navar and Prince of Conde with the ConÅ¿table, Å¿eeing themÅ¿elves juÅ¿tled out of that power and favour in Court, which as due they did expect, and alÅ¿o foreÅ¿eeing the event which muÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿arily enÅ¿ure, having onely the pacings of the Duke of GuiÅ¿e; they abÅ¿ent from Court, with all their Attendants, reÅ¿olving to right their wrong on the Queen Mothers Regency, and the GuiÅ¿ans uÅ¿urpation of their unlimited power. Now the Queen Mother by her Å¿ubtil and natural inÅ¿ight to Å¿ecret affairs, judged Å¿o at their DiÅ¿content, that Å¿he politickly caÅ¿t her Cards, that both might have a good hand, yet deald her Å¿elf the Trumps; checking their power, that they might not check hers.

The King of Navar by the Queens policy jointly governs with her.To which purpoÅ¿e Å¿he makes a new Agreement with the Navarois, concluding him in the Government, that taking the Title and Power of Regency to her Å¿elf, he Å¿hould be called [and but called] Lieutenant General to his MajeÅ¿ty. All this but in Paper and Ink, compoÅ¿ed of a double intent: but thoÅ¿e that can break Oaths witneÅ¿Å¿ed by God and all the World, how Å¿oon can they Å¿wallow and digeÅ¿t the breach of Å¿uch Paper-promiÅ¿es; like that good Actor in Smyrna, that cried, O Terram! yet pointing to the Heaven; and O Coelum! yet pointing to the earth; which when one of the Spectators Å¿aw, in anger he Å¿aid to the company, This fellow has made a SoliciÅ¿m, Å¿poken as it were falÅ¿e
Greek with his hand. div.p: THe DiviÅ¿ions thus increaÅ¿ing, made way to erect a Theatre for a Å¿ad Tragedy: for the Prince of Conde publiÅ¿hed a ManifeÅ¿to, and Å¿ent Letters alÅ¿o to the King, Parliament of Paris, ProteÅ¿tant Princes of Germany, and to all other ChriÅ¿tian Princes.

And further it was declared, that the Duke of GuiÅ¿e a new-come Foreiner, tranÅ¿lated from the ForeÅ¿ts of Lorain, Å¿hould uÅ¿urp Å¿uch power in France, Å¿uch dominion and command, as the Princes of the Bloud muÅ¿t loÅ¿e their proper intereÅ¿ts to be his Å¿laves and vaÅ¿Å¿als, againÅ¿t all the Laws of the Nation; further declaring, That if the King Å¿hould cauÅ¿e an obÅ¿ervation of the Edict for Religion already Å¿igned, and that Arms might be laid down on the Kings part, they were ready to do the like, and would Å¿peedily lay down their Arms; To this he added the Queen Mothers Å¿ingular care (as it was reported and as indeed Å¿he did outwardly Å¿hew)

Burges & Orleans proves a Sanctuary, and hiding place in time of GodsTheÅ¿e flames being begun could not Å¿o eaÅ¿ily be extinguiÅ¿hed; mauy cruelties being committed on the bodies of the poor ProteÅ¿tants without mercy, & Å¿uch as will no queÅ¿tion draw out tears from the eies of Å¿erious ChriÅ¿tians being Å¿uch Å¿ad examples of crueltie as cant be believed Å¿hould have proceeded from any that had known that ever ChriÅ¿tianity had been in the world; nothing being drunk more eagerly then the blood of the poor Saints; Yet in this callamity God provided a place of refuge for Å¿uch as he pleaÅ¿ed in mercy to preÅ¿erve from their cruelty: For Bourges, and Orleans, being kept by the ProteÅ¿tants,The King declares againÅ¿t the prince of Conde. did greatly adminiÅ¿ter comfort to many diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed ChriÅ¿tians that fled theither. Hereupon the King at Paris declares againÅ¿t the Edict and the Prince of Conde.

The Queen Mother now arms thoÅ¿e Å¿he privately huggs in the boÅ¿om of ther affections. The Prince of Conde deÅ¿ires to lay all private intereÅ¿ts aÅ¿ide for preÅ¿ervation of the Publick efuÅ¿ion of blood; But the King of Navar, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, the ConÅ¿table, and MarÅ¿hall of St. Andre, by an Edict, baniÅ¿hes the ProteÅ¿tants out of Paris, and Å¿udenly advances towards the Prince of Conde with twelve thouÅ¿and foot, and three thouÅ¿and horÅ¿e; They find the Prince Å¿trong enough to encounter them, contrary to ther expectations; and De Andelot

But the Queen Mother abuÅ¿es them with her Å¿ubtile treachery, telling them the hopes of agreement was too near for them to undo all by a too haÅ¿ty ingagement: in Å¿o much that Å¿he fed them with hopes till the Catholick Army increaÅ¿ed in Å¿trength both with French and forein forces.

Thus the Queen having delayed and protracted all hopes of IÅ¿Å¿ue by battle, the Prince of Conde maintains his Army about two months in Å¿uch peace to the Country, as was not in the leaÅ¿t found to be outragious, by Å¿poyling or robbing; Å¿uch was the ChriÅ¿tian and carefull diÅ¿cipline of the Prince and Admiral of the ProteÅ¿tant Army; which in France was the greater wonder, becauÅ¿e whoring robbing and blaÅ¿pheming was the uÅ¿ual attendants and conÅ¿tant harbingers to the Catholick camp; which could not be avoyded becauÅ¿e the King could not keep to Å¿o Å¿trickt a diÅ¿cipline as the Prince of Conde and Admiral.

The Prince and Admiral diÅ¿perÅ¿e the Armie into Å¿everal Provinces.The Prince of Conde, and Admiral, wiÅ¿ely & prudently, like valliant & carefull Commanders take all waies to uÅ¿e their preÅ¿ent power for future advantages and enÅ¿uing Storms; Å¿o they Å¿end out to Å¿everal Provinces, men of approved fidelity to the ProteÅ¿tant cauÅ¿e, which proved (next to Gods bleÅ¿Å¿ing) a great help to their Å¿ucceÅ¿s, in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ing many Å¿trong holds in Å¿undry parts of France, as Roan, Deip, Angiers, Blois, VendoÅ¿me, Tours, Poictiers, Ragency, Maus, AngouleÅ¿me, Chalon upon Soan, MaÅ¿kon and the moÅ¿t part of Daulphin. THe ProteÅ¿tants during this Å¿harp war had many cruelties, and Å¿ad Å¿ufferings done to their perÅ¿ons without any pitty, or remorÅ¿e, the which was not in one City, but in moÅ¿t parts of France, and with Å¿uch bloodÅ¿hed, as will make any ChriÅ¿tian heart to bewail their Å¿aid Å¿ufferings, and may Å¿erve to teach us our habitation is not in this world, and Å¿o may encourage us to look out for another, whoÅ¿e foundation and building is in JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, that Rock of ages, that good and gracious anchor-hold in time of Storms and TempeÅ¿ts; and to let us a little taÅ¿te what a happineÅ¿s it is that when men come with bloody reÅ¿olutions to aÅ¿Å¿ault our innocency, then for a Å¿oul to have his eye fixed on heaven, by a
firm faith of aÅ¿Å¿urance in Gods mercy, that though mens rage be like the lofty billows, yet our Å¿alvation, and our Å¿trength is in God, and thrice happy is that Å¿oul that can aÅ¿Å¿uredly Å¿ay in times of perÅ¿ecution, that God is my Rock and hiding place in times of Storm.Cruelties at Paris.

The poor Saints of God in Paris were cruelly perÅ¿ecuted by the bloody papiÅ¿ts, who being fully delighted, and Å¿et on blood, together with the help of the Parliament there, did Å¿pare none that fell into their bloody hands, either in the City of Paris, or Å¿uch as by appeal or Å¿ummons were brought thither.

The bloody uÅ¿age of ChriÅ¿tians at Senlis. Many dear and pretious Saints of God at Senlis, Å¿uffered the fury of bloody and deceitfull men; Å¿ome murthered in a popular tumult, Å¿ome beheaded, others cruelly whipped, impriÅ¿oned, and Å¿ent to the Gallies, not Å¿o much as Å¿paring women.
There murthers at Les Bordes. At Les Bordes, the Duke of Nevers being Governour of Campagn, his Lieutenant Å¿lew many men, and women, impriÅ¿oning others, and Å¿poiling their houÅ¿es.

Their unheard of crueltie to a Godly MiniÅ¿ter of ChriÅ¿t.At Chaalons, a godly MiniÅ¿ter of Gods word, Mr. Fournier was Å¿o baÅ¿ely abuÅ¿ed, as the mercileÅ¿s cruelty by his Enemies, and Gods merciful deliverance muÅ¿t crave leave to have a little remembrance, and indeed is worthy our ChriÅ¿tian peruÅ¿all and obÅ¿ervance.

This Godly Å¿ervant of ChriÅ¿t, being priÅ¿oner was Å¿tript of his cloaths, put into a Cart, and with many abuÅ¿ive jears, taunts and Å¿coffs, was often in danger of his life by the common-people. At Monchon, he was caÅ¿t in priÅ¿on,
where a Captain and many Souldiers came and told him he Å¿hould be cut in peices, afterwards the Judges came and commanded him to be loaden with Irons; after a while, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e being made Governour, he was cruelly tortured, by Å¿training his thumbs Å¿o hard, till blood iÅ¿Å¿ued out, they then bind his hands behind his back, and tying a Rope to his thumbs, they hoiÅ¿t him up, and then Å¿uddenly twitches him down five or Å¿ix times, tying alÅ¿o great Å¿tones to his toes, and Å¿o let him hang till his vitals failed him almoÅ¿t to death; at laÅ¿t he was put into priÅ¿on, and no Chyrurgion allowed to dreÅ¿s his wounds, although the Cords had made gaÅ¿hes in his fleÅ¿h to the bones, inÅ¿omuch that he underwent great pain, that he could not lift his hand to his mouth, but had almoÅ¿t loÅ¿t the uÅ¿e of them, this did this Servant of ChriÅ¿t endure, like a true Soldier with invincible courage and patience, and by the Å¿pecial providence of God, news was brought that the Duke of GuiÅ¿e was dead. The very next day one BuÅ¿Å¿i had order from the ConÅ¿table to let him free, which yet Å¿aid, BuÅ¿Å¿i came, and told this faithful MiniÅ¿ter of God, with all acquainting him that he Å¿hould be let free, but it Å¿hould be to the peoples rage. But let us yet Å¿ee another Å¿pecial providence,A Å¿ingular token of Gods care of his faithful Ones. for at the Å¿ame time came by the Prince of Portion with his German HorÅ¿es, who Å¿ent in word to the Town, that if Mr. Fournier was not Å¿peedily delivered to him, and from their cruelties, he would not leave Å¿o much as the tokens of a foundation, but raze it to ruin as a monument of their mercileÅ¿s deÅ¿erts. Which meÅ¿Å¿age Å¿o terrified the enemies of this Godly Å¿oul, that immediately he was Å¿afely conveyed
to the Prince,he gathers a Congregation and yeilds his Å¿oule to God. which faithfull Å¿ervant of the Lord after he had reÅ¿ided a little Å¿pace at Ver, and gathered a Congregation, he preÅ¿ently after reÅ¿igned up his Å¿oule to the Lord that gave it and Å¿o put a period to the miÅ¿erable attendance of this life, and begun that life of glory.

A Treacherous and baÅ¿e murther of MounÅ¿eir de St. EÅ¿tiene, his two Brothers and 16. more all Å¿tabbed by his own CoÅ¿en Germain.
MounÅ¿eir de St. EÅ¿tiene, in his jorney from Orleans, retiring himÅ¿elf with his two brothers and Å¿ome others for RefreÅ¿hment to his own houÅ¿e neer Reims, they were not long there till the houÅ¿e was beÅ¿et by fifteen hundred men, who being forced to yield, had liberty on their words, to go forth to Å¿peak with the Duke of Nevers, whom (as they Å¿aid) deÅ¿ired to Å¿ee him, and going out was there baÅ¿ely and treacherouÅ¿ly murthered by the Baron Ceruy, his own CoÅ¿en German; Å¿o were his two Bretheren alÅ¿o, with Å¿ixteen others baÅ¿ely and unworthely, Å¿tabbed and diÅ¿troyed without the leaÅ¿t compoÅ¿ition; Their wives they Å¿poyled of all they had, and led away priÅ¿oners.

At Amiens, all Bibles, TeÅ¿taments, and pÅ¿alms, were Å¿ought for and openly with much profanneÅ¿s were burned, the GuiÅ¿ans murthering and killing the poor ProteÅ¿tants, and caÅ¿ting their dead bodies into the River; Å¿hooting Å¿ome to death, and hanging others,

At Meux 400. murthered.The ProteÅ¿tans at Meaux, being the Å¿tronger partie, continued the exerciÅ¿e of their Religion for a while, but at laÅ¿t the Parliament at Paris gave judgement againÅ¿t them, whereupon a company of Å¿ouldiers enters the Town, diÅ¿arms the Citizens, and unworthyly, and cowardly murthered above four hundred poor ProteÅ¿tants; and as if it were not enough, as if their blood-thirÅ¿tineÅ¿s could not be quenched, MounÅ¿eir De'BoyÅ¿y enters with Å¿ouldiers,Virgins a BuÅ¿ed in the Å¿treets children daÅ¿hed againÅ¿t the walls. committs unheard-of, and inhuman villanies, deflouring virgins in the open Å¿treets, many maÅ¿Å¿acred and drowned, children daÅ¿hed againÅ¿t the walls, divers papiÅ¿t preiÅ¿ts murthered Å¿ome with their own hands. div.p:
WE concluded the latter part of the Å¿econd chapter with a Peace concluded at Orleans, whereupon was publickly proclamed a free liberty for the ProteÅ¿tants, according to the Edict of Pacification. The peace not keptBut alas this peace Å¿ucceeds not the hopefull

The Council of Trent meets. The King of Spain, and France make a league and call it the Holy leagueAnd now aÅ¿Å¿embles that Council, known by the name of the Council of Trent; who meet for the maintainance of the Catholick Religion.

The Cardinal poÅ¿ts to Rome, and endeavours all be can againÅ¿t the proteÅ¿tants.Now as Å¿oon as this Council broke up, the Cardinal poÅ¿ts to Rome, and labours with Pope Pius Quartus, to Å¿end to the King and Queen Mother of France, to cauÅ¿e publickly the Decree of the Council to be obÅ¿erved throughout the Kingdom of France, preÅ¿ently they begin to have it put in execution, for the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours of Spain, Italy, &c. demand of the French King the ObÅ¿ervation of the Decrees of the Council of Trent, that the Edict Å¿hould be diÅ¿annulled, and Hereticks rooted out.

Secret animoÅ¿ities in the hearts of both parties.Now begin new firebrands to be caÅ¿t again, all their deÅ¿igne from firÅ¿t to laÅ¿t being to work out the poor ProteÅ¿tants, who

Now the daily threats againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, put them into a doubt of their Å¿ecurity;The Å¿ad maÅ¿Å¿acres at Tours. for the King and Queen Mother having concluded with the King of Spain; Å¿ecretly to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t one another; It now fiftly falls out to diÅ¿cover that treacherous part which all this while lay hid

On the fourteenth day the Prince and Admiral with their Army,the Prince of Conde and Admirall with their Army march to joyn with the Prince CaÅ¿imirs Army of 11. thouÅ¿and. marched to Campagn, and Å¿o paÅ¿t into the confines of Lorrain, to joyn with Prince CaiÅ¿imir, Å¿on to the Prince Palatine of Rhine, Elector to the Sacred Empire; whoÅ¿e royall worth cannot Å¿hine through the deÅ¿cription of my pen, according to the luÅ¿tre of his native, and intrinÅ¿ick worth: who had now for the defence of the ProteÅ¿tants, rayÅ¿ed an Army of ten or eleven thouÅ¿and, who in their march took in Å¿om towns; In this mean while the Duke of Lorrain was created Generall of the Kings Army, and the Duke of Anjon Lieutenant Generall, now Prince CaÅ¿imir aforeÅ¿aid, writ to the King, proteÅ¿ting that it was not any profit, or privat intereÅ¿t of his own that prompted his reÅ¿olutions, Prince CaÅ¿imirs noble declaraton in behalf of the proteÅ¿tants. but only, and really, to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t thoÅ¿e that afflicted, and perÅ¿ecuted, for the Å¿ame religion, had required his help, And further declared, That if yet the King would grant them free liberty, according to his promiÅ¿e in the laÅ¿t Edict, he was ready to retreat. When the Cardinal of ChaÅ¿tillon (formerly fled to England diÅ¿guiÅ¿ed, and having great Revenues and Wealth) his death being known to the King, he did give to the Admiral all the fruits of the whole year, with all his rich and coÅ¿tly HouÅ¿hold-Å¿tuff: and though all former Admirals in Council, and publick Ceremonies, had ever given place to the MarÅ¿hall of France, yet for the Admirals greater honour, it was the Kings will and pleaÅ¿ure that he
Å¿hould Å¿it next MonÅ¿eiur de Momorancy, who was the firÅ¿t MarÅ¿hall, and above all the reÅ¿t.

The K. deÅ¿ires the Duke of Savoy to favour the ProteÅ¿tantsThe King alÅ¿o writes to the Duke of Savoy, that for his Å¿ake he would pleaÅ¿e to be favourable to the ProteÅ¿tants under his Dominion, & it Å¿hould ly upon him as an acceptable favor.

It is not to be thought what kindneÅ¿Å¿es the King Å¿hewed to the ProteÅ¿tants, even to the great amazement of the Catholicks, and rejoicing of the ProteÅ¿tants, The K. Å¿o far diÅ¿Å¿embles, that by his shew of reÅ¿pects to the ProteÅ¿tants the Catholicks Å¿uÅ¿pect him. who poor Å¿ouls thought all true that he Å¿aid; but this love proved bitter hatred, like Judas kiÅ¿s, nay the King did Å¿o carry it, that the Catholicks began to Å¿urmiÅ¿e, and Å¿ay, that the King did not only favour the ProteÅ¿tants, but would himÅ¿elf turn one Å¿hortly.

And in regard there was a mighty enmity betwixt the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, and the Admiral, by reaÅ¿on of a report fixed on the Admiral, as if he Å¿hould be an inÅ¿trument of his Fathers death;The Admiral and Duke of GuiÅ¿e reconciled, and the Admiral declared not guilty of the Duke of GuiÅ¿es death. the King therefore to make up all breaches, and in order to a perfect peace, he preÅ¿cribes a perfect form of Reconciliation (the foundations whereof was laid Å¿ix years ago in the Town of Molins) where the King Å¿ummoning the principal eÅ¿tates of his Kingdom, did on conÅ¿ultation and deliberation; declare and pronounce the Admiral not guilty of the death of the Duke GuiÅ¿e: a thing his MajeÅ¿tie was before bound in conÅ¿cience to do, but now was acted and done as a piece of good policy; this block being taken away as an advance for the Admiral to the Court.

But as we Å¿aid before, the moÅ¿t Å¿olemn bond and ty for a Å¿ecure peace, is the Lady Margarite, SiÅ¿ter to the King of France, to be given

And in regard that it was objected, That the King of France his SiÅ¿ter was of the Roman Religion, and the Prince of Navar a ProteÅ¿tant, it could not well be effected to a good purpoÅ¿e; To which the King anÅ¿wered he would free her by a DiÅ¿penÅ¿ation from the Pope, that no Impediment might Å¿tand in the way to Å¿o great a good, as a Å¿ure peace betwixt him and his Subjects, nothing being more delightful or deÅ¿ired by him.

As Å¿oon as this was Å¿pread to the Courts of Forein Princes, it did amaze the PopiÅ¿h Party, that ever the King Å¿hould proceed in behalf of Hereticks. But on the contrary it did exceedingly poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s the hearts of the Prince,The K. plot takes effect and Admiral, and all forein Princes of the Å¿ame Religion, with exceeding joy, being Å¿uch a large demonÅ¿tration of the Kings affection, and as a Seal of fidelity to all he promiÅ¿ed, and did alÅ¿o drive out of their hearts all jealouÅ¿ies of plots, or Å¿ecret Contrivances; but the Admiral which had moÅ¿t reaÅ¿on, and was moÅ¿t backward to believe all reall, yet he at this time

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.head: The Contents.
argument.p:
THe Queen and Prince of Navar, with the Prince of Conde, comes to Court; the Articles of the War of the Low Countries put in writing; the Mariage between the Lady Margarite and Prince of Navar agreed on; the King heaps honours on the Admirall and friends; the King invites the Admiral to Court, and proteÅ¿ts his own life is envelloped in his; a croÅ¿s in deriÅ¿ion of the ProteÅ¿tants is pulled down by his MajeÅ¿ties command; the Plot almoÅ¿t diÅ¿covered by a lively inÅ¿tance; the King threatens Å¿evere puniÅ¿hment to any that Å¿hall affront the Admirall or ProteÅ¿tants; the Admiral comes to Court, and welcomed; the King allowes 50. for his Guard; the Count Lodowick of NaÅ¿Å¿aw, enters the Low Countries, and takes in Montz; A league offenÅ¿ive and defenÅ¿ive with Queen Elizabeth of England, but proved a deep plot; the Queen of Navar poiÅ¿oned by the Kings Apothecary, by whoÅ¿e death the Prince is King of Navar; the joyful and bloody mariage of the King of Navar, and the Lady Margarite; the Kings plot to take Rochel; the names of the ProteÅ¿tants in Lyons is taken in a bloody Book; Å¿ad complaints commeth to the Admiral, and great Å¿uÅ¿pition of a bloody MaÅ¿Å¿acre at hand, but he believed it not; the Admiral
from a Window Å¿hot in both Arms with a Harquebuzier as he walked in Paris; the King in great rage diÅ¿Å¿embles his treachery, but publiÅ¿hes his hypocriÅ¿ie by a Å¿hew of grief and diÅ¿content; he that Å¿hot the Admiral eÅ¿capes, having freÅ¿h horÅ¿es waiting for him; the Admiral Å¿hews himÅ¿elf a true ChriÅ¿tian, and patient Å¿ufferer; the matter examined by Judges, and the IÅ¿Å¿ue; he that Å¿hot the Admiral had commiÅ¿Å¿ion from the King for it; the Admiral like to dy requeÅ¿ts the Kings viÅ¿it; the King and Queen Mother with many Attendants perform his requeÅ¿t; they profeÅ¿s Å¿orrow, and diÅ¿Å¿emble wonderfully; the King and Admiral diÅ¿courÅ¿e alone; the Admiral commits his injuries to the Lord; the King intreats the Admiral to lodge in the Loure; the Admiral refuÅ¿es; a great Å¿uÅ¿pition of TreaÅ¿on by a Å¿udden Å¿peech of the Count de Retz in the ProteÅ¿tants hearing; the Admiral requeÅ¿ted a Guard for his perÅ¿on, which the King grants; the Admiral and ProteÅ¿tants adviÅ¿ed of their ruin, but they depended on the Kings promiÅ¿es, carriages, mariage, and Å¿olemn Oaths for their Å¿ecurity and Å¿afety.

div.p: THe laÅ¿t Chapter concluded with the great favours of the King to the ProteÅ¿tants, whereby he had Å¿o won into their affections, and to perÅ¿wade them all he Å¿aid was true, and to embrace his cruelty for loyaltyâª now in this chapter we Å¿hall Å¿ee the effects of his deÅ¿ires accompliÅ¿hed; for we Å¿hall behold all the Nobles of the ProteÅ¿tant Religion, and Princes, with the moÅ¿t of the Gentry, environed in Paris by the Treacherous baits of the Kings allurements.

The Queen of Navar with her Son the Prince, and the Prince of Conde, with a numerous train of the Nobility & Gentry of the Protestants all come to the Court with many brave Commanders. But Oh! my heart bleeds to think of the bloody iÅ¿Å¿ue.In the beginning of June, the Queen of Navar, and Connt Lodowick of NaÅ¿Å¿aw arrived at the French Court at Paris, the Count came to receive orders about the War in the Low Countries; the Queen of Navar was courteouÅ¿ly invited by the King to help prepare all things fitting for the Wedding, who to that purpoÅ¿e came, and was received with a joyful welcome, both of the King and whole Court; but as now we Å¿ee their faces Å¿miling with a good aÅ¿pect, Å¿o we Å¿hall Å¿hortly Å¿ee their hearts full of poiÅ¿on.

Two daies after arrives the Prince of Navar, the Prince of Conde, accompanied with the Count de Rochfoucault with all the Trains of the Princes, being the chief Commanders, Cavalliers and Gentlemen of the Religion; amongÅ¿t which was brave Pilles, Briquemault, and Pluveault. Collonels and reÅ¿olute Souldiers, who in time of the War, through their undaunted and reÅ¿olute valour for the ProteÅ¿tant cauÅ¿e, may challenge a right of honour amongÅ¿t the prime in France; their courage being Å¿uch as their Enemies yielded to them much glory and renown, as well as felt the power thereof. AmongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t alÅ¿o, came to Court that famous Commander the Sicur de Guerchy, that defended the City Sancere, where all miÅ¿eries were endured, and their enemies cruel mercy; a place which was driven to Å¿uch extream wants, as no filthy thing was left unfed upon; alÅ¿o came the MarqueÅ¿s de Revel, the Sieurs de Nove, de Collumbiere; one Lavardin a famous Commander of HorÅ¿e; with many Noble Lords, and gallant young Gentlemen, all ProteÅ¿tants,
in the Bud of their years, with a great many more â¢ f quality and reputation; but alas we Å¿hall Å¿ee theÅ¿e poor innocent Gentlemen baÅ¿ely murthered by the Kings command, and Å¿o deprived of all that Gallantry, which their Å¿prightful valour promiÅ¿ed to fill the World withal.

Articles of the Low Countrey war put in writing.The Count of NaÅ¿Å¿aw had with the King concluded on Articles for the Low Country war, which Articles were put in writing: So that we may Å¿ay the King uÅ¿ed the Count and the Prince of Orange in this War, as the Monky did the Cats foot to pull the CheÅ¿snuts out of the fire.

Articles of the mariage.And now to the mariage of the Lady Margaret, and Prince of Navar, the agreement being made, That the Prince of Navar Å¿hould have with the Lady Margaret four hundred thouÅ¿and Ducats, whereof three hundred thouÅ¿and Å¿hould be paid by the King, and Å¿ecurity given by the Queen Mother, and the Duke of Anjou; the mariage to be in the City of Paris; and now ChriÅ¿tian Reader the plot begins; The King advances a Gentleman of the Admirals to high Honour, his name Cavagnes, a Gentleman of great Worth and really honorable in himÅ¿elf, for excellent parts, and no leÅ¿s valour, whom the King,The Admiral intreated by the K. to come to Court. the better to work his DeÅ¿igns, Å¿ends as MeÅ¿Å¿enger to the Admiral, to intreat his preÅ¿ence at Paris, in order to honour the King and Court in this mariage, as alÅ¿o to conÅ¿ult about the War againÅ¿t the King of Spain, aÅ¿Å¿uring him, that the King intends his Å¿afety in that City as much as his own; and that although the PariÅ¿ians did cordially hate him by reaÅ¿on of their great Å¿uperÅ¿tition in
that City, being with Å¿editious preaching of Moncks and Fryers dayly inflamed to cruelty, and bloodÅ¿hed againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, yet his MajeÅ¿tie would take Å¿uch care of his perÅ¿on, as he Å¿hould be as Å¿afe as the watchfull eye and command of a King would make him

A Å¿tone CroÅ¿s pulled down by the K. command at the Admiralls requeÅ¿t.The King finding a Å¿tone croÅ¿s erected in Paris in a reproachful Triumph againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants in time of the Civil Wars, did at the requeÅ¿t of the Admiral pul it down, in regard it was a publick occaÅ¿ion of offence. And thus the King and his Council were hid with the love-hood of Å¿ecrecie, that whilÅ¿t they could Å¿ee others, others could not Å¿ee them. But alas God can eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿cover all their cloÅ¿e contrivances when he pleaÅ¿es; but it muÅ¿t be let alone to the Å¿ecret will of God, why at this time he was pleaÅ¿ed to let his people, and the Earth be burthened and oppreÅ¿Å¿ed with Å¿uch helliÅ¿h deÅ¿igns, that one would think Å¿hould make Devils afraid to contrive; but however, God Å¿uffered them to act their luÅ¿tful rage and bloody cruelty, yet he pleaÅ¿ed Å¿o to unmask the pretences of friendÅ¿hip, that in deÅ¿pight of Worldly Å¿ecrecie, the whole UniverÅ¿e may perceive the plot of PopiÅ¿h cruelty.

This wonderful and Tragical inÅ¿tance will cleerly evince any Impartial Reader, and if there were no other, yet would it Å¿tand alone, as an irrefragable Argument, that there was a premeditated plot to cut off the Admiral and ProteÅ¿tants; which Å¿tory for the Å¿trangeneÅ¿s of the DiÅ¿covery, and the Kings more Å¿trange way of JuÅ¿tice to prevent the further Å¿preading of his plot, take as followeth, and becauÅ¿e
of its uÅ¿e, I hope may prove no digreÅ¿Å¿ion.

The Å¿ecret deÅ¿ign of the K. and Council to deÅ¿troy the ProteÅ¿tants is almoÅ¿t diÅ¿covered in this cleer and pretty Story.There was in the Court of France at this came one MonÅ¿ieur de Lignoroles, a young Gentleman of a Å¿harp and accute wit, attended alÅ¿o with a high and bold Spirit, which Gentleman was the Duke of Anjou's great Familiar, which reaÅ¿on, together with the neerneÅ¿s of affection to each other, the Duke did impart to him the Å¿ecret CounÅ¿els of the King, with this Plot of cutting off all the ProteÅ¿tants, by a fair pretence of an alluring carriage, till they were under his power and mercy.

This young Gentleman by his great intimacy with the Duke, grew alÅ¿o into high favour with the King and Queen Mother, and for his wit and carriage, drew the eyes of all the Court towards him; attracting great eÅ¿teem from King, Queen Mother, and Court. This unfortunate Gentleman, more happy in the imployment, than wiÅ¿e in the improvement of his parts; who being in the high Road of Honour, wanted but few Å¿teps to a high preferment, which time, and his wiÅ¿e mannagement would neceÅ¿Å¿arily have courted him with, and conferred on him, This Gentleman (I Å¿ay) hapned by his great eÅ¿teem to be admitted to the preÅ¿ence of the King and Nobles; and once on a time when many Nobles of the Religion were preÅ¿ent with his MajeÅ¿ty, through Å¿ome occaÅ¿ion of a Treaty for a peaceable enjoyment of freedom of Religion according to the Edict.

At this time the King was highly moved with the ProteÅ¿tant Nobility; this young Gentleman, Å¿eeing the King angry, preÅ¿ently Å¿tepped to the King, and whether to pleaÅ¿e the
King, or to let his MajeÅ¿tie know he was thought worthy of counÅ¿el, by the great truÅ¿t Å¿ome had put him in, or moved by ambition to appear no Å¿tranger to the Kings neareÅ¿t Å¿ecreÅ¿ies, which Å¿ometimes in young wits many times runs before a diÅ¿creet conduct of their advantages; But he (I Å¿ay) whiÅ¿pers in the Kings ear, DeÅ¿iring his MajeÅ¿ty that he would pleaÅ¿e to Å¿ilence his mind, with a patient forbearance of anger, and to Å¿mile away their inÅ¿olency and folly, for his MajeÅ¿ty well knew that few days would ripen their deÅ¿truction, and lay them level to juÅ¿tice, which Å¿aies he, by a Å¿ecret policy of your MajeÅ¿ties great WiÅ¿dom and compleat contrivance, was almoÅ¿t brought to a full concluÅ¿ion laÅ¿t meeting; and which no doubt in the end will Å¿peedily, and Å¿ecurely, render your MajeÅ¿ty in a full and ample capacity to be avenged on their haughtineÅ¿s.

The King at theÅ¿e words Å¿tartled within himÅ¿elf, being touched at the quick to have Å¿uch a Å¿ecret imparted to one that was not of the conÅ¿piracy, whoÅ¿e raw retention might prove fatal to them all; wondering how, and by what means, he Å¿hould come to the knowledge thereof.

Now the King in whom lodged a knowledge beyond his years, diÅ¿Å¿embled his underÅ¿tanding at this time, and made no Å¿hew of any thing that might tend to the underÅ¿tanding of his Å¿peech; but Å¿peedily retired to his chamber, with a mind full of anxity and fury, and preÅ¿ently without any delayes examines the Count de Retz, who denies that ever he revealed any thing to any or to him; he then charged the Queen Mother, who anÅ¿wered Å¿he was

The King charges the MagiÅ¿trates of Paris, that none in the City Å¿hould offer the least affront to the Admirall or ProteÅ¿tants.After all the Kings favors to the ProteÅ¿tants and pulling down the Å¿tone CroÅ¿s, erected to

The King Å¿ends a ProteÅ¿tant Gentleman to invite the Admiral to Court who comes and is joyfully welcomed.Shortly after the King Å¿ends a Noble Gentleman of the ProteÅ¿tants, named Briquemault, to the Admiral, being a faithful aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tant of the Admirals, as alÅ¿o a man of Å¿ingular vertue, and eÅ¿teem among the ProteÅ¿tants, and at laÅ¿t proved a Å¿ad, though ChriÅ¿tian, Sufferer for the ProteÅ¿tant cauÅ¿e, him the King Å¿ends to the Admiral, to let him know, how greatly his MajeÅ¿ty longed for his counÅ¿el, in Å¿o weighty a buÅ¿ineÅ¿s as the War, which could not be done without his aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, and preÅ¿ent aid of his great WiÅ¿dom; and therefore was impatient of his delay. The Admiral at laÅ¿t is now perÅ¿waded and reÅ¿olved to go to Paris; he comes, and no Å¿ooner arrived, but was very honourably and affectionately embraced, with a courteous and joyful Å¿hew of welcome, and Å¿o was Å¿peedily conducted to the King, who under fair pretences of friendly ends, with a mouth full of courteÅ¿y; with well pleaÅ¿ed words, and a worÅ¿e tuned heart; with courteous expreÅ¿Å¿ions baited with TreaÅ¿on, he calls the Admiral Father, proteÅ¿ting, That in all his life he had not

The King of France: is afraid that his war in jeÅ¿t, might make the King of Spain war in earneÅ¿t.TheÅ¿e things troubled the King very much, for fear his counÅ¿els might be diÅ¿cloÅ¿ed to the King of Spain, and Å¿o might occaÅ¿ion Å¿ome quarrel, to the breaking forth of a War; yet he gave order to the Admiral to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the Prince of Orange in Germany with as many horÅ¿e and foot as he thought fit; which was done, and becauÅ¿e moneys might be had for their pay, the King called for the TreaÅ¿urer, and commanded him to deliver the Admiral Å¿o much money as he Å¿hould deÅ¿ire, commanding him that the receipt Å¿hould not expreÅ¿s the cauÅ¿e,Great diÅ¿Å¿imulation by the K. but Å¿hould run thus, Paid Å¿uch a Sum to the Admiral by the Kings Commandement, which is for certain uÅ¿es the King commands Å¿hould not be written; to which the King Å¿ubÅ¿cribes with his own hand; the King wrote a Letter alÅ¿o to Monducet, to uÅ¿e his beÅ¿t endravour for the releaÅ¿e of thoÅ¿e taken under the conduct of Genlis, by the Duke of Alva.

To the full effecting of their deÅ¿ire,A League with Q. Elizabeth of England, and the firÅ¿t Article was, the obÅ¿ervation of the Edict, but it proves a deep plot againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, and ties the hands of the EngliÅ¿h from all aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance in their greateÅ¿t need and extremity. it was thought convenient to enter into League with Queen Elizabeth of England, which the King committed to the Admiral, which he did Å¿o diligently and induÅ¿triouÅ¿ly handle, that by his elaborate pains, in a Å¿peedy time, By faith given, by EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours Å¿ent, and by Oaths it was confirmed, concerning a further procuring of other Leagues, as might moÅ¿t Å¿tand for the Low Country War, and of thoÅ¿e Leagues by the Admirals care, the principal Condition, was, That the Liberty of Religion Å¿hould be continued

The man that Å¿hot the Admiral, had commiÅ¿Å¿ion from the K. to do it. Ob horrible! Q. Mother, & many other viÅ¿it the Admiral. To which the King in his wonted Å¿train of courteÅ¿ie anÅ¿wered, He would perform his requeÅ¿t, and Å¿o in the afternoon the King goes to viÅ¿it the Admiral, taking along with him the Queen Mother, the Duke of Anjou, the Duke of MonpenÅ¿eir,

Å¿hould have as firm a guard for his perÅ¿on as he deÅ¿ired. THe King and Queen Mother by Letters, let the world know how the Admirall was hurt, to their great grief; They order a Guard for the Admiral, but is Å¿uch a one as Å¿ecured the Admiral, or any of his Friends, from eÅ¿caping their ruin; The Gentlemen of the Admirals Friends lodged in the Å¿ame Street where the Admirall lodged, which was deÅ¿ired in pretence of their Å¿ecurity alÅ¿o, but proved their Å¿ecure deÅ¿truction; The names of the ProteÅ¿tants in Paris, with their Å¿everal Lodgings put into a Catalogue; The Nobles and Gentlemen of the ProteÅ¿tants meet in the Admirals Chamber, and adviÅ¿es to remove for Å¿ecurity from the threatnings of an enÅ¿uing Å¿torm, yet reÅ¿olve to rely on the Kings Oaths, and PromiÅ¿es; The King and Queen Mother aÅ¿Å¿embles to take order
for the manner and time of the Admirals Murther; To colour this plot they order that it muÅ¿t be given out, That the occaÅ¿ion was through the difference betwixt the houÅ¿e of GuiÅ¿e and ChaÅ¿tillon; On ConÅ¿ultation it was reÅ¿olved to Å¿pare the King of Navar, and Prince of Conde, if they would turn PapiÅ¿ts; The Duke of GuiÅ¿e, and his bloody Followers force a Å¿trong report to be spread throughout all the City, of their danger by the Admirall and his Adherents, and Å¿o complain to the King, and depart the Court in Å¿hew of diÅ¿content, but privately lie in Paris to proÅ¿ecute his helliÅ¿h Plot, and the Kings command; two thouÅ¿and men on Sabbath night are commanded by the King to be in arms; The King Å¿ends word to the Admirall that he needs not fear, for all was done by his command; Some ProteÅ¿tant Gentlemen profer to watch all night with the Admiral, but were refuÅ¿ed; the Officers of the City AÅ¿Å¿emble, and are commanded by the King to deÅ¿troy the ProteÅ¿tants: The tokens to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the murtherers from others to be a Napkin about their arms, and a croÅ¿s
on their caps: Divers Lords guard the King all night: The bloody murtherers approach the Admiralls Lodging: The Admirall is fearful, yet often Å¿ilenced his Å¿uÅ¿pition by as often reiterating the Kings Oaths, PromiÅ¿es, Leagues, Covenants, and Law of Nations, &c. They enter his Lodging, kill all they meet with: The Admirall riÅ¿es, goes to prayer, and commands his Servants to Å¿ave their lives by flight: They get on the tops of houÅ¿es, but are perÅ¿ued and Å¿lain: They thruÅ¿t the Admirall through the body, beat him on the head, Å¿hoot him with a PiÅ¿tol, and wound him the third time, whereof he dies, his body thrown out of the window, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e kicks him on the face with his foot: They cry out Kill, Kill, this is the Kings command: The Alarum bell rings to a Å¿ad and generall MaÅ¿Å¿acre: The Admiralls head cut off and Å¿ent to the Pope: All in the Admiralls lodging murthered, among whom two young children of honourable birth: Brave Count Rochfoucault baÅ¿ely murthered: The Admiralls Son baÅ¿ely Å¿lain, his Lieutenant fights gallantly for his life, but is
Å¿lain: many brave Noblemen and Gentlemen baÅ¿ely murthered: they give the plunder to the Soldiers, crying kill, this is the Kings command: They Å¿pare neither young nor old, but kill women and children, and women with child, till the very Å¿treets are covered with dead bodies: nothing to be heard but Å¿ad crys and groans of the dying, with cruel Å¿houting of the Murtherers: The River dyed with blood: ten thouÅ¿and Å¿lain this day.

div.p: WE concluded the laÅ¿t chapter with the great preparations of the King, Queen Mother, and Councfl, ro effect their Plot; and yet how they coloured all with a diÅ¿tembling carriage of love too, and Å¿orrow for the Admirals condition; now in this chapter we Å¿hall Å¿ee the Å¿addeÅ¿t maÅ¿Å¿acre that ever was acted by any Prince, or in any Place.

Thus we leave the Admiral, baÅ¿ely, cowardly and bloodily wounded, and knew not how to have juÅ¿tice;The K. and Q. Mother write Letters teÅ¿tifying their Å¿orrow for the Admirals hurt, and yet done by the K. coÌmand. and Å¿o lay in his wounds expecting death as the inevitable iÅ¿Å¿ue of his Enemies cruelty.

Now we Å¿hall further Å¿ee the Kings diÅ¿Å¿imulation, and treachery; for the very Å¿ame day the Admiral was thus wounded, does the King (the more neatly to colour his own act of treachery, with Å¿mooth pretences) write Letters to EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours of Forein Princes, and Letters alÅ¿o to the Governours of all his
Provinces, Å¿hewing, How Å¿adly he reÅ¿ented the Admirals hurt. how ready he was to execute juÅ¿tice in the puniÅ¿hment of the Forgetting himÅ¿elf. Agent, deÅ¿iring that all the world might know how much How much it rejoiced his aeart, is no errata.
it did grieve him to the Soul, that any Å¿uch thing Å¿hould happen. And yet he pteÅ¿ently after declares openly, that he was Å¿lain by his Command, for treaÅ¿on againÅ¿t his perÅ¿on, as by other Letters we Å¿hall Å¿hew in due place.

But ChriÅ¿tian Reader, when thou peruÅ¿eÅ¿t the whole Å¿tory, then wilt thou be able to judge of this deep HypocriÅ¿ie before ehe face of God, and as it were againÅ¿t the face of Heaven!
But to proceed,

The King orders a Guard that the ProteÅ¿tants might not eÅ¿cape their Guard, being their Enemies, an intended for their Ruin.The Duke of Anjou, the Kings Brother, commanded CoÅ¿Å¿in Captain of the Kings Guard to place a band of Souldiers to watch before the Admirals Gate, giving Å¿trict charge that no Catholicks Å¿hould enter.
Now none could be pitched on as the grand Enemy to the Admiral and ProteÅ¿tants, and friend to the GuiÅ¿ans, than was this CoÅ¿Å¿in, as we Å¿hall Å¿ee by the following narrative.

The Admirals friends that lay Å¿cattered up and down the City, were deÅ¿ired under pretence of care and affection to remove their lodging into the Å¿ame Å¿treet with the Admiral, that they might be Å¿ure not to eÅ¿cape. Oh! MonÅ¿trous and HelliÅ¿h Plot, covered with the Kings care.Now the Duke of Anjou, as an inheriter of
his Brothers DiÅ¿Å¿imulation, Å¿trives alÅ¿o to colour his damnable Plot and TreaÅ¿on, in the lovingeÅ¿t and higheÅ¿t demonÅ¿trations and and care of the Admiral and ProteÅ¿tants, and therefore adviÅ¿es that the Admirals friends that now lodged Å¿o far diÅ¿tant from his perÅ¿on, as the Fauxburgh, might have liberty to have their lodgings neerer to him; for Å¿aies he, they being Å¿o far aÅ¿Å¿under, they might on any uproar be hurt, and no means to prevent it, which being neerer one another, they might join force to affection, and better afford one another their joint aid. Now this was a bait that took off all Å¿uÅ¿pition; for alas who could Å¿uÅ¿pect or imagine this to be out of any treacherous intent, but rather of care and reÅ¿pect? but Oh Å¿ad and helliÅ¿h plot under the vizard of friendÅ¿hip! theÅ¿e poor Noblemen, Gentlemen and brave Commanders that might have eÅ¿caped from the calamity, are intangled and allured into a narrow Å¿treet, as into a fold or narrow path of deÅ¿truction; no way to eÅ¿cape the fury of their Enemies rage and cruelty.

All the names of the ProteÅ¿tants and place of abode is taken into a Catalogue againÅ¿t the day of their calamity.The next day the Duke of Anjou and Duke of GuiÅ¿e, commanded the UndermaÅ¿ters of the Å¿treets, vulgarly termed Quartermen, to take a view of all the Inns and victual-houÅ¿es, from one houÅ¿e to another, and to take all the names of the ProteÅ¿tants, and Å¿o to bring in an Account of their names, and places of abode, in writing, and to deliver them to the Duke of Anjou, and Duke of GuiÅ¿e; Å¿o that preÅ¿ently after, the ProteÅ¿tants begun to diÅ¿cover Å¿ome bloody intentions, through the proÅ¿pect of
theÅ¿e preparations. Now the King had by this time Å¿et a Guard, of fifty Harquebuzeirs at the Gate of the Admirals Lodging; and great Å¿tore of Arms were carried into the Loure, and about the evening all the people of the City were in arms.

The ProteÅ¿tants meet advice given to remove from Paris, but they Å¿till reÅ¿olve to depend on the K. vows & promiÅ¿es.Hereupon the chief Noblemen and Gentlemen of the ProteÅ¿tants, aÅ¿Å¿emble together again in the Admirals lodging, where amongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t was the Vidame of Charteres, who as before, Å¿o now adviÅ¿ed Å¿peedily to try if by any means the Admiral might be forthwith carried out of Paris; and that preÅ¿ently the reÅ¿t Å¿hould diÅ¿lodge; yet all refuÅ¿ed this CounÅ¿el, reÅ¿olving to rely on the word of a King, Å¿ealed with Å¿o many Vowes, Covenants, and Solemn proteÅ¿tations in the preÅ¿ence of God, and to the clear witneÅ¿s of all Princes and States.

The K. and Q. meet and conÅ¿ult of their bloody cutting off the ProteÅ¿tants in a mercileÅ¿s cruelty and devilliÅ¿h maÅ¿Å¿acre.In the afternoon the King and Queen Mother walk forth into a Garden named Tegliers, accompanied with the Duke of Anjou, Gonzague, Tavignes, and Count de Retz, which garden being remote from ReÅ¿ort, was thought the fitteÅ¿t place for Å¿ecrecie, and a Å¿ilent place for privacy, and very well fitted for the preÅ¿ent concluÅ¿ion of their laÅ¿t and bloody conÅ¿ultation; Here in this bloody Council it was conÅ¿idered of and Å¿poken; That the Princes, Admiral, with the Noblemen, and Gentlemen of the Religion were now Å¿ecurely entangled in the Fetters of their own confidence, which was Å¿o well wedged into their minds, as priÅ¿ons could prove no better inÅ¿truments to ripen their deÅ¿ires; the Admiral he was lying bedÅ¿ick, and could not Å¿tir by reaÅ¿on of his wounds; the Prince of Conde was faÅ¿t in the CaÅ¿tle of
Loure; the City Gates kept Å¿hut all night, and watched all day; thoÅ¿e Gentlemen that lodged in the Suburbs, were now lodged in the Å¿ame Å¿treet with the Admiral, and all within the Gates of Paris; the reÅ¿t of the principal ProteÅ¿tants in other Towns were all unarmed and unprepared, beÅ¿ides there was not ten ProteÅ¿tants to a thouÅ¿and Catholicks, that the PariÅ¿ians were in arms, and able to make Å¿ixty thouÅ¿and fighting men, and that in one hour all might be Å¿lain, and if theÅ¿e were deÅ¿troyed they would never make head again in the Kingdom; but on the contrary, if the Admiral recover, Å¿uch an opportunity would never offer; therefore Å¿aies the Queen Mother this Å¿eaÅ¿on muÅ¿t not be loÅ¿t, but taking time by the Foretop, all our deÅ¿ires will now come to a period in a Å¿ucceÅ¿s proportionable to all our wiÅ¿hes; if we let Å¿lip time it withers, like a neglected roÅ¿e on a Å¿talk with a languiÅ¿hed head; if we Å¿hake hands with this golden opportunity, our deÅ¿igns will grow under the SunÅ¿hine of our deÅ¿ires; Thus they lie perdue under the Å¿helter of an unmercifull and bloody Balcony; all being reÅ¿olved to be Å¿o Å¿wift in execution of the Kings pleaÅ¿ure, that no time Å¿hall be delayed between his commands and the execution but the moment of performance, for now they reÅ¿olve to take journey from contemplation to action, they have learned the Theory of Treachery, perjury and cruelty, now they come to the practical part of this Å¿ad Tragedy.

But this being a groÅ¿s and downright murtherous way, and no handÅ¿ome Apology provided to caÅ¿t over the eyes of peoples underÅ¿tandings; it was thought fit to frame Å¿ome Å¿mooth
pretext,They Å¿tudy a Å¿mooth pretext for their bloody cruelty to coÅ¿en the vulgar conceptions, and honeÅ¿t interpretations: But oh! who can hide the greateÅ¿t Å¿ecrets from Gods Å¿earching eye? to take off the force and dint of vulgar reports; and Å¿o to divert the natural current of this tragedy, into the illegitimate name of convenient neceÅ¿Å¿ity; whereupon they order that the common vogue of the peoples tongues Å¿hould be tipt with this Å¿pecious pretence, that the Duke of GuiÅ¿e and Admirals enmity was the cauÅ¿e of this MaÅ¿Å¿acre.

They reÅ¿olve to Å¿pare the K. of Navar and Prince of Conde if they will turn PapiÅ¿tsNow in this bloody AÅ¿Å¿embly it was moved whether the King of Navar, and Prince of Conde, Å¿hould be deÅ¿troyed in this MaÅ¿Å¿acre, or whether Å¿aved; the King of Navar in regard of his affinity, was concluded to be Å¿aved; but for the Prince of Conde, it was doubtfully carred; they conÅ¿idered firÅ¿t, whether for his age it were beÅ¿t to Å¿pare him, or Å¿econdly whether to put him to death in revenge of his Fathers protection of the ProteÅ¿tant cauÅ¿e, as alÅ¿o in a hatred of his Fathers name; the Duke of GuiÅ¿e urged with a preÅ¿Å¿ing forwardneÅ¿s to have both the Prince of Navar, and the Prince of Conde to dy amongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t, but all thought that too abominable (if any thing could be Å¿o indeed to Å¿uch bloodthirÅ¿ty wretches) that two young Princes, in the flower of their age, of the Royal Family, the one in the imbraces of his dear SpowÅ¿e, under the protection of Å¿uch neer friends, and late conjunction by mariage, that they Å¿hould be Å¿o miÅ¿erably deÅ¿troyed; Å¿o that the opinion of Gonzague was prevalent, who pleaded, that with fear of death, and torment, they Å¿hould be violently turned to the
Catholick Religion.The plot is committed to the Duke of GuiÅ¿e to put in execution next day. And Å¿o this HelliÅ¿h vaux-like Council broke up with firm and fixed ReÅ¿olutions, to act their Å¿everal parts; and Å¿o it was appointed, that next morning about three or four a cloak, it Å¿hould be put in execution, and that all things Å¿hould be committed to the mannagement and care of the Duke of GuiÅ¿e.

On Saturday morning it is bruited and noiÅ¿ed throughout all the City of Paris, A report is Å¿pread that the Duke of GuiÅ¿e was in danger of the Admiral and friends. that the HouÅ¿e of G â¢ iÅ¿e was in danger of the Admiral and reÅ¿t of the ProteÅ¿tants, by their great threatenings; The Dukes of GuiÅ¿e and Aumale Å¿peed to the King, and complain of their danger, and inÅ¿olent threatnings of the Admiral and Adherents againÅ¿t their lives, proteÅ¿ting Å¿orrow to his MajeÅ¿tie that their Å¿ervices were not accepted, but their perÅ¿ons Å¿lighted, and Å¿o deÅ¿ired leave of his MajeÅ¿ty to abÅ¿ent from Court, and retire to their houÅ¿es,The Kings horrible diÅ¿Å¿embling for they were ready to depart; the King with a frowning countenance, Å¿aies, Go where you pleaÅ¿e, I will have you at all times if you be found guilty of the Admirals Hurt. So with a Å¿hew of diÅ¿content they mount their HorÅ¿es, and bloody reÅ¿olutions at once, but inÅ¿tead of going home they ly in Paris all night.Bloody treachery. The King Å¿ends the Duke of GuiÅ¿e to provide 2000 men in arms on Sabbath day at night.

All things being reÅ¿olved on, the 24. day of AuguÅ¿t, being Sabbath day, at twilight the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, with orders from the King comes to PreÅ¿ident Charron, ProvoÅ¿t des Marchands, the chief head of the People of Paris, giving him to underÅ¿tand, that by the Kings command he was fotthwith to provide and order in readineÅ¿s two thouÅ¿and armed men, which accordingly was done.

The Admiral having word brought thim, that
there was great noiÅ¿e of armour,The Admirall at the noiÅ¿e of armour fears danger, and Å¿ends to the King. Oh! bloody and cruel command of a King. They refuÅ¿e to let any ProteÅ¿tant Gentlemen to watch with the Admiral. The Officers aÅ¿Å¿emble and are commanded by the King to deÅ¿troy the ProteÅ¿tants whom he calls Rebells. and great threatnings heard in all parts of the City, and preparations of all things in order for a tumult that night; preÅ¿ently he Å¿ends word to the King, who gave anÅ¿wer, that the Admiral needed not fear, for all was done by his command, and that he had appointed in certain places of the Citie, a number of men in arms for fear of any tumult.
This evening Å¿ome ProteÅ¿tant Gentlemen profer to watch with the Admiral, but poor Gentlemen they were refuÅ¿ed: A Å¿ad preÅ¿age of Treachery, my heart relents and bleeds to write the reÅ¿t.

When the Duke of GuiÅ¿e Å¿aw all things ready, he called to him one Marcel, charging him a little after midnight to aÅ¿Å¿emble together the MaÅ¿ters of the Streets (commonly called Diziners) into the Town HouÅ¿e, for he was to declare from his MajeÅ¿ty, and by his command, Å¿everal things; they aÅ¿Å¿emble according to the appointed time, Charron the ProvoÅ¿t des Marchands guarded with Entrague, Puygailart, and certain other GuiÅ¿ans, did there declare, that the King had given him in command to deÅ¿troy all the Rebells (meaning the ProteÅ¿tants) to cut off root and branch of that Rebellious race, letting them underÅ¿tand, that the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s was Å¿o mannaged to their hands, that now with great facility his MajeÅ¿ties deÅ¿ire might be accompliÅ¿hed; for the Admiral, and all the chief were Å¿ecurely under their power, being lodged within the walls of the City; that it was firÅ¿t intended they Å¿hould begin with the Admiral, and the principal ProteÅ¿tants lodged in that Å¿treet, and then with Å¿peedy alacrity to

Now for better order in this bloody undertaking, the token given Å¿hould be with ringing the great Bell of the Palace, called TockÅ¿ein, at break of day, which Å¿aid bell was only rung on great and emergent occaÅ¿ions, and that the diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing marks Å¿hould be a white croÅ¿s on their caps, that candles Å¿hould be lighted at every window, that without confuÅ¿ion or diÅ¿order they might proceed from houÅ¿e to houÅ¿e to the exact execution of the Kings command.

The Duke of MontpenÅ¿eir and Duke of Nevers, with many other Lords of the Court, take arms, and being accompanied with their Friends, guard the Kings perÅ¿on, all the Guards being in Arms at the Gates of the Lour.

At the Prefixt hour the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, the Duke of Aumale. and MonÅ¿ieur de AngouleÅ¿m, Grand Prior of France, the Kings baÅ¿tard Brother, with other Commanders to the number of three hundred, went to the Admirals

The Admiral is Å¿till perÅ¿waded of the K. fidelity, & repeated his Oaths, PromiÅ¿es, Leagues, Publick Faith, Å¿acred reÅ¿pect to the Law of Nations, and credit with other Princes.By this time the Admiral underÅ¿tood of the noiÅ¿e, and though he had but ten perÅ¿ons in his houÅ¿e able to bear arms, and in his own chamber but two Chirurgians, one MiniÅ¿ter, and two Servitors; yet was he Å¿o confident of the K. promiÅ¿e, as he could not be made afraid, truÅ¿ting (as he often did repeat) upon the Kings good will to him, teÅ¿tified by Å¿o many and ample proofs of aÅ¿Å¿urance. having like confidence, that if the PariÅ¿ians did but once know the Kings mind to be againÅ¿t this tumult, they would Å¿oon ceaÅ¿e, but eÅ¿pecially when they Å¿aw CoÅ¿Å¿in the Kings own Captain waching at the gates for his defence.

But alas he did little think who they were, and by whoÅ¿e command, or to what intent, all was don; theÅ¿e reaÅ¿ons were the Admirals Remora's, to Å¿top the paÅ¿Å¿age of any belief of treaÅ¿on hid in the Kings heart: and it is commonly found that moÅ¿t Å¿uffer Shipwrack on the rocks of crudelity; and as one Å¿aies, it is no hereÅ¿ie to affirm, That many have been Å¿aved by their infidelity.

The Admiral recounted the Oath and Edict of Pacification, Å¿o openly and Å¿o often Å¿worn,
recorded by the King, Queen Mother and the reÅ¿t. The late League with Queen Elizabeth of England. The Articles covenanted with the Prince of Orange. His faith given to the Princes of Germany. They enter the Admirals lodging, kill all they meetAs Å¿oon as the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, and bloody Noblemen drew neer the Admirals lodging, CoÅ¿Å¿in knockt at the Gate, which he was to keep (a goodly guard for the wolf to keep the Sheep) he that opened the Gate was preÅ¿ently Å¿tabbed, as Å¿oon as they enter with a number of armed men they kill all they find within the porch. which were a few of the King of Navars Harquebuzeirs; only one eÅ¿caped to the Admirals Chamber; crying, Sir the Lord calls

Then Mr. Merlin the MiniÅ¿ter with the reÅ¿t, got up to the top of the HouÅ¿e, creeping out of the Windows to the Gutters to hide themÅ¿elves, but alas, moÅ¿t of them were Å¿ought out and Å¿lain in the next houÅ¿e; yet through Gods mercy the MiniÅ¿ter wounderfully eÅ¿caped; as you may at large Å¿ee in the reverend Author Mr. Clark his Examples, a Book worth the peruÅ¿al of every ChriÅ¿tian.

His body thrown out of the window, the D. of GuiÅ¿e with his foot kicks him on the face.Now the Duke of GuiÅ¿e and reÅ¿t of the Noblemen, Å¿taied below in the Court to hear how things went; the Duke of GuiÅ¿e with a lowd voice cryed, HaÅ¿t thou done BenveÅ¿e? who replied, I have done, the Duke replied our Chevalier (the Kings beÅ¿tard Brother) will not believe it, unleÅ¿s he Å¿ee it, throw him out of the Window; So BenveÅ¿e with the help of the reÅ¿t did lift his body to the window, who yet breathing laid hold with his hand on the window, but theÅ¿e butcherly blood-hounds and

They proceed, crying kill, this is che K. comand, this is the K. comand.PreÅ¿ently the Duke of GuiÅ¿e and his ignoble Train of Nobles, goes out of the Court, crying, Armour, Armour, we have had good Å¿ucceÅ¿s, and a happy beginning, let us now proceed to the reÅ¿t, for it is the Kings Commandment; which words he repeated often, This is the Kings command, This is his commandment, this is his Will, this is his expreÅ¿s PleaÅ¿ure.

The Alarm bell rings to a general MaÅ¿Å¿acre.Then was cauÅ¿ed to ring the bloody token for a General Alarum, being the great Bell of the Palace, and inÅ¿tantly it was bruted and publiÅ¿hed as the cauÅ¿e of this Murther, That the ProteÅ¿tants had conÅ¿pired againÅ¿t the King, Queen, and Court; and were about to put this deÅ¿ign into practice, being armed to that purpoÅ¿e.

The Admirals body cruelly abuÅ¿ed, his head cut off and Å¿ont to the Pope by the King.Then a certain Italian of Gonzagues band, cut off the Admirals head, which was Å¿ent to the King and Queen Mother, and by them preÅ¿erved with Å¿pices, and Å¿o Å¿ent to the Pope, and Cardinal of Lorrain at Rome, as a rich PreÅ¿ent; Others cut off his hands, others his Å¿ecret parts, then the common raÅ¿cally rable for three daies together dragged his dead body
