All they find in the Admirals lodging are baÅ¿ely murthered, among whom 2 children of honourable birth.Now the Nobles and their cruel Murtherers brake into the reÅ¿t of the Admirals chambers, and thoÅ¿e they found in their beds, or hidden in any corners, they mangled with many bloody-wounds, and Å¿o cruelly deÅ¿troyed them, amongÅ¿t which number thus Å¿lain, was two young innocent babes, Pages of an honourable birth and extract; which indeed Å¿eemed to all that heard it to be too great an act of cruelty; but what was bad enough to be done was their beÅ¿t deeds, whereby they hoped with the help of the Popes Bulls to prove not only pardonable, but alÅ¿o meritorious.

At the Å¿ame time alÅ¿o, and in the Å¿ame place, the Admirals Son Teligny was Å¿lain; he was a young Gentleman of great accompliÅ¿hments both of wit and valor, inÅ¿omuch that the King by his reÅ¿pects and affections Å¿hewed to him, did do homage to his great deÅ¿erts, even to exalting him to the higheÅ¿t Å¿train of Adulation; this gallant young Gentleman, I Å¿ay, being deÅ¿igned to Å¿uch a cowardly death, and baÅ¿e murther, cryed out, That now he Å¿aw it was even grievous for him to live, in that he was the cauÅ¿e of his Fathers confidence of the Kings Love, in that he had often commended the Kings faithfulneÅ¿s to him; and Å¿o this brave Gentleman refuÅ¿ed not this death offered him, yielding his life as a Å¿acrifice to their wrath and cruelty, and thus was this poor Gentleman miÅ¿erably butchered.

His Lieutenant Å¿hews great valor, and fights Å¿toutly, but is murthered.But his Lieutenant, a reÅ¿olute and brave young Gentleman, having the advantage of his arms, lengthened out his life in a Å¿tiff and Å¿tout reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, Å¿hewing that he would do what he could not, who like a valiant Souldier, wrapping his cloak about his arm he fought for his life to the feeling and applauÅ¿e of his bloody and mercileÅ¿s enemies, but at laÅ¿t overpowred with number and Å¿trength, was as unworthily Å¿lain as highly applauded.

Many brave Noblemen & Gentlemen baÅ¿ely bloodily and inhumanly murthered in their chambers and Å¿treetsAt this time alÅ¿o was murthered Collonel Montaumar, and Rouray Son to the Baron Des Adretts, with all the reÅ¿t of the Gentlemen that had relation to the Admiral; amongÅ¿t whom were many flouriÅ¿hing young Noblemen, and Gentlemen, all being baÅ¿ely and cruelly murthered, and butchered in the prime of their youth, and Å¿o cut off from all future hopes of high attempts; who as they were the cream of the ProteÅ¿tnt Gallantry, Å¿o were they the But of their Enemies cruelty. And thus fell theÅ¿e Noble Gentlemen, that at all times carried Å¿o much intrinÅ¿ick worth as purchaÅ¿ed immortal praiÅ¿e.

After this, CoÅ¿Å¿ins Souldiers with the Noblemens bands,The Soldiers encoraged to blood by having the plunder free for their reward. Men, Women and children murthered, & children taken out of the womb alive and murthered, the Å¿treet Å¿trewed with dead bodys went ranÅ¿acking from HouÅ¿e to houÅ¿e, tearing all away that was worth carriage, and in Å¿uch a manner as is commonly done at taking a Town by Å¿torm; and Å¿o many grew rich by others poverty; For the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, Duke of MontpenÅ¿cir, the Cavalleir King Henry's baÅ¿tard, Gonzague, Tavignes, and other Principal Lords, encouraged the Soldiers to proceed to blood with promiÅ¿e of all the booty free for their pains, Å¿till crying out, This is the Kings commandment.

So all the day from Morning to evening, the skum of the City, the gleanings of all villains, did run up and down with their bloody Swords raging and glorying in their bloody MaÅ¿Å¿acres, & unheard of murthers; for they Å¿pared not the aged, nor the women with child, nor the poor innocent babes, Å¿ome whereof being taken alive out of their Mothers wombs, without pitty they cruelly and preÅ¿ently deÅ¿troyed, and in a Triumphant joy they threw the Å¿lain bodies out of the Windows, inÅ¿omuch that there
was Å¿carce a lane that was not Å¿trewed with the dead bodies of the poor ProteÅ¿tants.

Nothing to be heard but the doleful crys and groans of the dying, and terrible noiÅ¿e of the murtherersAnd as the City felt the rage of theÅ¿e Tygers, Å¿o the Suburbs alÅ¿o, where was nothing but murthering, and all Å¿orts of cruelties committed, men, women and children, rich and poor, old and young, nothing to be heard in Paris, and the Subburbs, but a horrible and terrible noiÅ¿e of arms, horÅ¿es, and harquebuziers, with a doleful, Å¿ad, and lamentable howling, and crying of poor Å¿ouls going to the Å¿laughter, and knew not wherefore; a piteous complaint of Å¿uch as cryed to the villains for mercy; together with the mercileÅ¿s and cruel Å¿houts of murtherers, and bloody Hell-hounds, crying kill, deÅ¿troy, for the King commands it, mixed with the Å¿ad groans of the dying; that it Å¿eemed as if heaven and earth had met together, as if the Heavens would have rent with thunder.

Oh! Å¿ad, Oh! wretched King, to Å¿tain thy honour with Å¿uch perfidious breach of promiÅ¿e, to water thy Kingdom with the blood of Gods people, and Å¿o to diÅ¿Å¿emble with the world, as if diÅ¿Å¿embling were further from thy thoughts than thy heart from reality.

Streets and Rivers dyed with blood.The Pavement, Market place, and Rivers, were died with blood, and it was heard Å¿ay, by the murtherers, that they had put an end to that quarrel, that neither pen, paper, decrees of JuÅ¿tice, nor open War could accompliÅ¿h in twelve years. 10000. proteÅ¿tants murthered, in one day by the K. command.

About ten thouÅ¿and Å¿ouls makes this Lords day famous for ever, with effuÅ¿ion of their pretious and innocent blood, Å¿uch as no age or time can parallel; for there was at this time
in Paris, Å¿ixty thouÅ¿and men, with PiÅ¿tols, Pikes, Poinyards, Curtelaces, Knives, and Å¿uch other bloody InÅ¿truments, who run up and down Å¿wearing and blaÅ¿peming the Å¿acred MajeÅ¿ty of God; cruelly maÅ¿Å¿acring all they meet, the Å¿treets being covered with mangled bodies, Gates and doors defiled with blood; And yet we Å¿ee but in part what cruelties were committed, if we compare what we have read, and what we Å¿hall read together.

For now having given thee a Å¿ight of Å¿uch Treachery, PoiÅ¿onings, perjuries, Cruelties, and damnable diÅ¿Å¿imulations, with the many murthers committed on the Admiral and Friends in Paris, I Å¿hall endeavour in the next chapter, to give a taÅ¿t of Å¿uch Å¿ad MaÅ¿Å¿acres, and cruelties, as will affright and aÅ¿toniÅ¿h the heart of any true ProteÅ¿tant; and if thou haÅ¿t any grain of true ChriÅ¿tianity in thee, thou canÅ¿t not but be toucht with a fellow-feeling of theÅ¿e Å¿ad and unheard of murthers and crueltys.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.head: The Contents.
argument.p:
THe King labours to turn the King of Navar, and Prince of Conde, to the Catholick Religion, by threatning of death, and promiÅ¿es of Life; Their anÅ¿wers; Many Gallant and PeerleÅ¿s Commanders, hewen in peeces at the Loure, crying out to the Kings Oaths and PromiÅ¿es in the Kings hearing; That brave and unparalleled Commander MonÅ¿ieur de Piles baÅ¿ely Å¿lain, crying out aloud to the King, proteÅ¿ting againÅ¿t his treacherous cruelty and perjury; Two hundred gallant Gentlemen Å¿lain; Count de Montgomery, and Vidame of Charteres eÅ¿cape to England; A Plot againÅ¿t Rochel, but prevented; La Charite Å¿urprized, and all the ProteÅ¿tants cut off; The murther at Paris renewed next day; the bodies of
the dead thrown into the River Sein; In two daies above ten thouÅ¿and Å¿lain, whereof five hundred of Noble blood, Gentlemen, with many Ladies and Gentlewomen, that came to the mariage; The King Å¿ends by PoÅ¿t to command all the ProteÅ¿tants to be cut off, following the example of Paris; Three Noble Gentlemen in the Court murthered; The Å¿trange, Å¿ad and cruel death of a brave Gentleman MonÅ¿ieur de la Place; Peter Ramus, that famous ProfeÅ¿Å¿or of Logick baÅ¿ely Å¿lain; A Å¿ad yet comfortable death of a Godly young ChriÅ¿tian; A terrible and unheard-of cruelty committed on a Gentlewoman with child; MercileÅ¿s cruelty committed on a poor child; The moÅ¿t Cruel, Horrid and unheard of butchery at Lyons, not to be paralleled in any age, the blood running through the Å¿treets reeking hot, to the terrour of the Catholicks themÅ¿elves; The Bloody MaÅ¿Å¿acre at Meaux; The like Å¿ad MaÅ¿Å¿acre at Troys; The bloody Murthers at Orleans; The cruel butcheries at TholouÅ¿e: The cruel Å¿laughters and bloody murthering of Å¿ix thouÅ¿and ProteÅ¿tants at Roan. The
Murthers at Angiers; A Godly MiniÅ¿ter that had laid the firÅ¿t foundation of a Church in Paris, is murthered by the Kings command.

div.p: WHilÅ¿t theÅ¿e Å¿ad cruelties were executed at the Admirals Lodging, and in the City and Suburbs of Paris, Let us now behold with pitty a number of brave Commanders murthered in the Kings CaÅ¿tle of the Loure, by the Kings commandement, and in his Å¿ight. For the King of Navar and Prince of Conde did lodge in the Loure, with many other brave Commanders, which came to accompany the King of Navar and Prince of Conde.

The K. promiÅ¿es pardon to the King of Navar, & Prince of Conde, if they will turn PapiÅ¿ts.The firÅ¿t thing the King falls on after his bloody Butchery in Paris, was to deal with the King of Navar and Prince of Conde, to whom he gave command to be brought into his preÅ¿ence.

The King told them all that was done, that he had now cut off all the inÅ¿truments of the late Civil Wars, and he hoped would prove a prevention of future troubles; for by his command the Admiral was Å¿lain with his Train, and that no leÅ¿s was done in other Cities to all the ProteÅ¿tants; but Å¿aies he, by reaÅ¿on of your young and tender years, and neer alliance in conÅ¿anguinity and marriage, therefore it is I deÅ¿ire you Å¿hould be pardoned; but we Å¿hall Å¿ee it on Å¿ad terms to theÅ¿e poor tender hearts, ready to break with grief at their friends death, and their own too Å¿ad and rigid fate. Poor Princes betrayed by the cruelty of a perfidious
mercileÅ¿s King; The King tells them their Lives depended on the reforming their Judgements, and turning to the Catholique Religion, for he is reÅ¿olved never to have any more than one Religion in his Kingdom; and if they embraced not this Snake in their boÅ¿ome, they muÅ¿t be Å¿tung with his bloody Sword, as the deÅ¿erts of their obÅ¿tinacy.

The K. of Navars anÅ¿wer to the K. of France. The King of Navar humbly beÅ¿eeched his MajeÅ¿ty to remember his PromiÅ¿es, Engagements, and now the near alliance by mariage, lately contracted, and not to force him in thoÅ¿e things, which only he muÅ¿t be accountable to God alone for: that he would pleaÅ¿e rather to impriÅ¿on his body, than his Å¿oul, and not to force him to make Å¿hipwrack of a good conÅ¿cience by a violent aÅ¿Å¿ault.

Now the Prince of Conde like a reÅ¿olved ChriÅ¿tian alÅ¿o,The P. of Conde's zealom anÅ¿wer to the King. did with much zeal anÅ¿wer the King in this manner, That he having given his Oaths, and promlÅ¿es in Å¿olemn and publick ProteÅ¿tations to all of the Religion, would not, he hoped, forget the great ty of performance, which all men are bound to obÅ¿erve, under pain of Gods heavy Judgements, and therefore he wondered his MajeÅ¿ty Å¿hould Å¿o Å¿oon be perÅ¿waded to break his moÅ¿t Solemn Vows and ProteÅ¿tations, which by the Law of God and Nations he was bound to keep, but know (Å¿aies this noble Prince) that for my Religion it is Å¿o cloÅ¿ely enÅ¿hrined in a fixed reÅ¿olution to preÅ¿erve with my Å¿oul, that it is beyond the reach of Mortality, and I hope by Gods grace, am Å¿o reÅ¿olved, that loÅ¿s of life Å¿hall not Å¿hake my Å¿teddy Å¿oul to batter my conÅ¿cience. And though your great threatnings peirce my underÅ¿tanding,
yet Å¿hall they not make me loÅ¿e my hold of that Religion, which by Gods grace is planted, and by your promiÅ¿es, and oaths freely granted to me the free exerciÅ¿e of, and as for my body and goods you may uÅ¿e as you pleaÅ¿e, but my unÅ¿potted Å¿oul is in the hands of God.

Many Nobles and brave Commanders, that waited on the K. of Navar, and Prince of Conde, by the K. order, and in his fight are cut in peices, crying out to his Oaths and PromiÅ¿es. Brave MonÅ¿ieur de Piles his Å¿ad death lamented and pittied by his enemies yet baÅ¿ely murthered in the K. fightThis notable anÅ¿wer of this tender young Prince, did Å¿o move his raging cruelty, that letting looÅ¿e the reins of his furious indignation, he calls him Rebell, and the Son of a Rebellious perÅ¿on, with horrible threatnings that he Å¿hould loÅ¿e his life, if within three daies he did not obey his command, and without any more ado, he aÅ¿Å¿aults him with a furious countenance, iÅ¿Å¿uing out theÅ¿e terrible words MaÅ¿s, Death, or BaÅ¿tile.

But now their poor Friends that waited upon them, being many gallant Gentlemen, as alÅ¿o their Servitors in their chambers, their SchoolmaÅ¿ters, and thoÅ¿e that had the bringing them up, were thruÅ¿t out one, by one, among the crowd of Murtherers, being the K. Guard of Switzers, that Å¿tood in two ranks, prepared for blood and cruelty: TheÅ¿e Gentlemen crying out to the Kings Oaths, PromiÅ¿es, and fidelity, were nevertheleÅ¿s by the K. command, and in his own Å¿ight, unmercifully hewen and cut in pieces.

There did dy of note amongÅ¿t theÅ¿e in the Loure, the MarqueÅ¿s de Rennet, with Å¿everal others of noble blood, as alÅ¿o many brave Gentlemen, but no mans death was Å¿o much bemoaned of many both friends and enemies as brave MonÅ¿ieur de Piles, whoÅ¿e valour, though great, yet could not be victor over his Religious
and Godly zeal, whoÅ¿e great courage and greater ChriÅ¿tianity, fought for MaÅ¿tery: for he had defended (as aforeÅ¿aid) the little Town of St. Jean de Angeli, againÅ¿t the K. great Army for fourty daies, who at laÅ¿t yielded not Å¿o much to their valour as their number.

There this brave Commander got Å¿uch Renown, that of his Enemies who felt his valor he was highly honoured, and was thought to be beloved, and much eÅ¿teemed of by the King. This brave de Piles, I Å¿ay, with Leranne, Odou's Son, were both lodged (by the Kings command) all night in a Wardrope next the King of Navars own chamber; but this command of the Kings was looked on by the poor Gallant Gentlemen rather to be an act of Å¿pecial favour, then baÅ¿e treachery; theÅ¿e noble Commanders, a little before day, hearing a great noiÅ¿e of running of men in Armour, with doleful cryings, and howlings of the Å¿lain for mercy, wondered what Å¿hould be the matter, and Å¿o aroÅ¿e; who were no Å¿ooner up, but de Naunce approaches their chamber; and tells them, it was the Kings Commandment that they Å¿hould come down into the Court, leaving their weapons behind them, and Å¿o to depart out of the CaÅ¿tle.

He diÅ¿claims againÅ¿t the Kings treachery Proclaiming his Trayterous infidelity and cruelty in the Kings hearing.Now when this brave MonÅ¿ieur de Piles Å¿aw himÅ¿elf diÅ¿armed, and thruÅ¿t out amongÅ¿t the murthering Souldiers, who Å¿tood ready to kill him, and viewing the Å¿ad Å¿pectacles of Å¿o many
of Å¿o many of Gods people already Å¿lain, he cryes out with a loud voice to the peircing of the Kings ear; proteÅ¿ting againÅ¿t the Trayterous infidelity of his bloody cruelty; that Covenants nor Oaths could not bind his looÅ¿e hands and cruel heart, no more than fetters can ty the raging Ocean; but who is deaÅ¿er than he that will not hear, for his words peirced the air, but not this Tyrants heart. So having a rich Cloak, he takes it off, and gives it an acquaintance, Saying, Take here this token of Piles, and let poÅ¿terity know poor Piles moÅ¿t Å¿hamefully, cowardly and unworthily Å¿lain, by the perfidious command of a perjured King; Oh! my good and noble MonÅ¿ieur de Piles, replyed he, I am none of them, I thank you for your Cloak, but I will not receive it on that condition,He is thruÅ¿t out amongÅ¿t the Murtherers, & Å¿lain. Å¿o immediately MonÅ¿ieur de Piles was thruÅ¿t through the body with a PartiÅ¿an by one of the Kings Guard, and Å¿o was there baÅ¿ely murthered and Å¿lain.

And thus died this moÅ¿t noble and valiant Gentleman, pittyed by his Enemies that knew him to be a valiant Commander; thus was he haled to a cowardly death, that never knew what compulÅ¿ion meant, but when his virtues and valour, incited him to good actions; Å¿o his body was thrown into the quarry with the reÅ¿t, the beholders crying out, theÅ¿e are the Traytors that plotted our deÅ¿truction, and would have killed our King.

Now it pleaÅ¿ed God to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of Leranne otherwiÅ¿e, who being thruÅ¿t through the Body with a Å¿word eÅ¿caped by running into the Queen of Navars chamber who preÅ¿erved him
from their cruelty and preÅ¿ently obtained his pardon: and alÅ¿o by the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of her own Doctor of PhyÅ¿ick, he recovered and lived.

200 Gallant Noblemen and Gentlemen baÅ¿ely Å¿lain by the K. command.AmongÅ¿t theÅ¿e Gentlemen, and at the Å¿ame time, was alÅ¿o murthered, Pontbreton, Pluviault, Bandine, Francourt, Chancellour to the King of Navar, Pardillan, Lavardin, and other chief Commanders Gentlemen to the number of two hundred, whoÅ¿e cryes no more peirced the Kings cruel heart, than an arrow can an Adamantine Rock.

Count De Montgomery, and the Vidam of Charteres with Å¿ome others eÅ¿cape to England. Now it fell out by Gods good providence otherwiÅ¿e with thoÅ¿e of the ProteÅ¿tants that lodged in the Fauxburg, At St. Germain beyond the Sein, amongÅ¿t whom was the Count de Montgomery, and the Vidame of Charteres; who preÅ¿aging Å¿ome intended miÅ¿chief, having a cleer foreÅ¿ight of this TempeÅ¿t, provided for an eÅ¿cape, and Å¿o would by no means be drawn to lodge with the Admiral; who now hearing the noiÅ¿e and underÅ¿tanding the matter inÅ¿tantly fled, but were quickly perÅ¿ued by their grand enemie the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, who as Å¿oon as the day had relieved the night, paÅ¿Å¿ed the water with many horÅ¿e and foot, and overtaking the ProteÅ¿tants in their flight found Å¿ome without Å¿hoes, Å¿ome without arms, others without Saddles, Å¿ome without bridles, all equally unable to make reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, and Å¿o were without mercy Å¿cattered and cut off, the Count De Montgomery and Vidame of Charteres with about ten in company by the good mercy of God Å¿aved themÅ¿elves, and after many dangers and difficulties got to the Sea Å¿ide, and Å¿o eÅ¿caped over to England, bringing Å¿ad news in their dejected countenances for the loÅ¿s of their
dear and pretious Friends; who were alÅ¿o as kindly welcomed by our good Queen Elizabeth as Å¿afely eÅ¿caped from the cruelty of their treacherous and perjured King.

WhilÅ¿t theÅ¿e bloody and unheard of crueltys were committed in Paris, A bloody plot againÅ¿t Rochel, but prevented. Strozzi the Kings Admirals lay hovering at Rochel, endeavouring to Å¿urprize it, under pretence of a Banquet to be made for his Friends of the CaÅ¿tle of La Cheine, but being diÅ¿covered he retreated without the effects of his deÅ¿ire, or performance of the Kings command.

The ProteÅ¿tants murthered at La Charite. The murthers at Paris is renewed next day.But the poor ProteÅ¿tants of La Charite as aforeÅ¿aid was entraped by the Italian horÅ¿e, and were now put to the Sword.

But to return to the bloody City of Paris, the next day the Å¿laughter was renewed, for all that was found hidden in corners or private places of the City were all Å¿ought out, brought forth, and murthered, inÅ¿omuch that the day before, and this day were maÅ¿Å¿acred in Paris, above ten thouÅ¿and ProteÅ¿tants of all degrees and Å¿exes, the very common Labourers, Porters, and the moÅ¿t raÅ¿cally and deÅ¿perate villains of the City, did this day abuÅ¿e the dead bodies by pulling off their cloaths, and throwing them naked into the River of Sein. The places of preferment which now lay empty by reaÅ¿on of this horrid maÅ¿Å¿acre, were now by the King given to whom he pleaÅ¿ed. The Admirals office he gave to the MarqueÅ¿s de Villars &c. And Å¿o like a true Tyrant leaves nothing his poor Subjects can call their own but their miÅ¿eries.

In this butcherly MaÅ¿Å¿acre at Paris were Å¿acked above four thouÅ¿and houÅ¿es, and above
five hundred Barons, Knights, and Gentlemen, who had held the chiefeÅ¿t imployments in the War, with many noble and gallant yong Ladies and Gentlewomen that had now purpoÅ¿ly met together from all parts, to rejoice in honour of the King of Navars mariage with the L. Margaret, who poor Noblemen, Gentlemen & Ladies thought of nothing more then of jollity and pleaÅ¿ures, but now Å¿uffer the Tyrannical rage of a furious King, and bloody death to be pittied by all that Å¿hall hear this Å¿ad Å¿tory; for poor Ladies they expected no Å¿uch tragical welcome from a Royal King, contrary to his Oaths, and their Å¿potleÅ¿s innocency: and it muÅ¿t needs Å¿tick as the greateÅ¿t badge of inhumanity and cowardice, nay a true character of a bad cauÅ¿e, To murther like Devils, not fight like men.

Immediately after theÅ¿e unheard of murthers were acted in Paris, the King not yet glutted with blood, Å¿ends MeÅ¿Å¿engers by poÅ¿t to all parts of the Kingdom (often Å¿hifting horÅ¿es for more Å¿peed) with expreÅ¿s command to all other Cities, to follow the example of Paris, commanding all ProteÅ¿tants which were amongÅ¿t them to be Å¿lain; and yet at the Å¿ame time the Å¿ame King writes other Letters, wherein he laid the fault of the Murthers upon the Admiral and the Duke of GuiÅ¿e. Now this command of the King to cut off all the ProteÅ¿tants in all Towns and Cities under his command, it cannot he expreÅ¿Å¿ed how chearfully, willingly and readily they were obeyed by the greateÅ¿t part of the Cities in France, for on the receipt of his MajeÅ¿ty Letters they fell on the ProteÅ¿tants at Meaux, Troys, Orleans, and other
parts, murthering them without all pitty.

And now let us a little read with melting hearts the Å¿ad affliction of Gods Church, let us bring the Å¿ad ruins of a good cauÅ¿e to our neer view, by a Å¿piritual improvement, as a proÅ¿pect draws the object nearer; for we muÅ¿t now relate the Å¿ad cataÅ¿trophe of many thouÅ¿ands of poor ChriÅ¿tians, who fell under the cruel and bloody command of the King to all his MagiÅ¿trates, which indeed is not to be expreÅ¿Å¿ed, what Å¿ad cruelties were committed to the wonderful aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment of all that hears or reads it; for no Å¿ooner does the King let looÅ¿e his cruel commands, but Å¿peedily the bloody PapiÅ¿ts break out with horrid MaÅ¿Å¿acres, more like Devils than men.

For now in Paris the PriÅ¿ons that had any ProteÅ¿tants (by which reaÅ¿on they eÅ¿caped for a time) were now brought forth, and baÅ¿ely Å¿lain by the multitude of murtherers, in which were three gallant Gentlemen of great reputation, viz. Captain Monius, a very valourous and Å¿tout Gentleman; next Lomen, Secretary to the King, and greatly honored and eÅ¿teemed for his faithful Å¿ervice in his place; and laÅ¿tly Chappes, an antient Lawyer of fourÅ¿core years. And was alÅ¿o of great renown and fame in the Court of Paris, all three were baÅ¿ely murthered as cannot be expreÅ¿Å¿ed.

AmongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t muÅ¿t be Å¿et forth that unparallel'd bloody and treacherous death of MonÅ¿ieur de la Place, PreÅ¿ident of the Court of Wards; which muÅ¿t I Å¿ay for the Å¿trangneÅ¿s of the murther begg leave to have place in this hiÅ¿tory.

Their comes a Captain armed to the Gentlemans
houÅ¿e and acquaints him that the D. of GuiÅ¿e had Å¿lain the Admiral by the Kings commandment, and alÅ¿o many other ProteÅ¿tants, but out of his deÅ¿erts, he deÅ¿ired to protect him from their fury; with all deÅ¿iring to Å¿ee his Gold, which he might as well beÅ¿tow on him for Å¿aving him, as on others for deÅ¿troying him; the Lord de la Place admires at the Captains audatious and petulant demeanour, and Å¿o confidently required of him whether he thought there were a King or no; the Captain blaÅ¿pheming deÅ¿ired him to go to the K. to know his pleaÅ¿ure, the Lord De la Place thinking danger too near, abÅ¿ented from him to a place of better Å¿ecutity; the Captain hereupon plunders his houÅ¿e, This poor Gentleman, Å¿eeking Å¿helter in three houÅ¿es for his life, was refuÅ¿ed, and Å¿o at laÅ¿t was forced to return to his own houÅ¿e again, where finding his wife very penÅ¿ive and Å¿ad, he rebuked, and exhorted her not to be Å¿o full of diÅ¿pondency of Å¿pirit, for death was the utmoÅ¿t, and heaven the crown of their afflictions and Å¿ufferings; and Å¿o Å¿poke fully and Å¿weetly of the promiÅ¿es of God; which jointly knit their hearts together in comfort, and Å¿o calling together his Family he Å¿weetly exhorted them, expounding out of a chapter to them; then went again to prayer, and Å¿o reÅ¿olved with the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of ChriÅ¿t to Å¿uffer all Torments of death, rather than diÅ¿honour God in the leaÅ¿t drawing back, preÅ¿ently after comes the ProvoÅ¿t MarÅ¿hal to his houÅ¿e with many Archers. with a pretence to Å¿ecure him, and conduct him to the King; who anÅ¿wered, that he freely deÅ¿ired to continue his obedience to the King, but could not Å¿ee how to
eÅ¿cape the fury of the preÅ¿ent danger by continual maÅ¿Å¿acres.

PreÅ¿ently after comes the ProvoÅ¿t des Marchands, with order to bring him to the King, but he excuÅ¿ed it as before, but he would not have any delay or excuÅ¿e, Å¿o that this Noble Lord reÅ¿olves to meet death by a ChriÅ¿tian preparation; and Å¿o embracing his wife, he deÅ¿ires her never to forÅ¿ake the true faith, but to continue Å¿teadfaÅ¿t in the fear of God; and Å¿o willingly and ChriÅ¿tianly advanced, like a true martyr of ChriÅ¿t; and indeed it fell out Å¿o as this Godly Å¿oul expected, for in the way the murtherers waited with open mouth and bloody hearts, with their daggers, that he did no Å¿ooner approach but they Å¿tabbed him, that he fell down dead; they pillaged him, caÅ¿t his body into a Stable, covering his face over with dung, and Å¿o the next day threw his body into the River.
And thus died this bleÅ¿Å¿ed Servant of ChriÅ¿t in the heigth of their cruelty, and his Spirit full of ChriÅ¿tian magnanimity.

AmongÅ¿t theÅ¿e many murthers in Paris was Peter Ramus Å¿lain; a man famous for learning, being the Kings ProfeÅ¿Å¿our in Logick, the bloody Murtherers breaking into the College of PrieÅ¿ts, they baÅ¿ely maÅ¿Å¿acred him, then caÅ¿t him out of the chamber window, that his bowels with the fall, iÅ¿Å¿ued out on the ground, to a Å¿ad view of all tender hearted Spectators, then was his body dragged through the Å¿treets, and by certain yong Schollars whipped, being commanded to do it by their PopiÅ¿h Tutors.

On the Lords day a Godly young man walking abroad in the morning, and hearing that
the Admiral and the reÅ¿t were deÅ¿troyed, and Å¿eeing little hopes of life, he preÅ¿ently returned home, and with a Son-like care to his loving Mother, told her of the danger, and Å¿o Å¿peedily Å¿ecured her in a place of great Å¿ecrecie, and Å¿o Å¿hut himÅ¿elf up in his Å¿tudy, and powring out his Soul before the Lord in prayer, and preparation for Å¿trength to Å¿uffer for his name; preÅ¿ently the Murtherers aÅ¿cend, and with Battleaxes, and other bloody InÅ¿truments, brake into his Å¿tudy, and Å¿o knockt him down, this poor Soul receiving the blood in his own hands, his body they threw into the River.
Thus dyed this young man and old ChriÅ¿tian, and may Å¿tand as a pattern for our Imitation.

Two MiniÅ¿ters belonging to the King of Navar were alÅ¿o murthered, and thrown into the River; but all the reÅ¿t of the MiniÅ¿ters of Gods word, were by a Å¿ingular and Å¿pecial hand of Gods Providence preÅ¿erved and kept from the rage of theÅ¿e bloody Tygars.

There was in this City a Gentleman, whom the Murtherers found a bed with his Wife, who was then nigh her time of delivery, they no Å¿ooner knock, but poor Gentlewoman Å¿he opens the door to theÅ¿e bloud-hounds, they preÅ¿ently Å¿tab her husband in his bed; now the Midwife Å¿eeing them bent on blood, earneÅ¿tly intreated them to Å¿pare her, at leaÅ¿t till the Child was born, this being the twentieth child that God had given her, but their bloody minds admitted of no mercy, but preÅ¿ently truÅ¿t a dagger up to the Hilt into her fundament, this poor Å¿oul feeling her Å¿elf mortally wounded, fled into a Corn loft to Å¿ee if God would
pleaÅ¿e to bring the fruit of her womb to a birth, but theÅ¿e villains perÅ¿ued her and Å¿tabbed her in the belly, whereof Å¿he preÅ¿ently dyed, then they threw her body out of the window into the Streets, which fall forced the child out of her body, with the head formoÅ¿t, gaping and yawning for life, in a Å¿ad, doleful and lamentable manner, and Å¿o it died.

One of theÅ¿e villains Å¿natching up a Little child in his arms, the child began to play with his beard, but inÅ¿tead of compaÅ¿Å¿ion this baÅ¿e murtherer had Å¿uch a flinty heart, that he wounded it with his dagger, and Å¿o caÅ¿t it in a goar blood into the River.

But this bloody MaÅ¿Å¿acre at Lyons cannot be paralleled by any age, the bare narrative will cloy and Reader at firÅ¿t view; Oxen and Å¿heep could not be deÅ¿troyed with leÅ¿s pitty and more cruelty, than thoÅ¿e poor ProteÅ¿tants of all Å¿exes and degrees, from the Cradle to the Bedrid: Indeed its the moÅ¿t aÅ¿toniÅ¿hing and horrible murther that ever ChriÅ¿tian heard or read of. For

No Å¿ooner arrived the Kings commandment to Mandelot Governour of Lyons, certifying of the MaÅ¿Å¿acre at Paris, and commanding to deÅ¿troy all the ProteÅ¿tants, but Mandelot ordered the Gates of the City to be Å¿hut, declaring it to be death for any ProteÅ¿tant to come out of his houÅ¿e, and then by a cryer, and afterwards by Å¿ound of Trumpet he proclaimed that all the ProteÅ¿tants Å¿hould Å¿peedily repair before him, they quickly obey and come, he then Å¿ends them to PriÅ¿on, they poor Å¿ouls Å¿ubmit, and Å¿o followed the officers that was appointed to lead them, but by reaÅ¿on of the great
multitude of them, they are diÅ¿perÅ¿ed into Å¿everal priÅ¿ons; Mandelot, the bloody Governour, Commanded the common Executioner to take aid to him, and deÅ¿troy them all; but he, having his conÅ¿cience Å¿mit with pitty, replyed, He was an Executioner of the Law, but not to put to death without law; he put to death all Å¿uch as the world was witneÅ¿s to their publick condemnation, and Å¿o deÅ¿ired Mandelot to Å¿eek Å¿ome that might better diÅ¿pence with a bloody conÅ¿cience.

This cruel Governour having his deÅ¿ire fruÅ¿trate by an honeÅ¿t refuÅ¿al, commands the Souldiers that were garriÅ¿oned in the CaÅ¿tle to murther them; they reply it conÅ¿iÅ¿ted not with their honour to deÅ¿troy men in cold blood, and too cowardly to cut the throats of thoÅ¿e that had not wherewith to defend, being a thing too far off from valour, or the part of a true Souldier to deÅ¿troy men at mercy, lying Å¿upplyant before them, nor Å¿aw they any cauÅ¿e why death Å¿hould be inflicted upon poor innocent Å¿ouls.

Dear Lord, what ProteÅ¿tant heart can contain to read this Å¿ad and lamentable murther without thought of revenge, who has a Å¿park of ChriÅ¿tianity that can read, and not wiÅ¿h himÅ¿elf able to revenge their cauÅ¿e, only God is the Avenger of the cauÅ¿e of the innocent, and doubtleÅ¿s God has a Scourge for this Nation.

The Governour being refuÅ¿ed by a conÅ¿cientious Hangman, and honourable Souldiers, more fit for Alexander and CaeÅ¿ar than this bloody and cruel Tyrant; he I Å¿ay rather than let the command of a King ly dead, gathers together the Å¿cum of wicked men, and Å¿pawn
of the Devil, the legitimate of-Å¿pring of a HelliÅ¿h brood, the Watermen, and bloody Butchers, who being let into priÅ¿on with their bloody Knives and inÅ¿truments, (oh unmerciful wretches!) Å¿uch as they find proÅ¿trate at their feet, holding forth their petitions in their Å¿ad requeÅ¿ts in a bleating Oratory, crying to Gods mercy and mans pitty.

TheÅ¿e Butchers of innocent Å¿ouls, inÅ¿tead of pitty, for Å¿port cut of their fingers, and tops of their noÅ¿es, and then fell a murthering; throughout the City was Å¿uch doleful noiÅ¿e of the dying, and lamentable howling of women and children, that all thoÅ¿e that were zealous in the RomiÅ¿h Religion, abhorred their cruelties, and had their hearts Å¿o peirced with the Å¿ad groans of the dying, that they thought they were devils that onely had human Å¿hape, or that they were Indian Tygars, or wild beaÅ¿ts only had aÅ¿Å¿umed the Å¿hape of men; nay many women of the PopiÅ¿h Religion that were with child, and now nigh their time of Delivery, were Å¿o affrighted with theÅ¿e Å¿ad cruelties, that they parted with child; The murthers and maÅ¿Å¿acre was Å¿o great that out of one of the priÅ¿ons called the Arch-biÅ¿hops houÅ¿e, the blood of the Å¿lain was Å¿een running down the Å¿treets in the day time, in great abundance to the aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment and horrour of all the Beholders, for it run warm and Å¿moaking hot through the Å¿treets and Å¿o into the River.

AmongÅ¿t them that were butchered in this PriÅ¿on, was an antient man, named Francis de BoÅ¿Å¿u, a Merchant that had to his Sons two Religious young-men, whom he had carefully trained up in the fear of the Lord: As Å¿oon
as the Murtherers approached with their Axes, he exhorted his Sons, Not to fear death, for it was but a quick paÅ¿Å¿age to their Fathers houÅ¿e, for that through many tribulations we muÅ¿t enter into the Kingdome of God; for it has alwaies been, and will be to the end of the World, the lot of all Gods people to be as Å¿heep among wolves; if we Å¿uffer with ChriÅ¿t we Å¿hall alÅ¿o reign with him, this Å¿hort cut of ours will be, but as a Bridge for our more Å¿peedy paÅ¿Å¿age to eternal life; let us joyfully follow this company that is gone before us; and Å¿o the old ChriÅ¿tian and aged Father imbraced his two young Sons, and they him, with mutual embraces, and held Å¿o faÅ¿t together, that with the Murtherers blows they fell all flat to the ground together, crying to the mercy of God, and thus with many wounds was the godly Soul, and his two Sons cruelly murthered, by theÅ¿e bloody Butchers, and which is not to be forgotten, TheÅ¿e three bodies along time after were wonderfully knit together, which afforded a Å¿ad Å¿ight to the Spectators.

After all theÅ¿e cruelties were done, Mandelot the Governonr commanded to be proclamed, that no man Å¿hould commit any more murthers, and that if any one would diÅ¿cover any of the actors of Å¿uch horrid villainyes, they Å¿hould be rewarded with a hundred Crowns for their information; but alas, this was in a baÅ¿e, Å¿cornful and diÅ¿dainful way, for from that time they ceaÅ¿ed not to kill and murder all they knew had eÅ¿caped the common deÅ¿tiny, and on Sabbath day morning thoÅ¿e poor ProteÅ¿tants that had eÅ¿caped their fury, was now by order of this baÅ¿e and bloody Mandelot, deÅ¿troied and hewen in pieces.

TheÅ¿e bloody Villains paÅ¿Å¿ing through the Streets with their bloody InÅ¿truments, boaÅ¿ted that they had died their white Doublets with the blood of the ProteÅ¿tants, one bragging that he had killed an hundred, Å¿ome more, Å¿ome leÅ¿s: On the firÅ¿t of September their dead bodies were ordered to be thrown into the River, but a great part of them Mandelot ordered to be boated over to the other Å¿ide of the River, and laid on a green bank, neer to an Abby named EÅ¿ne; and there the people came and abuÅ¿ed their bodies: and one thing (for the like was never heard of) is not here to be omitted; The Apothecaries viewing the bodies Å¿aid, they uÅ¿ed to make medicines of mens greaÅ¿e; and being there were many fat bodies, there might be monies got, and Å¿o wiÅ¿hed the Butchers to procure them their greaÅ¿e, and they Å¿hould be rewarded, the bloody fellows Å¿peedily chooÅ¿e out the fatteÅ¿t, launched them with their bloody Knives, and Å¿old their fat for three Å¿hillings a pound. So at laÅ¿t their bodies were Å¿ome thrown into a great pit, the reÅ¿t into the River.

The people inhabiting on the borders of the River, admired to Å¿ee Å¿o many dead carcaÅ¿Å¿es come down, having their bodies baÅ¿ely mangled, Å¿ome with eyes out, others their noÅ¿es, hands and ears cut off, and Å¿tabb'd in every part of their bodies.

Not long after the Popes Legat arrived at Lyons, who coming out of the great Church from MaÅ¿s, the bloody Murtherers of Å¿o many innocent ChriÅ¿tians kneel down before him for abÅ¿olution, and as Å¿oon as the Legat was told who they were, and for what they kneeled
down, he made the Å¿ign of the croÅ¿s, and abÅ¿olved them of their Å¿ins whether they repented or no, and doubtleÅ¿s theÅ¿e bloody Devils were canonized at Rome for Saints.

The Kings Letters and commands coming to CoÅ¿Å¿et the Kings Atturney at Meaux; he forthwith ordered thoÅ¿e of his bloody crew to come to him, who accordingly at Å¿even a clock at night came, and received Orders to Å¿hut up the City Gates; at which time alÅ¿o they went through the Town doing nothing all that night but murther, kill and diÅ¿troy the poor ProteteÅ¿tants; in the morning they apprehended two hundred, and committed them to priÅ¿ons; CoÅ¿Å¿et comes to them, and having a Catalogue of their names, he calls them out one by one, and baÅ¿ely murthers as many as they could, being aweary they went to Å¿upper, and after a little refreÅ¿hment they returned again, and now they brought quicker InÅ¿truments of death, being Axes, and Å¿o fell again to call them out by their names, and butchered them moÅ¿t cruelly, amongÅ¿t whom was a godly Elder of a Church, who praying for his Enemies, they reviled him, and having on a buff Coat, they fearing it Å¿hould be Å¿poiled with blood, did open it before and Å¿tabb'd him in the breaÅ¿t, whereof he died. AmongÅ¿t theÅ¿e alÅ¿o thus Å¿lain was an antient Gentleman Sheriff of the City, whom they cruelly handled, for firÅ¿t they cut off his noÅ¿e, and privy members, then thruÅ¿t him often into the body, toÅ¿Å¿ing him up and down, that at laÅ¿t he fell down dead, crying out to God for mercy.

As Å¿oon as the Å¿peedy poÅ¿t with the Kings Letters came to Troyes, the poor ProteÅ¿tants
were quickly impriÅ¿oned, the Bayliff Summons the Keeper of the PriÅ¿on, who being Å¿ick Å¿ent one Martin to know his pleaÅ¿ure, the Bayliff told him all their PriÅ¿oners muÅ¿t be Å¿lain; and Å¿o commanded a pit to be digged in the PriÅ¿on that the blood might not run down the Streets, now the Jaylor and his bloody aÅ¿Å¿ociates going to murther theÅ¿e poor innocent Å¿ouls, no Å¿ooner Å¿aw them, but their conÅ¿ciences gave back, Å¿tanding amazed at the horridneÅ¿s of their task, and Å¿o return, but the Bayliff got them, and filled them Å¿o full of wine and Å¿trong drink, that without any fear or danger they came again, and called them forth by their names, he that came out firÅ¿t had a chearful countenance, and calling on the name of the Lord he opened his BreaÅ¿t and was killed preÅ¿ently; the next that came, being Å¿everal times wounded with a Halberd, and not killed, did at laÅ¿t cheerfully take the Halberd by the point, and put it to his breaÅ¿t, Å¿aying, Here bloody Murtherer, here, right at the heart, right at the heart, and Å¿o was thruÅ¿t through and died. All the reÅ¿t were cruelly murthered, and caÅ¿t into a great pit on the back of the PriÅ¿on; and although Å¿ome were not quite dead, yet they caÅ¿t them in, one of theÅ¿e poor Souls having more life than the reÅ¿t, roÅ¿e up in the pit above his Fellows, but was preÅ¿ently Å¿mothered with Earth, and although there was a pit digged in the PriÅ¿on to Å¿ave the blood, yet Å¿uch was the effuÅ¿ion of ChriÅ¿tian blood, that it run out of priÅ¿on Å¿treaming down the Gutters of the Å¿treets, to the amazement of the PopiÅ¿h Inhabitants.

But now at Orleance, the place of the laÅ¿t Treaty of peace, and the place where it was
Å¿olemnly proclaimed with full command for ObÅ¿ervation of the Edict. At this place, I Å¿ay, the Kings Letters came, commanding to murther all, and happened to come the Å¿ame day that three hundred were met together at a Sermon, whereupon the Maior and Officers commanded the Companies in arms to fall on, and to execute Å¿peedily the Kings command, oh Tyrant, and bloody command! One of the Murtherers went to a noble mans houÅ¿e inviting himÅ¿elf, and his bloody followers to Supper, where they were made welcome with good chear, no Å¿ooner was Supper ended, but they blaÅ¿pheming murthered him, and all his family, and then plundered his houÅ¿e.

There were many that lived on the outÅ¿ide of the Town, amongÅ¿t whom was heard Å¿uch Å¿ad murtherings, and cruelties, that all night long was heard nothing but howlings and cryings of men, women and children maÅ¿Å¿acred, Å¿hooting off of Guns, and PiÅ¿tols, breaking doors, and rumbling of Carts that conveyed away the dead bodies, all which were mixed with the cryes of the bloody Murtherers, crying Kill, Kill them all, and then take the Spoil; and thus they continued all the week in theÅ¿e Å¿ad and bloody murthers, and plundering, blaÅ¿phemouÅ¿ly Å¿inging in Å¿corn, where is now their God.

On TueÅ¿day they came to a Doctor of the Civil Law, who being found in earneÅ¿t prayer to God, they had not the power to kill him, only took a little plunder with them, next day they came again, and views his Library, what books they demanded he gave them, they told him he muÅ¿t be killed, he therefore goes to prayer
again, and afterwards deÅ¿ired of them that if he muÅ¿t dy to murther him there, which they refuÅ¿ed, they take him and lead him through the Streets, and coming to the Schools he deÅ¿ired them to kill him where he taught Å¿o many; but they led him a little further, and Å¿o knocked him on the head. One that was forced by hunger out of a Å¿ecret place where he hid himÅ¿elf, was preÅ¿ently Å¿lain. Such as for fear revolted, they forced to kill their friends or were killed themÅ¿elves.

As Å¿oon as the Kings bloody MeÅ¿Å¿age came to the City of TholouÅ¿e, the Gates were preÅ¿ently Å¿hut, but it pleaÅ¿ed the Lord of his good grace and Providence Å¿o to order it, that the ProteÅ¿tants were gone that morning out of the Ciry to a Sermon, and as Å¿oon as the noiÅ¿e of the MaÅ¿Å¿acre came to their ears, many returned not again to the City! But others would venture Å¿o far as to go to order their affairs for a Return, but poor Å¿ouls they never returned back, for as Å¿oon as they came to the Gates they were Å¿uffered to enter, leaving their Å¿words at the Gates, amongÅ¿t whom was many of great account, and on wedneÅ¿day morning all the poor ProteÅ¿tants were impriÅ¿oned, with command that none Å¿hould on pain of death hide any of them.

AmongÅ¿t theÅ¿e were Å¿ix CounÅ¿ellers; which like good ChriÅ¿tians encouraged the reÅ¿t: at laÅ¿t they were all brought into one place, and Å¿o the bloody Murtherers being ready with axes and knives they were one by one deÅ¿troyed, their bodies Å¿tripped naked, and lay for two daies; The Å¿ix CounÅ¿ellours being hung up in their long Gowns upon Elm Trees in the Palace
yard; which would move any one to compaÅ¿Å¿ion there being in this City three hundred thus murthered.

In Roan as Å¿oon as the Kings command came, there was an infinite number Å¿lain in few daies, Å¿ix thouÅ¿and men beÅ¿ides women, whom they uÅ¿ed as cruelly as can be imagined, their bodies were Å¿tript and caried out in carts, being put into the pits in great heaps.

At Bourdeaux, as Å¿oon as the news of the MaÅ¿Å¿acre at Paris arrived, and command from the King to follow their Example. The ProteÅ¿tants were boating over the River to a Sermon, but orders followed them that they Å¿hould be apprehended, whereupon the Gates of the City were Å¿hut, yet the MiniÅ¿ters through Gods good mercy and grace eÅ¿caped, and Å¿afely landed in England. The Governour was Å¿omewhat timerous to act the Kings command in Å¿uch a bloody Å¿ubjection to cruelty, but the Lord MonpeÅ¿Å¿at aÅ¿Å¿ured him, how acceptable it would be to his MajeÅ¿ty, and for their better encouragement he enters the houÅ¿e of the Lord of Obiers, and baÅ¿ely murthered him in his own Court.

And then preÅ¿ently the froath and Scum of the Town, aÅ¿Å¿embled and murthered all the reÅ¿t, amongÅ¿t whom was a MiniÅ¿ter that came out of the adjacent Countrey, AlÅ¿o there was a reverend old Deacon of a church whom they dragged out of his Å¿ick bed through the Streets, and Å¿o baÅ¿ely and inhumanly murthered.

As Å¿oon as the bloody MeÅ¿Å¿age of the Kings cruell command arrives at Angiers, they fell on all the ProteÅ¿tants without mercy or pitty,
to Å¿ex or age, for no Å¿ooner were the MaÅ¿Å¿acres begun at Paris, but one MonÅ¿orel a bloody and cruel PapiÅ¿t, poÅ¿ted and Å¿oon arrived with orders from the K. to deÅ¿troy all; he no Å¿ooner arrives but deÅ¿ires a Å¿peedy conduct to one MaÅ¿Å¿on de Rivers, who was a Godly and zealous PaÅ¿tor of a Church; a very able and elaborate DiÅ¿Å¿penÅ¿er of the MyÅ¿teries of the GoÅ¿pel; and one excelling in wiÅ¿dom, knowledge and learning; He it was that laid the foundation Å¿tone of the firÅ¿t Church of ChriÅ¿t in Paris: This bloody MonÅ¿orel meets Mr. MaÅ¿Å¿on's wife at the Door, and kindly Å¿aluted her, demanding where her Husband was, Å¿he anÅ¿wered in the Garden, whither Å¿he conducted him, who as Å¿oon as he commeth to him, embraces him kindly, Å¿aying doeÅ¿t thou know my meÅ¿Å¿age, and the buÅ¿meÅ¿s I come to thee about, it is (Å¿aid this villain) to kill thee preÅ¿ently, for the King commands it; and Å¿o preÅ¿ents a PiÅ¿tol to his BreaÅ¿t, MaÅ¿ter MaÅ¿Å¿on replyed, I know not wherein I have given his MajeÅ¿ty Å¿uch cauÅ¿e; but one thing Sir I humbly beg at your hands, to give me Å¿o much Å¿pace as to commend my Å¿oul to God by prayer; which as Å¿oon as he had ended, this cruel and mercileÅ¿s Tyger piÅ¿toled him.
And Å¿o this faithful Servant of ChriÅ¿t fell dead at his feet.

Not long after, arrives another bloody Harbinger from Paris by the Kings Order, who drowned many, amongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t, was the virtuous wife of this Godly MiniÅ¿ter of ChriÅ¿t Mr. MaÅ¿Å¿on: a ChriÅ¿tian getting into an obÅ¿cure place of a Rock, the entrance being narrow, was, after he got in, covered with a
Spiders web; the bloudy PerÅ¿ecutors paÅ¿Å¿ing by, Å¿ome of them Å¿aid it was a fit place for an eÅ¿cape from danger, others Å¿aid, can any be here and this Spiders web whole, whereupon they departed, which may very well be remarkably obÅ¿erved as a Å¿pecial Providence of God.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.head: The Contents.
argument.p:
THe King prolaims pardon to all thoÅ¿e that had eÅ¿caped in Woods, and Rocks, who no Å¿ooner comes home, but treacherouÅ¿ly deÅ¿troys them all, in a moÅ¿t cruel manner. For thirty days nothing but killing of poor innocent Protestants. The Copy of the Kings letters, laying the fault of the Admirals death and the murthers on the D. of GuiÅ¿e; yet the Å¿ame day Å¿ends Letters to command it to be done, and cauÅ¿ed all the murthers to be done by his comand, both in Paris, and all over France. The King in Parliament opens his deÅ¿ign, and acknowledges all to be done by his own command. The Kings Speech in Parliament. The true Copy of the K. Declaration, printed at Paris. The PreÅ¿ident of Parlament congratulates the King for his bloody Å¿ucceÅ¿s. The
Advocate adviÅ¿es the King to ceaÅ¿e the murthers, and to colour his crueltits with the name of JuÅ¿tice. A Parliament is called, and Proclamation is made that all murthers Å¿hould ceaÅ¿e. Many gÃ²es to view the body of the Admiral hanging on the common Gallowes. The King and Queen Mother goes alÅ¿o; but his body over night was Å¿ecretly taken away and buried: Å¿o they loÅ¿t their journey. Judges pickt out to condemn the innocent with the pretence of JuÅ¿tice. The Admiral diÅ¿honoured by a man of Å¿traw, and Libels printed. The King Å¿ends to Å¿urprize the Admiralls wife, but Å¿he was fled to Geneva. The Admiral a little deÅ¿cribed. Brave Caviagnes and Briquemault tortured to confeÅ¿s themÅ¿elvs and the Admiral Traytors, they Å¿hew much ChriÅ¿tianity, the Judges refuÅ¿e to Å¿it in judgement againÅ¿t them, new Iudges are choÅ¿en, they are condemned and led to the Gallows, their Speech, they are hanged in Å¿ight of King, Q. Mother, Prince and Nobles with many thouÅ¿and Spectators. The Man of Straw for the Admiral, hanged with them. Some Letters collected
according to the Original, which gives much light to the HiÅ¿tory, and diÅ¿covers how Queen Elizabeth of England reÅ¿ented the Murther, with the General pitty and DiÅ¿like of the whole English Court. TheÅ¿e cruelties Å¿potted the French Nation with a great Odium among Forein Princes. The Duke of GuiÅ¿e his Letter to his Wife intercepted, and the Plot diÅ¿covered. The King notwithstanding his former Edicts granted, and Oaths to keep his PromiÅ¿es, does now proclaim, that none Å¿hould exerciÅ¿e any Religion on pain of Death, but the RomiÅ¿h. A form of Abjuration Å¿ent to thoÅ¿e that would come in, and forÅ¿ake the ProteÅ¿tant Religion; and when they did, they were murthered contrary to the Kings proclamation: A true Copy of the Remembrances of the King to all his Lieutenants, and Governours of his Provinces, with a Copy alÅ¿o for Abjuration.

div.p:
NOw when all was murthered that could very well be laid hands on, and the King underÅ¿tanding that divers ProteÅ¿tants, had in many parts of the Kingdom fled, and left their Habitations for Å¿ecurity of their Lives; He
acts the Å¿econd and worÅ¿t part of his DeviliÅ¿h Treachery and cruelty; for after many Å¿weet baits of inticing and alluring promiÅ¿es for them to come in, he at laÅ¿t publiÅ¿hed Letters, and Å¿ent MeÅ¿Å¿engers;

Wherein he Å¿hewed, The great grief it was to him that Å¿o much blood Å¿hould be Å¿pilt in the Nation, contrary to his will, promiÅ¿ing to puniÅ¿h the Actors of Å¿uch horrid villainies, with as much crueltie as JuÅ¿tice could inflict, and they deÅ¿erve. And that if the Admiral, and his AÅ¿Å¿ociates. deÅ¿erved the death inflicted for their treaÅ¿onable practices, yet was it no reaÅ¿on Å¿o many innocents Å¿hould bear part of this puniÅ¿hment, that had no hand in the Plot.

Now many poor ProteÅ¿tants that had left all, and fled into the woods, being encouraged by theÅ¿e inticing and fair pretexts, returned home, eÅ¿pecially they that had fled from Diep, Roan, and TholouÅ¿e; now we Å¿hall Å¿ee the King like a Thorny BuÅ¿h to the poor Å¿heep, that in a Å¿torm they run to Å¿helter, and inÅ¿tead thereof are intangled, and their wool pull'd off their backs. But oh wretched Tyrant, and worÅ¿e King! whoÅ¿e furious and bloody mind, like an impetuous Whirlewind, or Hiricane, could not be kept in bounds, but ere two daies paÅ¿t he impriÅ¿ons them all, and appoints baÅ¿e fellowes to murther them, with cruel Torments.

And thus for thirty daies together was nothing but horrible Å¿laughter throughout the Kingdom of France; inÅ¿omuch that there were about a hundred thouÅ¿and little Babes, Widdowes and children wel-born that fatherleÅ¿s
and MotherleÅ¿s, lived long in wandering, and beggary.
And truly that reverend and faithful Servant of ChriÅ¿t, did not miÅ¿s the Mark of the Kings treachery and perfidious dealing, when he made this Anagram on his name;

q.p: CHARLES VALOIS, Anagram, ChaÅ¿Å¿eur deÅ¿loyall, i. e. Perfidious Hunter or PerÅ¿ecutor.

div.p: In this calamity many that would have Å¿aved their lives among their own friends, could not have the favour, nay their own parents refuÅ¿ed them, others betrayed by their friends, and yet it pleaÅ¿ed God to move the hearts of Å¿ome of their Enemies, by their high deteÅ¿ting theÅ¿e cruelties, and villainies, inÅ¿omuch as they hazarded their own lives to Å¿ave Å¿ome of the ProteÅ¿tants.

Was ever Å¿uch unheard of cruelties permitted and commanded by any ChriÅ¿tian King, and Court with Å¿uch delight of Å¿hedding ProteÅ¿tant blood; We may Å¿ay of the French nation (as the caÅ¿e here Å¿tood) as the poor. Indian Å¿aid of the Spaniards.
The Å¿tory Å¿tands recorded thus.

A Prince of the Indians being Å¿o far wrought upon as to receive baptiÅ¿m at the hands of a Fryer, he firÅ¿t queÅ¿tioned, whether the Å¿ouls of Å¿uch as were baptized went? AnÅ¿wer was returned, To Heaven; then Å¿aies he, whether muÅ¿t they go too that are not baptized; They anÅ¿wer, To Hell; but he further demanded,
To which of theÅ¿e two places the Spaniards went? AnÅ¿wer is returned, To heaven, then Å¿aid the Indian, Let me go to Hell if the Spaniards go to Heaven; for I cannot believe heaven to be a good place, that is a reward for Å¿uch bloody Butchers; and MaÅ¿ters of Å¿uch unheard of cruelties. May we not Å¿ay Å¿o of this Å¿ad MaÅ¿Å¿acre of France? but I leave the application to the judicial reader.

The King now fearing the DiÅ¿honour of falÅ¿ehood, treachery, and perjury, and that it might not fix any reproachful blot, or Å¿tain on the Kings name; This King at the Å¿ame time that he Å¿ends Letters through France, giving in command to cut off and deÅ¿troy the ProteÅ¿tants, the Å¿ame King with the Å¿ame hand, and at the Å¿ame time, Å¿ends Letters to the Governours of his Provinces; wherein he lets the world know that the late miÅ¿chief in Paris, had to his great Å¿orrow hapned by means of the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, who having raiÅ¿ed the people, they tumultuouÅ¿ly broke through the Guard, which he had appointed for the Admirals Å¿afety, and with great Fury killed the Admiral and his Friends, and that he with the Queen Mother and Brethren, were through the danger of a furious multitude, forced to retreat for Å¿afety to the Lour, all which he Å¿aid was againÅ¿t his mind and will, and therefore he deÅ¿ired the Edict of Pacification to be kept inviolable.
The like Letters he writ to England, Switzerland and Germany; which becauÅ¿e they bear one tenure, and pen'd after one manner, I have to avoid prolixity, incerted only this following Letter.

body.head: The true Copy of the Kings letter to the Governour of Burgundy.
body.p:
YOu have perceived what I wrote unto you YeÅ¿terday, concerning my CouÅ¿in the Admirals wounding, and how ready I was to do my endeavour to Å¿earch out the truth of the deed, and to puniÅ¿h it, wherein nothing was left undone or forgottou. But it hapned Å¿ince, that they of the houÅ¿e of GuiÅ¿e, and other Lords and Gentlemen their Adherents, (whereof there be no Å¿mall number in this City) when they certainly knew, that the Admirals friends would proceed to the revenge of his hurt, and becauÅ¿e they were Å¿uÅ¿pected to be the Authors thereof, were Å¿o Å¿tirred up this laÅ¿t night, that a great and lamentable Å¿edition aroÅ¿e thereof, inÅ¿omuch that the Guard by me appointed for his defence about his HouÅ¿e, was Å¿et upon, and he himÅ¿elf with certain of his Gentlemen Å¿lain, and havock of others made in divers places of the City, which was handled with Å¿uch rage, that I could not uÅ¿e the remedy I would, but had much ado to employ my Guards, and other Defence, for the Å¿afety of my Å¿elf, and my brethren in the CaÅ¿tle of the Loure, to give order hereafter for the appeaÅ¿ing of this Sedition, which is at this hour well appeaÅ¿ed, thanks be to God, and came to paÅ¿s by a particular and private quarrel of long time foÅ¿tering betwixt theÅ¿e two houÅ¿es.
Whereof when I foreÅ¿aw that there would Å¿ucceed; Å¿ome miÅ¿chievous purpoÅ¿e, I did what I could poÅ¿Å¿ibly to appeaÅ¿e it, as all men know, and yet hereby the Edict of Pacification is not broken, which I will to be kept as Å¿traitly as ever it was, as I have given to underÅ¿tand in all places throughout my Realm, and becauÅ¿e it is greatly to be feared that Å¿uch an execution might Å¿tirr up my Subjects, one againÅ¿t another, and cauÅ¿e great murthers through the Cities of my Realm, whereby I Å¿hould be greatly grieved, I pray you cauÅ¿e to be publiÅ¿hed and underÅ¿tood in all places of your Government that every perÅ¿on abide and continue in the Å¿afeguard of his own houÅ¿e, and to take no weapons in hand, nor one to hurt another upon pain of death; commanding them to keep and diligently to obÅ¿erve our Edict of Pacification, and to make the Offenders and ReÅ¿iÅ¿ters, and Å¿uch as would diÅ¿obey and break our will, to be puniÅ¿hed. You Å¿hall aÅ¿Å¿emble out of hand as great force as you can, as well of your friends as of them that be appointed by me and others, advertiÅ¿ing the Captains of CaÅ¿tles and Cities in your Government, to take heed to the Å¿afeguard and preÅ¿ervation of the Å¿aid places, Å¿o that no fault enÅ¿ue on their behalf, advertiÅ¿ing me alÅ¿o as Å¿oon as you can, what order you have given herein, and how all things have paÅ¿Å¿ed within the circuit of your Government. Hereupon I pray God to keep you, CouÅ¿in, in his Holy Å¿afe-guard.
body.closer:
At Paris
AuguÅ¿t 24.
Å¿igned Charles, and underneath BRULAND.

div.p:
Now at the Å¿ame time, were Orders given
out by the King, for all Towns and Provinces within his Power, to follow the example of Paris, and to murther and put to death all of the Religion, and the very next month he wholly aboliÅ¿hes that famous Edict, giving command to root out all the ProteÅ¿tants both from EÅ¿tates and Places, and at laÅ¿t as we Å¿hall Å¿ee, cauÅ¿es a Form of Abjuration to be made, and cauÅ¿ing it to de proclaimed, That no Religion Å¿hould be exerciÅ¿ed in the Kingdom but the RomiÅ¿h.

Now we Å¿ee by theÅ¿e Letters that the King would fain lay the blot of this foul crueltie to the antient Quarrel of the houÅ¿es of GuiÅ¿e and ChaÅ¿tillon, therefore the GuiÅ¿ans foreÅ¿eeing the foulneÅ¿s of the fact, Å¿trove as much to evade the dint of the DiÅ¿honour, as the King did, though the GuiÅ¿ans were the Plotters and chief Agents in the practical part of this cruel Tragedy; whereupon they handled the matter Å¿o, that the King was forced to acknowledge, and avow publickly this horrid act, and indeed none more fit than the King that commanded it. And truly the Å¿ad effects of theÅ¿e unheard-of cruelties, would make any one diÅ¿own it, and gladly would the King don Å¿o, for he loved the effects, and now could neither evade the diÅ¿honour, nor Gods juÅ¿t Judgements. But he is not yet ripe for them; although in theÅ¿e many maÅ¿Å¿acres he had not Å¿pared, but baÅ¿ely cauÅ¿ed to be butchered, an infinite number of gallant Noblemen, and Young Ladies, with abundance of learned men, many reverend old men, many young Gentlewomen and Virgins, many honourable Matrons of good account, women with child, and little infants at their mothers breaÅ¿ts.

Now the King being forced, to let the world know his perjury, and cruelty, he labours to Å¿et a good face on his cruel heart, Å¿o that the King that had the four and twentieth day of AuguÅ¿t, 1572. declared by Letters to all the Provinces and Å¿everal Princes abroad, that the tumult in Paris, aroÅ¿e betwixt the two parties of the GuiÅ¿an and Admiral; now but two dayes after, being the twenty Å¿ixth of the Å¿ame mouth, This moÅ¿t mighty King (and by conÅ¿ent of all nations commonly called) the moÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tian King, comes into the Parliament, with a great Train of his Brethren, and other Princes and Lords of his Court attending him, where in a full AÅ¿Å¿embly of his Council, he aÅ¿cends the Throne, and Å¿itting thereon, he directs his Speech to this great AÅ¿Å¿embly in manner following,

The Kings Speech in ParlamentThat having been informed, that the Admiral with certain of his confederates, notwithÅ¿tanding all his favors, & gratious pardons granted to their former Rebellions, yet have now plotted againÅ¿t my perÅ¿on, with my mother and Brethren, to our utter perdition, which being diÅ¿covered, I was forced to prevent my own ruin, by JuÅ¿tice to procure theirs, and by a Å¿peedy courÅ¿e, have heaped on their own heads what they would have heaped on mine. For this cauÅ¿e therefore it was, that by my command the Admiral and his Complices, are deÅ¿ervedly cut off, hoping thereby, that a period is not only put to their TreaÅ¿on againÅ¿t my Å¿elf, and Nobles, but alÅ¿o to future troubles, which would have fallen on this poor Nation, to an utter ruin thereof.

Now although at firÅ¿t, he had both by words
and Letters, laid the whole BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s on the fury of a popular tumult, headed by the faction of the GuiÅ¿ans, yet now at this time, unmasking his DeÅ¿ign, he diÅ¿covers himÅ¿elf like his actions, and now laid down his ReaÅ¿ons and grounds of this manner of proceeding againÅ¿t theÅ¿e Rebells, as he calls them; and Å¿o further declared,

That he thought it not altogether unfit to make his MagiÅ¿trates acquainted with it, That what was done at Paris in the late Slaughters, was by his own commandment, for the Å¿afety of his own life, and national tranquillity, and alÅ¿o that they might proceed with the like Å¿everity, againÅ¿t Å¿uch Traytors, and Rebells of Å¿uch a wicked ConÅ¿piracy, and that it was a Å¿udden thing, and not premeditated (a deep reach to take off the edge of Å¿uÅ¿pition) hapning in a manner, Å¿aies he, by chance, and not by any plotted contrivance.

This Speech of the Kings, was by himÅ¿elf, and the Parliament commanded to be written, and entered into the Records of Parliament, proclaimed by Heraulds, and publiÅ¿hed in print, a Book alÅ¿o was publiÅ¿hed by the Kings commandment (which becauÅ¿e it is within four daies of the Å¿ame date of that Letter, wherein he laies the blame of the Admirals death, &c. on the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, and here takes it to himÅ¿elf) therefore I Å¿ay I thought fit to inÅ¿ert that printed Book by way of Declaration, which is as followeth.

div.head: A Declaration of the King, concerning the occaÅ¿ion of the Admirals death, and his Adherents and Complices, hapned in the City of Paris, AuguÅ¿t 24. 1572.
div.p:
HIs MajeÅ¿ty deÅ¿iring to have all Seigniours, Gentlemen, and other Subjects underÅ¿tand the cauÅ¿e of the Murther of the Admiral and his Adherents and Complices, which lately happened in the City of Paris, the four and twentieth day of this preÅ¿ent month of AuguÅ¿t, leÅ¿t the Å¿aid deed Å¿hould be otherwiÅ¿e diÅ¿guiÅ¿ed and reported than it was indeed, His MajeÅ¿ty therefore declareth, that which was done was by his expreÅ¿s commandment, and for no cauÅ¿e of Religion, nor breaking his Edicts of Pacification, which he alwaies intended and Å¿till mindeth and intendeth to obÅ¿erve and keep, yea it was rather done to withÅ¿tand and prevent a moÅ¿t deteÅ¿table and curÅ¿ed conÅ¿piracy, begun by the Å¿aid Admiral, the chief Captain thereof, and his Å¿aid Adherents, and Complices, againÅ¿t the Kings perÅ¿on, his EÅ¿tate, the Q. his Mother, and the Princes his Brethren, the King of Navar, and other Lords about him, wherefore his MajeÅ¿ty by this Declaration and Ordinance, giveth to underÅ¿tand to all Gentlemen, and others of the Religion, which they pretend Reformed, that he mindeth and
purpoÅ¿eth that they live under his Protection, with their wives and children in their houÅ¿es, in as much Å¿afeguard as they did before, following the benefit of the former Edicts of Pacification, moÅ¿t expreÅ¿ly commanding and ordaining, that all Governours, and Lieutenants General, in every of his Countreys and Provinces, and other JuÅ¿tices and Officers to whom it appertaineth, do not attempt, nor Å¿uffer to be attempted, any thing in what Å¿ort Å¿oever upon the perÅ¿ons and goods of them of the Religion, their wives, children and families, on pain of death to be inflicted on thoÅ¿e that Å¿hall be found faulty, and culpable in this behalf. And nevertheleÅ¿s to withÅ¿tand the troubles, Å¿landers, Å¿uÅ¿pitions and defiances, that may come by Sermons and AÅ¿Å¿emblies, as well in the houÅ¿es of the Å¿aid Gentlemen, as in other places, as it is Å¿uffered by the Å¿aid Edicts of Pacification, it is expreÅ¿ly forbidden, and inhibited by his MajeÅ¿ty to all Gentlemen and others of the Å¿aid Religion, to have no aÅ¿Å¿emblies, for any cauÅ¿e at all till his MajeÅ¿ty hath provided and appointed otherwiÅ¿e for the Tranquillity of his Realm, upon pain of diÅ¿obedience and confiÅ¿cation of body and goods. It is alÅ¿o expreÅ¿ly forbidden under the pain aforeÅ¿aid, that for the aforeÅ¿aid accaÅ¿ions none Å¿hall take or retain any PriÅ¿oners, or take ranÅ¿ome of them, and that incontinently they certifie the Governours of every Province, and the Lieutenant General, of the name and quality of every Å¿uch PriÅ¿oner, whom his MajeÅ¿ty hath appointed Å¿hall be releaÅ¿ed and Å¿et at liberty, except they be of the late ConÅ¿piracy, or Å¿uch as have made Å¿ome practice or device for them, or had intelligence
of, and they Å¿hall advertiÅ¿e his MajeÅ¿ty of Å¿uch ro know his further pleaÅ¿ure. It is alÅ¿o ordained, that from henceforth none Å¿hall take or arreÅ¿t any PriÅ¿oner for that cauÅ¿e, without his MajeÅ¿ties commandment, or his Officers, nor that none be Å¿uffered to roave abroad in the Fields, to take up Dogs, Cattel, Beefs, Kine, or other BeaÅ¿ts, Goods, Fruits, Grain, or any thing elÅ¿e, nor to hurt the Labourers by word or deed, but to let them alone about their work or calling in peace and Å¿afety.
div.closer:
At Paris
AuguÅ¿t 28. 1572.
Å¿igned Charls, and underneath Fizes.

postscript.p: Imprinted at Paris by Iohn Dalleir, Stationer, dwelling on Saints Michaels Bridge at the Å¿ign of the White RoÅ¿e, by the Kings Licence.

div.p: There was Letters alÅ¿o writ by the King to the Officers of Burghs, alÅ¿o remembrances Å¿ent to the General Lieutenant of Burgundy, which being to the Å¿ame purpoÅ¿e, is omitted for brevity.

The Kings Oration, in the great AÅ¿Å¿embly aforeÅ¿aid, being ended; before this AÅ¿Å¿embly broke up, one ChriÅ¿topher Thuane, the PreÅ¿ident of this AÅ¿Å¿embly in Parliament, being one of a high Spirit, and Å¿ubject to admire his own parts and actions, ready to wonder what a fool he could make of Solomon, being a man reported
to be notable for his light brain and cruel heart, who truÅ¿ting more to a Å¿lipery tongue, than a Å¿ound cauÅ¿e, congratulated the King for his wiÅ¿e Policy and good Å¿ucceÅ¿s in a Å¿peedy conqueÅ¿t over his Enemies.
But alas! how did he conquer? Only by wearing the veÅ¿t of the Innocent, to conceal and cover the deformed uglineÅ¿s of his perfidious perjury.
But the Advocate of the Finanees Å¿uccinctly delivered his mind to this purpoÅ¿e.

That though his MajeÅ¿ty had juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to puniÅ¿h Delinquents, yet it were more becoming the juÅ¿tice of a Prince, to proceed according to the Lawes by himÅ¿elf decreed and eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed, and Å¿o more fit for his MajeÅ¿ty to command a Å¿peedy ceÅ¿Å¿ation of Å¿uch violent Å¿laughters, and to enter upon a judicial proceeding, according to the Laws, which was well known to be the proper and peaceable eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment of Empires and Kingdoms.

This advice takes well, for now the King begins to do unjuÅ¿tly in the name of JuÅ¿tice; Å¿o he proceeds to diÅ¿Å¿emble a Legality for all his future Butcheries, unwilling to murther any more without a Å¿tatute, and pretence of JuÅ¿tice for it.
This being a brave principle of a Tyrant; and that whereas the Laws at firÅ¿t were known to be the legitimate daughter of judgement, it muÅ¿t now be made the adopted daughter of Tyranny.

Now is an arreÅ¿t of Parliament, with his Royall aÅ¿Å¿ent, Å¿o that immediately Heraulds went about the City, and an Edict was proclaimed in the Kings name, That all murthers
Å¿hould ceaÅ¿e; but thoÅ¿e that he intended more immediately to have a hand in himÅ¿elf, by Å¿itting in judgement and quallifying his cruelty, and bloodÅ¿hed, with the name of JuÅ¿tice.

And firÅ¿t let us Å¿ee a little of this new JuÅ¿tice of the Kings, which now muÅ¿t be exerciÅ¿ed on the dead Admiral, which being as aforeÅ¿aid, hung by the heels on the common gallows of Paris, the people by flocks and multitudes gathered to Å¿ee it.

The Queen Mother, to delight her Å¿elf with that Å¿ad v â¢ ew of her Sons and her own bloody cruelty, Å¿he takes the King and his Brethren, and Å¿o advances towards this Å¿ad Å¿ight, but his body was in the night conveyed away by two of the MarÅ¿hall de Momorancies Servants, and was Å¿ecretly buried at Chantilly, whoÅ¿e faithfulneÅ¿s and adventure is beyond a terrene Reward.

And now the King begins to put in execution the adviÅ¿e of the Advocate; being alÅ¿o perÅ¿waded to it by Morvilleir, a wicked fellow, and the firÅ¿t that brought the PrieÅ¿ts into the Kingdom of France, now it was thought fit to bring to publick JuÅ¿tice, thoÅ¿e that were taken flying and hiding themÅ¿elves, and Å¿o after the uÅ¿ual manner of Judicial proceedings, Å¿hould be examined by choÅ¿en Judges cull'd on purpoÅ¿e, and Å¿o by Sentence condemned, that in view of all the world, they might receive their execution as the effects of juÅ¿tice, and reward of there TreaÅ¿onous practices.

The Judges thus appointed, was Birage, Thuan, Limege and Belleuxe; who preÅ¿ently gave order for a man of Hay made in Å¿hape of
a mans body, and Å¿o to perÅ¿onate the Admiral, whom they had murthered; and Å¿o it was dragged through the Å¿treets by the Boreau, his memory was condemned and razed out of remembrance, his arms and EnÅ¿igns of Honour and Chivalry demoliÅ¿hed, his CaÅ¿tles and Farms razed to the ground, his Children pronounced infamous, and unnoble, and all the trees in his woods to the growth of Å¿ix foot to be cut down.

And now to make way abroad in the World, in the Court of Forein Princes and Nations for a more neat excuÅ¿e to their unheard-of baÅ¿eneÅ¿s; They diÅ¿perÅ¿e Libells full of diÅ¿honour to the Admiral, and his Adherents, and Å¿tuft with the Defamation of their memories, and that their Actions might not run in a Line Antartick to their words, The King diÅ¿patches his Grand ProvoÅ¿t with all diligence to Å¿eize upon the Admirals wife, and MounÅ¿eir de la Vall the Son of Andelot deceaÅ¿ed, who by Gods good Providence were already fled to Genova, and the better to eÅ¿cape further danger, went to live among the Switzers in the Canton of Bearn, the younger Children both male and female were condemned to death in their tender years.

They give alÅ¿o new charges to their AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours, negotiating in Germany, Poland, England, Switzerland, and other Forein Countreys, to juÅ¿tify the actions of the King and Catholicks, tending alÅ¿o to the Publick reproach and Å¿hame of the Admiral and his Friends.

But God uÅ¿ed theÅ¿e things afterwards as a further mean to diÅ¿cover their treachery, and
Å¿o proved againÅ¿t their expected advantage.

For had the King and Court of France declared at firÅ¿t that they deÅ¿igned to cut of their Enemies, as the exuberous branches of the Kings indulgency, and now grown his Enemies hy their plotted treachery, this would have excuÅ¿ed them from perjury and treaÅ¿on, but to pretend that they intended not what they really reÅ¿olved to do, and nothing leÅ¿s than what they did, This I Å¿ay was the height of diÅ¿honour to the Crown of France.

And thus died that famous, Religious, and Noble Commander GaÅ¿per de Colligny Admiral to the ProteÅ¿tant Army and cauÅ¿e, for the Å¿pace of twelve years; whoÅ¿e deÅ¿erved Fame lived with great renown in the hearts of all the Godly, and with no leÅ¿s terrour and amazement often filled the Kingdom of France, whoÅ¿e valour purchaÅ¿ed great merit from his Enemies; He that made the King and Court afraid, in a haÅ¿ty and diÅ¿orderly retreat from Meaux to Paris. And that I may add one mite to the TreaÅ¿ure of his true worth, this is he that many praiÅ¿ed and all admired, that through a wiÅ¿e conduct of his affairs, terrified his boiÅ¿terous Enemyes, to a Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ive calm of Å¿ubjection; A man Å¿o inÅ¿pired with great courage, and conÅ¿tancy, that to take a DeÅ¿cription by any pen, would be the higheÅ¿t road to lay his merits in the grave of obÅ¿curity, being a man full of the Å¿ail of valour and Å¿ound judgment, a Å¿tar of the greateÅ¿t magnitude in the affairs of higheÅ¿t importance, Å¿hining for ever in the loweÅ¿t obÅ¿curity of diÅ¿cords, Å¿udden dangers, and inÅ¿urrections. One that cannot be enough admired, commended or honoured,
being above all a man of profound judgement in point of reality. This being the leaÅ¿t part of honour that is paid to his eternal worth by all that knew him. He, he it was that baÅ¿ely Å¿uffered, the unreÅ¿iÅ¿table Å¿hock of a perfidious, and treacherous death, cowardly murthered by thoÅ¿e that durÅ¿t never draw a Sword with a ReÅ¿olution of valour againÅ¿t this Champion, but trembled at his Remembrance and PreÅ¿ence, who was never overcome by valour but by cowardice.

AmongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t that were brought to a Legal murder. was one named Caviagnes MaÅ¿ter of the RequeÅ¿ts to the King, and one named Briquemault, both inward friends to the Admiral, and in great reputation in the Court of honour and Camp of Chivalry.

Now this brave Commander and old Souldier Briquemault, having great renown by his Å¿ervice under King Francis, and King Henry, was therefore honoured by all but Å¿uch as love no Rivals, nor valued any crueltie if they could but out Å¿hine others loyalty, by their own treachery. This brave Gentleman was about fourÅ¿core and ten years old, and poor Gentleman had gone through too much proof of fidelity, now to end his life under the command and protection of Å¿uch a cruel Tyrant.

Now theÅ¿e gallant Commanders aged with experience, and filled with innocent integrity, were like Lambs before Wolves, threatened to be torn in pieces unleÅ¿s without delay, they would with their own hands Å¿ubÅ¿cribe that they were of the Admirals Councel, to cut off the King, by an untimely death; together with the Queen his Mother and his Brethren,
and promiÅ¿ing pardon, if they would accept of it; TheÅ¿e innocent Gentlemen cryed out, That they were ready to Å¿uffer the Torments of their mercileÅ¿s cruelty upon their bodies, rather than pull down vengeance upon their Å¿potleÅ¿s Å¿ouls, Å¿o humbly beÅ¿eeched the King to Å¿pare his torments, Å¿eeing none could peirce Å¿o far as force themÅ¿elves to a falÅ¿e accuÅ¿ation, yet if his MajeÅ¿ty pleaÅ¿ed to totment their bodies, they hoped God would Å¿o in his mercy order it, as to leÅ¿Å¿en the pain thereof by his gratious preÅ¿ence in their Å¿ouls; in whoÅ¿e goodneÅ¿s they hoped to depend for aid, rather than perjure their own Souls by a falÅ¿e accuÅ¿ation of themÅ¿elves, and others, being as full of innocency and integrity as they of cruelty and perjury; they were reÅ¿olved never to accuÅ¿e murthered innocency, wherein they never were guilty, nor commit Å¿uch an execrable crime as the King requeÅ¿ted; and (Å¿ay they) though the King values the tranquility of his Realm before the blood of ChriÅ¿tians; yet we hope to embrace a peaceable conÅ¿cience, in trampling underfoot the high eÅ¿teem of a tranÅ¿itory poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion; for what will it gain us to gain our lives and loÅ¿e our immortal Å¿ouls?

The Judges having Å¿ome remorÅ¿e of conÅ¿cience, began to deny the embracement of that infamy,The Judges toucht in conÅ¿cience do refuÅ¿e to fit in Judgement. which muÅ¿t juÅ¿tly fall on their unjuÅ¿t Sentence; for indeed their reaÅ¿ons were unrefiÅ¿table; and theÅ¿e Judges underÅ¿tood the intent of the King by the Defendants Pleas, Å¿o they refuÅ¿ed any more to hear, or determine, much leÅ¿s to give Sentence, whereupon were new Judges appointed in their room, and to
them was joined a Tormenter, and Notary, as might Å¿uit with them, Å¿o at laÅ¿t theÅ¿e eminent and brave Cammanders and Gentlemen, were by a Å¿hadow of Law, and illegal Legality, condemned to dy, and Å¿o the 22. of October 1572. in the fight of the King, Queen, Mother, her Sons, with many thouÅ¿and gazing on them, they were led to the gallows, Å¿eated in the prime Å¿treet of the City, but before execution, as Briquemault aÅ¿cended the Ladder, came to him the under ProvoÅ¿t of the Town, whom the King had commanded to inÅ¿inuate into him and to profer pardon for life, if he would confeÅ¿s what was laid to his charge, Å¿aying further, that his MajeÅ¿ty being of an eaÅ¿ie nature, and courteous affability, would as Å¿peedily grant pardon, as he ask it, but he, like one truer to his own Å¿oul, then the K. to his promiÅ¿e, replyed, That it was the K. duty to ask pardon of God, if the day of Gods mercy had not paÅ¿t upon his cruelty and perjury, and Å¿o was far from asking forgiveneÅ¿s for that, whereof God and his Å¿oul were witneÅ¿Å¿es of his innocency, yet to prove himÅ¿elf as good a ChriÅ¿tian as the King a ernel Tyrant, he cordially deÅ¿ired God of his great mercy to forgive the King. And Å¿o lifting up his eyes to heaven, he uttered theÅ¿e Words, Oh my God, upon whoÅ¿e Tribunal Å¿eat I Å¿tand, and whoÅ¿e face I hope Å¿hortly to Å¿ee, thou knoweÅ¿t well that I know nothing, nor did not Å¿o much as once think of any ConÅ¿piracy againÅ¿t the King, nor againÅ¿t his EÅ¿tate; though I Å¿tand charged with the Å¿ame in my proceÅ¿s, but I beÅ¿eech God to pardon the King, and all thoÅ¿e that have been the cauÅ¿e of this my unjuÅ¿t death, even as I deÅ¿ire pardon
at thy hands for my Å¿ins, and offences committed againÅ¿t thy Divine MajeÅ¿ty; Å¿o aÅ¿cending another Å¿tep of the Ladder, he onely Å¿aid, I have Å¿omwhat to utter to the King, which I would be glad to communicate unto him, but (Å¿aies he) I Å¿ee that I may not; and Å¿o Å¿hrunk up his Å¿houldiers, forbearing to uÅ¿e any further Å¿peech; Å¿o theÅ¿e two brave Gentlement were at laÅ¿t with halters about their necks, moÅ¿t baÅ¿ely, unjuÅ¿tly and diÅ¿honorably thrown off the Ladder by the Hangman; whoÅ¿e deaths ere this are accounted for; and as Briquemaults conÅ¿tancy was much commended, Å¿o was his death much bewailed by many Catholicks, that were Å¿pectators of this Å¿ad crueltie.

Two things was very ill Å¿poken of by the Catholicks and ProteÅ¿tants; firÅ¿t the preÅ¿ence of the King, as a thing unworthy the Head of JuÅ¿tice, to Å¿ee the Execution; Secondly, That Briquemault being a Gentleman of Good deÅ¿cent, was baÅ¿ely hanged, being a thing rare in France, but eÅ¿pecially now in regard he was reputed of his Enemies to be free from the charge for which he died; about an hour after this unheard-of JuÅ¿tice and execution the bloody Catholicks of Paris, drew their bodies through the Streets, thruÅ¿t their dead bodies through with daggers, Å¿hooting of dags at them, cutting off their ears, and omitted no other kind of cruelty, and barbarous villany that could be imagined.

And thus the Noble Gantlemen, by their ChriÅ¿tian Moderation and compoÅ¿edneÅ¿s of mind, reared Trophies of Honour out of the Ruins of their own misfortunes, Et MiÅ¿erias infularum loco habuere, wore their diÅ¿aÅ¿ters like
holy veÅ¿tments as robes of honour, They let the world know they could not only do but Å¿uffer, and that paÅ¿Å¿ive fortitude is as good as active valour, Et facere & pati fortia, hoc Romanum eÅ¿t, L. Flo.
And now to perfect all, they likewiÅ¿e with theÅ¿e two famous Gentlemen, cauÅ¿e to be hanged a man of Å¿traw made for a Å¿hadow of the Admiral.

TheÅ¿e barbarous cruelties, Å¿trange Treacherie, and unheard-of perjury in theÅ¿e bloody proceedings againÅ¿t the poor ProteÅ¿tants of France, brought an odium and bred a Hatred from Stranger Princes, but eÅ¿pecially in Poland; likewiÅ¿e did much fruÅ¿trate the French Negotiations in behalf of the Duke of Anjou.

And Courteous Reader, Å¿ince the firÅ¿t beginning of publiÅ¿hing this Å¿ad Tragedy, there came in the interim a book to my hand; wherein is Å¿omwhat diÅ¿coverd of this HiÅ¿tory, but Å¿pecially the reÅ¿entment and judgement of Sir F. WalÅ¿ing ham then AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador in France for Q. Eliz. of bleÅ¿Å¿ed memory, as alÅ¿o Å¿ome orher Letters, the matter contained therein I have Å¿hortly collected for the publick good, which though abÅ¿tracted here, yet may more at large be read in the Author.

body.head: In a Letter to Sir Tho. Smith, page 245.
body.p: âAnd therefore I hope her MajeÅ¿ty will Å¿tand upon her Guard, and Å¿trengthen her Å¿elf with the Amity of the ProteÅ¿tant Princes of Germany, who (as I hear) are awake, and marvelouÅ¿ly Å¿tomack this late cruelty, and do think that the danger thereof will reach to themÅ¿elvs, if they do not Å¿eek to prevent it.
