body.head: In a Letter to Sir Francis WalÅ¿ingham, page 246.
body.p:
âThe AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour proceeded, Å¿hewing alÅ¿o outwardly, a marvellous inward grief of mind for this Å¿hameful fact, profeÅ¿Å¿ing himÅ¿elf aÅ¿hamed to be accounted a French man. âAlthough indeed the Å¿ame informations
had been true, yet the manner of the cruelty uÅ¿ed cannot be allowed in any kingdom or Government, and leaÅ¿t in that place where the King might by order of JuÅ¿tice have done due execution, both to the Admiral, and all others that Å¿hould have proved offenders: for it cannot be denied, that the Å¿ame forces that murthered Å¿o many, might have more eaÅ¿ily attached them all, or the principals, and brought them to anÅ¿wer to JuÅ¿tice when the King would, &c.âwhoÅ¿e age and knowledge ought in Å¿uch caÅ¿e to have foreÅ¿een how Offenders ought to be juÅ¿tified with the Sword of the Prince, and not with the bloody Swords of Murtherers, being alÅ¿o the mortal enemies of the party murthered, &c.âAnd as for the Admiral, Å¿he confeÅ¿Å¿eth, that Å¿he was very Å¿orry for his death, as for one whom Å¿he thought a good MiniÅ¿ter to continue Amity betwixt their two MajeÅ¿ties, and Å¿he had cauÅ¿e to bewall the reÅ¿t of the Noblemen for the like cauÅ¿e &c.âHer MajeÅ¿ty did greatly lament their death, and doth Å¿urely perÅ¿wade her Å¿elf, that if the King Å¿hall not uÅ¿e his power to make Å¿ome amends for Å¿o much blood Å¿o horribly Å¿hed, God, who Å¿eeth the hearts of all, as well Princes as others, will Å¿hew his JuÅ¿tice in time and place, when his honour Å¿hall therin be glorified, as the Author of all JuÅ¿tice, and the Revenger of all blood-Å¿hedding of the innocents, &c.

body.head: In a Letter to Sir Francis WalÅ¿ingham, folio 250.
body.p: I See the Devil is Å¿uffered by the Almighty God for our Å¿ins, to be Å¿trong in following the perÅ¿ecution of ChriÅ¿ts Members; and therfore we are not only vigilant of our own defence againÅ¿t Å¿uch trayterous attempts as lately have been put in ure there in France, but alÅ¿o to call our Å¿elves to repentance, &c.
âI deÅ¿ire to have the knowledg of as many principals as were Å¿lain, and what ProteÅ¿tants did eÅ¿cape, we are much perplexed with variety of Reports, &c.

body.p:
THe Lamentable Tragedy that hath been there uÅ¿ed of late doth make all ChriÅ¿tians look for a juÅ¿t revenge again at Gods hand, as it hath pleaÅ¿ed him to fear us, and Å¿o pinch us in the mean time, with the Å¿courge of Correction by the Å¿ufferance of his people thus to be murthered, &c.âThat we may Å¿ee as well the fall of his and our Enemies, as the blood of his Saints to be Å¿o innocently Å¿pilt, even for his mercies let him turn it ten fold upon their heads, &c.âIf he
continue in confirming the fact, then muÅ¿t he be a Prince deteÅ¿ted of all honeÅ¿t men, what Religion Å¿oever they have, for as his fact was ugly, Å¿o was it inhumane, for whom Å¿hould a man truÅ¿t if not his Princes Word? and theÅ¿e men whom he hath put to Å¿laughter not onely had his word, but his writing, and not private but publick, with open Proclamations, and all other manner of Declarations, which could be deviÅ¿ed for their Å¿afety, which now being violated and broken, who can believe or truÅ¿t him?

body.head: In a Letter to Sir Francis WalÅ¿ingham, page 252.
body.p:

body.head: In a Letter to the Right Honourable his very Good Lords, the Lords of Her MajeÅ¿ties moÅ¿t Honourable privy Council, page 253.
body.p:
âThat Å¿he was not a little aÅ¿toniÅ¿hed, and perplexed, upon the hearing of the late miÅ¿erable and moÅ¿t lamentable accident in Å¿uch Å¿ort, as Å¿he knew neither what to Å¿ay or Judge of the matter, Å¿eeing thoÅ¿e murthered without pitty and compaÅ¿Å¿ion, without regard had either of Å¿ex or age, without ordinary form of JuÅ¿tice, who upon aÅ¿Å¿urance of the Kings word, laying all Å¿uÅ¿pition aÅ¿ide, did miÅ¿doubt nothing leÅ¿s than that which happened unto them; who thought their lives then in moÅ¿t Å¿afety when by proof it appeared they were in moÅ¿t danger &c.âThat though Å¿he was much aÅ¿toniÅ¿hed at the firÅ¿t report made of the great Å¿laughter, and horrible murther, without regard had either to Å¿ex or age of thoÅ¿e of the Religion, who laying aÅ¿ide all diÅ¿truÅ¿t, and repoÅ¿ing themÅ¿elves upon his words, did moÅ¿t confidently throw themÅ¿elves into the arms of his Protection, &c.âAnd as for the cruelty (Å¿aith he) exerciÅ¿ed both here in my Town of Paris, and elÅ¿ewhere, it is a thing

âThe cruel Murthers at Roan is now long ago written unto us, when we thought all had been done, and by the Å¿ame Letters was written unto us that Deip was kept cloÅ¿e, and the Å¿ame execution of the true ChriÅ¿tians looked for there, but as then not executed, howbeit Sigoigne did warrant all our EngliÅ¿hmen to be out of danger, and not to be afraid; but what warrant can the French make, now Seals and words of Princes being traps to catch innocents, and bring them to the butcheries? if the Admiral and all thoÅ¿e murthered on that

âThe BeÅ¿t is we Å¿tand I thank God, upon our Guard, nor I truÅ¿t Å¿hall be taken and killed aÅ¿leep, as the Admiral was, &c.â

body.p:
âDoth well enough diÅ¿cern that he late cruelty here executed is void of all manner

div.p: Now we may Å¿ee how things were reÅ¿ented by bleÅ¿Å¿ed Queen Elizabeth, how at firÅ¿t the King by his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour would perÅ¿wade her to believe, that he had reaÅ¿on for what he did, although he deÅ¿ired to excuÅ¿e it by neceÅ¿Å¿ity. Now although the King did declare it to the world, that he intended not to break the Edict of Pacification, but that liberty Å¿hould be granted to their PerÅ¿ons, yet the all-Å¿eeing God diÅ¿covered their deeds of darkneÅ¿s, in the day-light, and that the King only deceived

div.p: And thus this King and Court, waÅ¿hed their bloody, and crimÅ¿on hands in the blood of the ProteÅ¿tants.

And that the World might Å¿ee that effected, which he Å¿o often publickly proclaimed was never intended, his heart and his tongue being not Confederates, Å¿hewing himÅ¿elt now perjured to purpoÅ¿e, he cauÅ¿es to be proclaimed, That thoÅ¿e that had any charge in the Nation, Å¿hould for Å¿ake their Religion and their Places; inÅ¿omuch that there was no Å¿mall village, but the poor ProteÅ¿tants were compelled to hear MaÅ¿s, or Å¿peedily periÅ¿h by the Sword, and yet Å¿o baÅ¿ely bloody, and murtherous did the French Nation Å¿hew themÅ¿elves at this time, that even thoÅ¿e that through a Å¿udden fear embraced by temptation, a Å¿ad ApoÅ¿tacy, abjuring the ProteÅ¿tant Religion, yet were preÅ¿ently murthered.

The Remembrances of the King Å¿ent to all Governours of Provinces, and alÅ¿o the form of Abjuration, I have here inÅ¿erted, according to the Original Copy, that the world may Å¿ee the perjury of a faithleÅ¿s King.

div.head: Remembrances Å¿ent by the King, to all Governours, and Lieutenants of his Provinces, to put out, and remove all thoÅ¿e of the RELIGION from their Estates, and Charges, although they would abjure the Å¿ame; Å¿aving Å¿uch as have but Å¿mal EÅ¿tates and Offices, to whom his MajeÅ¿ty permitted continuance, on condition that they abjure the Å¿aid Religion, according to the Form of Abjuration Å¿ent for that purpoÅ¿e.

THe King, conÅ¿idering how much his Officers, and MajeÅ¿trates of JuÅ¿tice, and Å¿uch as have the AdminiÅ¿tration and dealing of his fines and payments which be of the New Religion, are Å¿uÅ¿pect and hated, and put his Catholick Subjects in great miÅ¿truÅ¿t, if they Å¿hould preÅ¿ently exerciÅ¿e their Offices after theÅ¿e freÅ¿h commotions: Therefore leaÅ¿t the people Å¿hould thereby be brought to a new occaÅ¿ion of Å¿tir, and they of the new Religion be in danger and hazard of their own perÅ¿ons, although they would abjure their Å¿aid new Religion, and profeÅ¿s the Holy faith and Catholick Religion of Rome; His MajeÅ¿ty deÅ¿iring to avoid the new miÅ¿chiefs and troubles which may come, hath adviÅ¿ed to diÅ¿charge the Å¿aid Officers, from the
exerciÅ¿e of the Å¿aid Offices, untill he Å¿hall otherwiÅ¿e appoint. And yet nevertheleÅ¿s in the mean while, if the Å¿aid Officers be obedient unto his will, and live quietly in their HouÅ¿es, without attempting, practiÅ¿ing, or taking any thing in hand againÅ¿t his Service, they Å¿hall receive their wages, and they that will reÅ¿ign their Å¿aid Offices to Catholick perÅ¿ons, and come to his MajeÅ¿tie, Å¿hall be honourably provided for. And as touching other Å¿mall Offices without wages, which cannot be troubleÅ¿ome, as Notaries, Sergeants, and Å¿uch, where the Officers have none Authority, which cannot be Å¿o odious nor miÅ¿truÅ¿tful to the people as the other; His MajeÅ¿ty is adviÅ¿ed, that Å¿uch Å¿mall Officers which will abjure the Å¿aid New Religion, and confeÅ¿s the faith Catholick, ApoÅ¿tolick and RomiÅ¿h, and therein live continually hereafter, Å¿hall continue in the exerciÅ¿e and enjoying of their eÅ¿tates: but they that will continue in their new opinion, Å¿hall depart from their Offices until his MajeÅ¿tie have otherwiÅ¿e provided. And this is for the great miÅ¿chief and inconvenience that may betide them, if they Å¿hould exerciÅ¿e their Å¿aid EÅ¿tates, becauÅ¿e of the great miÅ¿truÅ¿t and Å¿uÅ¿pition which the Catholicks have conceived of them of the new Religion. NevertheleÅ¿s his MajeÅ¿ty well conÅ¿idering, that the moÅ¿t part of the Å¿aid Officers have none other way to live, but the exerciÅ¿e of their Å¿aid Offices, willeth that they Å¿hall be in choice to reÅ¿ign to Catholike and capable perÅ¿ons, and then to come to him for that effect, and he will grant them the greateÅ¿t favour and moderation of his TreaÅ¿ury that is poÅ¿Å¿ible. The which reÅ¿olution
and pleaÅ¿ure of his MajeÅ¿ty, he willeth to be declared to the Å¿aid Officers of the new pretended Opinion, as well by Governours, and Lieutenant Generals of his Provinces, as by them of his Courts of Parliament, of the Chamber of his Accounts, of the Court of his aids, them of his great Council, of the TreaÅ¿ury of France, the Generals of his fines, His Bayliffs, SeneÅ¿hals, ProvoÅ¿ts, Judges, or their Lieutenants, and every one of them as Å¿hall appertain; and to this intent his MajeÅ¿ty willeth and intendeth, that every one of them in their calling Å¿hall Å¿end particularly and apart for every of the Å¿aid Officers of the new Religion, which be of their incorporation, charge and juriÅ¿diction, and Å¿hall admoniÅ¿h them in this behalf, to conform themÅ¿elves to his MajeÅ¿ties mind, and if any of them in Authority, becauÅ¿e of their Å¿aid EÅ¿tates, will return to the boÅ¿om of the Catholick and RomiÅ¿h Church, it Å¿hall be Å¿aid to them, that his MajeÅ¿ty liketh very well of it, and that he taketh a great and Å¿ingular affection therein, and that it Å¿hall give him the greater aÅ¿Å¿urance and credit of their good will, and that his MajeÅ¿ty will not bar them from his Å¿ervice hereafter, but will provide for them as their behaviour Å¿hall deÅ¿erve; and notwithÅ¿tanding for the reaÅ¿ons above Å¿aid, he willeth that they Å¿hall ceaÅ¿e from the exerciÅ¿e of their EÅ¿tates, and Offices, untill he otherwiÅ¿e appointeth. And becauÅ¿e that in many places of the Realm, they have proceeded by way of Å¿eizing the Goods of them of the new Religion, which be dead or abÅ¿ent, or hid themÅ¿elves, and Å¿ometimes of thoÅ¿e, which be in their own HouÅ¿es, although
his MajeÅ¿ty gave to underÅ¿tand by his Declaration of the 28. of AuguÅ¿t laÅ¿t, that he would, and intended that they of the new Religion Å¿hould enjoy their Goods, nevertheleÅ¿s to the intent there Å¿hould be no doubt of his purpoÅ¿e, and that no miÅ¿truÅ¿t might ariÅ¿e thereupon, he declareth, willeth, and intendeth again, that according to the Declaration of the 28. of AuguÅ¿t, they of the New Religion, which be living, whether they be preÅ¿ent or abÅ¿ent, and be not culpable or charged with the laÅ¿t ConÅ¿piration, or to have attempted againÅ¿t his MajeÅ¿ty, or his EÅ¿tate, Å¿ince his Edict of Pacification, Å¿hall be reÅ¿tored to their HouÅ¿es, and put in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of all and Å¿ingular their goods moveable and immoveable, And that the Widdows and Heirs of them that be dead, may and Å¿hall Å¿ucceed them, and apprehend all and Å¿ingular their goods, and that they Å¿hall be maintained in them, and kept under the protection and Å¿afeguard of his MajeÅ¿ty, Å¿o that no hurt Å¿hall be done or Å¿aid unto them, in any manner of ways and Å¿ort. Willing for this purpoÅ¿e that all neceÅ¿Å¿ary Å¿urety Å¿hall be given them, and that all Officers, MagiÅ¿trates, Maiors, and others, which have publick charge, Å¿hall maintain them in all Å¿afety, forbidding all perÅ¿ons of what eÅ¿tate, quality, or condition Å¿oever they be, not to hurt them in perÅ¿on or goods upon pain of death; and nevertheleÅ¿s his MajeÅ¿ty willeth that they of the New Opinion Å¿hall Å¿ubmit themÅ¿elvs, & promiÅ¿e upon pain to be declared Rebels and Traytors to his MajeÅ¿ty, that they Å¿hall hereafter live under his Obedience, without attempting any thing to the contrary, or taking
their parts that do attempt againÅ¿t his MajeÅ¿ty, and eÅ¿tate, or things againÅ¿t his Ordinances, and to acknowledge none but his MajeÅ¿ty, or Å¿uch as he Å¿hall appoint under him, to have authority to command them, and if they know any that Å¿hall enterprize againÅ¿t his MajeÅ¿ty, and Å¿ervice, to reveal them incontinent to him and his Officers, as good and faithful Subjects; and to take away all doubt and Å¿uÅ¿pition as well from the Nobility as others, becauÅ¿e that in the Declaration of the twenty fourth of the laÅ¿t moneth theÅ¿e words are contained (except they be of the chief, which had commandment for thoÅ¿e of the new opinion, or thoÅ¿e which made practiÅ¿es or deviÅ¿es for them, or thoÅ¿e which might have had intelligence of the Å¿aid ConÅ¿piracy) his MajeÅ¿ty declareth that he meaneth not of things done and paÅ¿t, during the troubles which were before the Edict of Pacification in AuguÅ¿t 1570. and that their Å¿hall be no InquiÅ¿ition thereof, and none Å¿hall be troubled in goods or perÅ¿on therefore (but for that reÅ¿pect they Å¿hall enjoy the benefit of the Edict of Pacification) but that the Å¿aid Words extend only to thoÅ¿e which be found to be guilty, or acceÅ¿Å¿ary to the late conÅ¿piracy, done againÅ¿t his MajeÅ¿ty and EÅ¿tate, and that others which are impriÅ¿oned, Å¿hall be Å¿et at liberty; and as touching them which will make profeÅ¿Å¿ion of their faith, and return to the Catholick Religion, his MajeÅ¿ty deÅ¿ireth that his Governours and Officers Å¿hall excite and comfort them as much as they can, to that effect, and execution of that good will; and that their friends and kinsfolks Å¿hould alÅ¿o be exhorted to do the like for their part, and if

div.head: The form of Abjuration of HereÅ¿ie, and ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of Faith, which they which have Å¿warved from the faith, and pretend to be received into the Church, ought to make.
div.p: FIrÅ¿t, they which have Å¿warved from the Faith, and deÅ¿ire to return into the compaÅ¿s of our Holy Mother Church, ought to preÅ¿ent themÅ¿elves to their Curates or Vicars to be inÅ¿tructed of that which they ought to do; that done, they Å¿hall be Å¿ent unto the Reverend BiÅ¿hop of the DioceÅ¿s, or his Chancellour or Official, to make the Å¿aid Abjuration and confeÅ¿Å¿ion in Manner and Form following.

ValdiÅ¿laus King of Hungaria, concluded and confirmed a Peace by Solemn Oath, with the great Turk Amurath; but the King of Hungaria, by the Popes perÅ¿waÅ¿ion, breaks his Solemn Oath, and wars againÅ¿t the Emperour of the Turks, and proceeding to Battel, the whole day was carried dubious on both Å¿ides; But preÅ¿ently the great Turk Amurath takes out of his boÅ¿ome the Articles agreed on, and covenanted too by Oaths, and holding up in his hand, lifting up his eyes to Heaven, uttered theÅ¿e words; Oh JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t! If thou art a God as theÅ¿e ChriÅ¿tians Å¿ay, Revenge this wrong done to thy name and me, and puniÅ¿h theÅ¿e Covenant-Breakers; which words were hardly Å¿poken, but God Å¿hewed his powerful Judgements on the King of Hungaria, and his whole Army; For preÅ¿ently the King ValdiÅ¿laus amidÅ¿t his Enemies was Å¿lain, and his whole Army routed, few eÅ¿caping.

AgeÅ¿ilaus, General of the Spartan Army, marching in AÅ¿ia Minor, made Truce with TiÅ¿Å¿aphernes Lieutenant to the King of PerÅ¿ia, till he had Å¿ent to the King his MaÅ¿ter to know his PleaÅ¿ure; but inÅ¿tead of Å¿ending to the King for ayd in adviÅ¿e and CounÅ¿el, he contrary to his Oath, Å¿ends for a Great Army to Å¿urprize the General of the Spartan Army; But Gods Judgements followed at the Heels of this perjury; for the Army was quite overthrown, according to the propheÅ¿ie of the Spartan General, who Å¿aid, the Gods were angry,
and no doubt would be revenged on his perjury.

The Romans in antient times highly reverenced faith and Oaths in caÅ¿e of publick affairs between Prince and People, or between King and King; and to that purpoÅ¿e they had a Temple erected, and dedicated, where conÅ¿tantly they uÅ¿ed to repair, and there Å¿olemnly promiÅ¿e, and Å¿wear to all the conditions of peace and Truces, and Å¿o curÅ¿ed thoÅ¿e that went about to break them firÅ¿t, and therfore for greater and more Å¿trict confirmation thereof, they offered Sacrifices to the Image of Faith, for the greater TeÅ¿timony of the Intentions, and love to keep their Oaths, moÅ¿t Å¿olemnly made: How will our King Charls the Ninth be aÅ¿hamed by theÅ¿e poor Heathens.

The PÅ¿almiÅ¿t Å¿ayes, A man ought not to break covenant, but Å¿tand to it though to his great hurt, yet Å¿uch a bold wickedneÅ¿s hath poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed Å¿everal Popes, that they undertake to diÅ¿charge any that Å¿hall break their oaths with Hereticks as they Å¿ay.
This audacious and impious practice of confronting Gods command, calls for vengeance from Heaven.
That any man Å¿hould be Å¿o boldly blaÅ¿phemous, as to Å¿ay they will pardon this Å¿in, which God has denounced Å¿uch fearful Judgements againÅ¿t.

There was in antient time, a people in Italy called Aequi, their Memory only now remaining. TheÅ¿e people made League with the Romans, and give Oath to keep it; but not
long after they raiÅ¿ed an Army, and Å¿poiled the Romans, falling on them, contrary to Covenant; the Romans Å¿end three AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours to complain; but their Captain General Å¿lighted them, and bid them deliver their AmbaÅ¿Å¿y to an Oak-tree Å¿tanding by; One of the three AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours Å¿pake to the Oak-Tree, in theÅ¿e words; Thou hallowed Oak, and what ever elÅ¿e in this place belongs to the Gods, hear and bear witneÅ¿s of this DiÅ¿loyal perjury, and breach of Covenant, and favour our juÅ¿t complaints, that we may at laÅ¿t by the help of the Gods, be revenged on this perjured people.
So they returned home, and preÅ¿ently raiÅ¿ed an Army, Å¿et on this perjured people, and by the juÅ¿t Judgements of God utterly deÅ¿troy them off the face of the earth.
To omit many other Examples of this Nature, take but this one more.

King of Lacedemonia. The King of Lacedemonia, and the Argives being at War, Cleomenes the Lacedemonian King, made Truce for Å¿even days; and the third night following fell on them, and made a great Å¿laughter; and with this excuÅ¿e thought to evade the dint of the Å¿hame, and Gods juÅ¿tice: for Å¿ayes he, It is true I made Truce for Å¿even days, but I did not mention nights.

Yet God followed this perjured King with theÅ¿e Judgements. The Wives of the Å¿lain Argives arm under the command of ToleÅ¿illa their CaptaineÅ¿s; enter the City, and puts to the Sword and flight the power and forces of the perjured King Cleomenes; afterwards he was baniÅ¿hed into Egypt, where he miÅ¿erably
died a deÅ¿perate death, being his own Executioner.

Thus we Å¿ee what heavy Judgements God has made, and does execute, upon all Å¿uch as are contemners and breakers of this holy Edict, and Law of God; The Lord is to be feared and obeyed, for in all his Judgements none greater threatned, nor heavyer and Å¿urer falls on, than on bloody and perjured men. A thing abhorred and hated by Heathens, before ever they were Å¿o far enlightened as to know the Law of God was above the Law of Nature; for though they had but the light of Nature, yet they held it a Å¿in unpardonable, and no PuniÅ¿hment accounted enough, as they could invent.

There were Å¿ome that recorded theÅ¿e cruelties and treacherys of the Kings, and inÅ¿tanced the Law of the twelve Tables. Si patronus clienti fraudem facit Å¿acer eÅ¿to, if the Sovereign cheat his Subjects, let them be out of Å¿afety or Protection.

He that in antient time deÅ¿piÅ¿ed the keeping of Oaths, was no more to be called a King. The Right hand was called a Pledge of Faith; The Throne is eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed by JuÅ¿tice, and it is an Abomination for Kings to do wickedneÅ¿s: The Throne is upheld by mercy Å¿aies Solomon, But this King by his Treachery, Perjury, and Cruelty, degraded himÅ¿elf of his peoples affections, for he valued not the lives of many thouÅ¿and, Å¿o his bloody cruelty could be Å¿atisfyed.

Scipio accounted it an honourable thing to Å¿ave one Citizen, rather than to kill a thouÅ¿and Enemies. There was no power and authority
Å¿o great as the Dictators at Rome, it was Å¿uch an AÅ¿Å¿embly which met together, as had the power of War and Peace, nay they had the command of life and death at their will, and that without any Appeal; and yet it was not lawful for them to execute a Citizen, unleÅ¿s his cauÅ¿e was publickly and juÅ¿tly heard, and he legally committed and condemned.

But indeed it is the manner of Murtherers to bereave of life without Law, or cauÅ¿e of death. Nay had this horrid MaÅ¿Å¿aere been a bare down-right murther, it had been the leÅ¿s; but it was covered with fraud and deceit. The King and Court muÅ¿t perÅ¿onate a Religious habit, and pretence of a Religious vow, making Gods holy Ordinance Å¿toop to his deceitful and tteacherous intention.

div.head: The Duties of Kings and Powers of the World, which is not inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent with prudent Policy, and Å¿ound ChriÅ¿tianity.
div.p:
A King ought by his ChriÅ¿tian demeanour to have a rich Å¿tore-houÅ¿e and exchequer of Affection, and allegiance in his peoples hearts; and he, who takes care therein to lay Å¿uch proviÅ¿ion of love, as that it may be as a firm Rock, as a Å¿trong foundation, what is there then that he may not command, which is in their power to perform, then the arms of the peoples affections open, and are Å¿pread to imbrace any command; this
is the way to have the key of their hearts, and to open that treaÅ¿ury of reÅ¿pect; which by the wiÅ¿e mannagement of his power (received from them) he hath ready laid up.

Loving Subjects are moÅ¿t uniting in a harmonious conÅ¿ent of obedience to all his Commands; love to a Prince created by himÅ¿elf, will make cowards valourous, even to defend him from the Å¿hock of his Enemies aÅ¿Å¿aults: And it is Å¿een with greateÅ¿t luÅ¿tre, and to his beÅ¿t advantage in his Straights, when he hath made all his Subjects on the leaÅ¿t notice, ready to be voluntiers in the greateÅ¿t dangers, and hotteÅ¿t attempts for the Honour of their own Prince.

But when Kings Å¿pend too much on the Å¿tock of his Peoples willing minds of Subjection, and prodigally trade away that Å¿tock of Love treaÅ¿ured up in his people, what does he but expoÅ¿e himÅ¿elf to all aÅ¿Å¿aults of fury and cruelty, without pitty? as it has been the end of many Princes; nay when love is abuÅ¿ed and turned to hatred, in what a tottering Throne does he Å¿it?

But whatÅ¿oever the Theory of an abÅ¿olute Monarchy be, yet a Good King loves the practical part of JuÅ¿tice, his Power being more Å¿afe in his Laws than his Will. Though his power and his Command may claim a Å¿trong Authority to do as he pleaÅ¿es; yet he will not make his Power arbitrary, nor beyond the limit of equal juÅ¿tice to all.

Now for OppreÅ¿Å¿ion, Tyranny, Cruelty, and perjury, to be Å¿eated in the heart of a King, and he in the heart of his Kingdome, Oh!
how it levells his peoples affections, and Å¿tems the tide and current of their allegiance, razes the very foundation of his own Å¿ecurity, and is the moÅ¿t compendious way to his own utter ruin.

It doth by a Å¿trange inÅ¿tinct, raiÅ¿e tumults, and viciÅ¿Å¿itudes, that like a rapid Torrent of confuÅ¿ion, falls upon his own head, as the reward of his vicious merits. What foundation can Å¿uch a King have, when it is builded on a Quagmire, Å¿eated on the terrible aÅ¿pect of the peoples hatred, accrewing by his Treacherous Tyranny?
An ingenuous people can no more brook oppreÅ¿Å¿ion, than the River Danube, can mix with the muddy Å¿treams of Sava.

But this King to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h his Throne of Cruelty, and Tyranny; Peaceable like, betroaths his People and HimÅ¿elf, in an indiÅ¿Å¿oluble bond of Peace, never to be broke on his part, yet no Å¿ooner made before the view of heaven, and in the Å¿ight and preÅ¿ence of God, but he regiÅ¿ters his falÅ¿ehood, cruelty and perjury, in a Å¿uddain breach, with the blood of his own Subjects, taking the advantage of their punctual obÅ¿ervance, to diÅ¿arm them, and take their Towns, which on the peace granted were delivered; and Å¿o erects his bloody Engines of deceit upon the ruins of his own promiÅ¿e.

Now ChriÅ¿tian Reader let us a little Å¿ee the Å¿mall probability that the Admiral Å¿hould attempt what they pretend; which reaÅ¿ons, for general Å¿atisfaction, I Å¿hall gather together; becauÅ¿e it is declared by the King, that it was
for a Plot againÅ¿t him and the Court, although it is clear, that it was reÅ¿olved on by the King, Queen Mother, and Cabinet Council, to deÅ¿troy the Admiral and his Friends; which by the Kings Commandment is lamentably, and wofully effected, to the great diÅ¿honour of the King, and the whole French Nation, and cannot but ly as a blot to after ages; and a time there muÅ¿t be to Å¿atisfy God and the World for it.

Now who can imagine, that the Admiral Å¿hould think with a few Gentlemen allowed for his Guard, to attempt any thing againÅ¿t the King, within Paris, there being in the Court conÅ¿tant watch, and at the entrance to the CaÅ¿tle, a Å¿trong Guard of Scots, Switzers, and GaÅ¿eoins, and was then more Å¿trictly kept in regard of the number of Lords, Noble-men, and Gentlemen, met to Å¿olemnize the mariage of the King of Navar, and the Lady Margaret, and that it is well known that in three hours Å¿pace, may be ready at command, Å¿ixty thouÅ¿and men in arms.

BeÅ¿ides all theÅ¿e ReaÅ¿ons, the young Noblemen and Gentlemen that came with the King of Navar and Prince of Conde, had no other arms than their Swords and Innocency; which latter in the greateÅ¿t danger would defend them beÅ¿t.

And yet further to clear all doubts, the Princes and Noblemen of the ProteÅ¿tants, for a Pledge, and TeÅ¿timony for a Solemn Engagement of their innocency, they brought with them, their Wives, SiÅ¿ters, Children and KinÅ¿women, having no thoughts of any
thing but Triumph and Recreation; The Nobles and Gentlemen intending to Å¿hew their expert skill at the Tilt and Tourney.
Now if it be Å¿aid it was after the Admirals Hurt, that he Å¿tudied to be revenged.

It is anÅ¿wered, With what probability can any Å¿ober mind, imagine or conceive that the Admiral lying wounded on both arms, tyed up, and hourly waiting when one Arm Å¿hould be cut off by the Doctors adviÅ¿e, that the Admiral, I Å¿ay, being Guarded by the Kings own Guard, Å¿hould attempt with three hundred Gentlemen of his Guard, to Å¿urprize the King, &c. being Å¿o Å¿ick as few daies was expected to paÅ¿s over, till God would call him to himÅ¿elf, that any Å¿hould think three hundred Å¿o reÅ¿olute as to Å¿et upon a City wherein was Å¿ixty thouÅ¿ond in Armes by the firÅ¿t Alarum?

But doubtleÅ¿s had Å¿uch a thing been known or Å¿uÅ¿pected, he would have been Å¿ecured by CoÅ¿Å¿in and his men, who had by the Kings commandment environed and beÅ¿et him; how Å¿oon might the Å¿ick Admiral been apprehended as well as murthered?

There was never any thing laid to his charge which could be proved by the leaÅ¿t witneÅ¿s, nor what they laid to his charge, had the leaÅ¿t mention of time, place, adherents, means, or witneÅ¿s; Å¿o that if it had been proved or Å¿uÅ¿pected, the King Å¿hould have proceeded according to Law and JuÅ¿tice, which are well known to be the props and Pillars on which a Kingdoms happineÅ¿s Å¿tands Å¿ecure.

But Å¿uppoÅ¿e we that all theÅ¿e things had been
really true, and that the manner of the Admirals death and his Complices had been allowable by all nations, yet let us conÅ¿ider a little, and demand a reaÅ¿on of the inÅ¿olent cruelty, infamous barbariÅ¿m, and unheard-of bloodÅ¿hed, of thoÅ¿e, that were thought by themÅ¿elves altogether innocent of any plot, being antient Matrons, many Noble young Ladies, and Gentlewomen in the flour of their Age, cut off Å¿o baÅ¿ely and barbarouÅ¿ly, a number of women great with child, againÅ¿t the Law of nature were caÅ¿t into Rivers before the time of their Delivery; many aged perÅ¿ons alÅ¿o which lay Å¿ick in Bed, Many CounÅ¿ellours, Advocates, Proctors, PhyÅ¿icians, &c. that conÅ¿ulted only with their books, and the reÅ¿t Å¿equeÅ¿tered from the conference of any CounÅ¿el, by the Sex and degrees; Why was there alÅ¿o Å¿o many learned Teachers and ProfeÅ¿Å¿ors of the Arts and Sciences; amongÅ¿t whom was Peter Ramus, that famous man for learning through out the world, who Å¿tands in the memory of the truly learned, as really, as theÅ¿e bloody actours render France infamous? How many young Students, without hearing or pleading their cauÅ¿e, were here deÅ¿troyed by this Å¿ad Decree of the King and Council?

LaÅ¿tly, what Armour was found, what weapons was found in any of the ProteÅ¿tants houÅ¿es, by which means Å¿uÅ¿pition might grow to proof? Or why was the Kings Letters Å¿ent to command the like murthers at Meaux, Lyons, Troys, TholouÅ¿e, and all over his Dominions, Å¿uch Å¿laughters were committed till the very blood of Gods Å¿aints made the Rivers Å¿well, and Å¿treamed through the Å¿treets reaking hot,
that at leaÅ¿t 40000. were Å¿lain by his bloody command.

Thus has this King and Court imbrewed their hands in the blood of Å¿o many thouÅ¿and innocent Å¿ouls, even to the great expectation of Å¿ome vengeance, which in Gods due time muÅ¿t needs break out on that land, to the third and fourth Generation; if a General repentance do not expiate this deÅ¿erved puniÅ¿hment.
Now ChriÅ¿tian Reader, to bring this Kings reign to a cloÅ¿e, I Å¿hall only abÅ¿tract the moÅ¿t notable paÅ¿Å¿ages together, which hapned after this Å¿ad MaÅ¿Å¿acre.

div.head: CHAP. XI.

argument.head: The Contents.

div.p: AFter this Å¿ad and lamentable Butchery and blood-Å¿hed, the poor ProteÅ¿tants that were eÅ¿caped, fled with all Å¿peed to the Å¿everal Sanctuaries, which God in his mercy had decreed for their preÅ¿ervation. ThoÅ¿e that inhabited upon the coaÅ¿t of Bretaign, Picardy, and Normandy, which were Provinces lying on the Sea over againÅ¿t England. They fled to Queen Elizabeths Protection, and if occaÅ¿ion offered, to fight under the command of Count Montgomery, who then was in the Queens Court.

The poor diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed remnant of ProteÅ¿tants in Dauphine, Provence and Lyonois, fled into SwiÅ¿Å¿erland, amongÅ¿t whom was the Admirals Å¿ons and Andelots, who by the fame of their Fathers Authority, and the tenderneÅ¿s of their years, were joyfully welcomed from Å¿uch a Land flowing with blood and vengeance.

Some imploy their time and Talents in Å¿etting forth to the World in Writing this horrid Treachery and MaÅ¿Å¿acre acted in France, and to let all the ProteÅ¿tants in other parts of the World beware by their Å¿ad example: letting the World know the Å¿tratagem that the French Court uÅ¿e, is to deÅ¿troy by Peace, and that to Å¿hake hands in a peace with PapiÅ¿ts, is the
ready way to deÅ¿truction; the inÅ¿tance whereof was Å¿o freÅ¿h in their minds, that they needed no grand Jury of examples to inforce belief; their own late woful experience being Å¿ufficient to teÅ¿tifie this for a truth.
The ProteÅ¿tants of Burgundy and Campagn fled to the Cities of Germany.

The ProteÅ¿tants in the heart of the Kingdome, and towards Rochel, flocked to Å¿ome Å¿trong Towns, which it pleaÅ¿ed God of his goodneÅ¿s to reÅ¿erve for their Å¿afety, which places they fortified with all the Å¿trength they could; They that inhabited in the IÅ¿le of France, Nivernois, and BeauÅ¿Å¿e, were poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed of Sancerre. ThoÅ¿e that lived in the Provinces of Languedoc and GaÅ¿coiny, placed themÅ¿elves in NiÅ¿mes and Montaubon. And the ProteÅ¿tants in Guienne, Poictou, Zaintonge, and Anjou, fled to Rochel; which proved a Å¿afe harbour from the cruel Birds of Prey; Henry Jaques, Maior of the City, had the Civil government thereof. To this City alÅ¿o reÅ¿orted three thouÅ¿and five hundred men, and came from Å¿undry parts, which had been Souldiers in the Wars, and men of approved valour; alÅ¿o to their aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance came fifty Gentlemen of good quality from the adjoining parts about the City; there came thither alÅ¿o fifty Å¿even MiniÅ¿ters of Gods Word, which by Gods mercy were preÅ¿erved in this Å¿ad blow; and for Ammunition and other ProviÅ¿ion, there wanted none to Å¿upply their neceÅ¿Å¿ity of a Å¿trong and laÅ¿ting Å¿iege.

Now at laÅ¿t the King, Queen Mother, with his Brethren and Court, orders a Day of extraordinary thankÅ¿giving, to be returned for
the good SucceÅ¿s againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants. Thus they reared up CaÅ¿tles of Triumph to their Eternal diÅ¿honour, which practice is condemned by a Turk, Sultan Orchan Å¿econd, King of the Turks, when he had overcome the ChriÅ¿tians in Battail, word being brought to him, adviÅ¿e was demanded what Å¿hould be done to thoÅ¿e PriÅ¿oners that yet alive remained in their mercy, whether they Å¿hould be killed or not? who more like a ChriÅ¿tian than a Turk replyed, Oh no, it is not the part of a Souldier to drown Mercy in Cruelty, for Å¿aies this brave Sultan, Mercy is the Alms of Victory, a noble Å¿aying of a Heathen.

Now the King Å¿ends MonÅ¿ieur de Byron to Rochell, to place a GarriÅ¿on, the ProteÅ¿tants refuÅ¿e it; being a priviledge granted them by the King to receive no GarriÅ¿ons; whereupon Byron proclaims a War againÅ¿t them. Poor Å¿ouls, they had Å¿adly felt the Å¿mart of the K. perfidiouÅ¿neÅ¿s, by their too credulous opinion of theÅ¿e fair pretences; and therfore now thought good to preÅ¿erve their lives from Treachery, or dy with honour.

And now to let the World know what little reality is Å¿ometimes found in Princes; the King of France declares to the King of Spain, that the war which he Å¿eemingly countenanced under command of Count Lodowick of NaÅ¿Å¿aw, was only a plot to bring about his ends; which as it could not be Å¿een by all, Å¿o could it not but be believed by the King of Spain; Å¿o that the undertakers under Count Lodowick, were Å¿harply perÅ¿ecuted by them that afterwards got power over them.

Thus were theÅ¿e poor Souldiers betrayed out
of the Kings own Treachery. Only MonÅ¿ieur de la Nove was preÅ¿erved Å¿ecretly; who being Å¿afely conducted to the Kings Court, his MajeÅ¿ty commands him to Rochel, to Å¿olicite the City to a CompoÅ¿ition, Brave MonÅ¿ieur de la Nove, Å¿toutly, and like a ChriÅ¿tian, anÅ¿wers the King, That it was againÅ¿t his ConÅ¿cience to adviÅ¿e his fellow ProteÅ¿tants, to lay their throats open to them that would too readily cut them; But the King commands, and together with his Å¿ecret deÅ¿ire to Å¿ee Rochel Å¿purs him on, Å¿o having came to MonÅ¿ieur de Byron, who was at St. Jean de Angeli, and after a viÅ¿it to him, delivering the Kings MeÅ¿Å¿age, he enters Rochel; who by a joint ConÅ¿ent of all the City was choÅ¿en their Captain General, who willingly accepted of it, and gave a good proof of his faithful adherence to the ProteÅ¿tant cauÅ¿e.

In January, by the Kings Commandment, MonÅ¿ieur de la Chastre with Å¿ix thouÅ¿and men, beÅ¿ieges Sancere; where finding a furious and reÅ¿olute Enemy, which would not yield to their Summons, after the expences of great toil and labour, diÅ¿charging in two moneths about Å¿ix thouÅ¿and Cannon Å¿hot, they made an aÅ¿Å¿ault, but were bravely repulÅ¿ed to the Eternal praiÅ¿e of the Sancerrois valour and ReÅ¿olution. The 18. of March by a Å¿econd battery on all Å¿ides, they at laÅ¿t made a great breach, and Å¿o aÅ¿Å¿ault and attempt to Å¿cale, but the beÅ¿ieged (who queÅ¿tionleÅ¿s had many friends Å¿lain in the bloody MaÅ¿Å¿acre) had Å¿ome Å¿parks of their Friends blood in their minds, which then Å¿hewed it Å¿elf in their reÅ¿olutions; that they fall on the Enemy by a Å¿trong defence, and made not only a Halt in the Catholicks
proceedings, but made them retreat with the loÅ¿s of Å¿ixty of their beÅ¿t Souldiers dead in the ditch, two hundred mortally wounded, and two hundred utterly lamed; all with the loÅ¿s of Å¿eventeen men of the ProteÅ¿tants; which piece of valour Å¿o cooled the courage of the Kings Army, that they reÅ¿olved no more attempts to be made again Å¿uch impregnable defendants. So they begirt them cloÅ¿e on all Å¿ides, no relief being able to come to them; which did Å¿o extreamly Å¿treighten the beÅ¿ieged, that they were forced to eat their AÅ¿Å¿es, Mules, HorÅ¿es, Cats, Dogs, Mice, Moles, Leather, and at laÅ¿t to eat parchment, and trappings of HorÅ¿es, horns, wild roots, Girdles, making bread of the Å¿eeds of flax, and herbs mixed with Bran, and of Å¿traw and NutÅ¿hels, they made uÅ¿e of Å¿lates, GreaÅ¿e, Tallow, and Ointments Å¿erved for pottage, frying therewith the Excrements of HorÅ¿es and Men; nay the very filth in the Å¿treets alÅ¿o; Å¿uch as went out to Å¿eek relief, were either killed by the Enemy, or lived on Sprigs of Vines, herbs, red Snails and Blackberries; they endured all miÅ¿eries till famine had imprinted old age on the ViÅ¿ages of Children, Å¿o that the youths appeared like the GhoÅ¿ts of the deceaÅ¿ed.

Eighty perÅ¿ons died by the Sword, but the famine deÅ¿troyed five hundred. Some Souldiers and TownÅ¿men, chooÅ¿ing to caÅ¿t themÅ¿elves upon the Enemy, than dy by famine, adventured out; whereof Å¿ome were killed, Å¿ome impriÅ¿oned, and others executed: The King having Å¿worn that he would make them devour one another, was diÅ¿appointed by a Å¿pecial hand of Providence, and a thing no waies expected
by the beÅ¿ieged ProteÅ¿tants, who indeed looked for a general MaÅ¿Å¿acre according to the K. threats; who was reÅ¿olved to bring their houÅ¿es of a threatning height as low as their foundation, and their aÅ¿piring reÅ¿olute minds, lower than them, reÅ¿olving to raze the City into a Å¿olitude, and to bury his ReÅ¿olution in their Ruin: but it pleaÅ¿ed God that the Duke of Anjou, this Kings Brother, being choÅ¿en K: of Poland, AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours were comming for him, and by the way hearing of this Å¿iege, they earneÅ¿tly Å¿olicite the BiÅ¿hop of Valence to perform his promiÅ¿e, for the BiÅ¿hop had Å¿worn in the name of the King his MaÅ¿ter that all Towns moleÅ¿ted for Religion Å¿hould be free. So the poor Town was Å¿aved from the fury of a bloody and cruel Enemy, and yielded on condition to depart with their arms, bag and baggage, thoÅ¿e that Å¿tayed to be free from any further queÅ¿tion for what was paÅ¿t, with a promiÅ¿e to preÅ¿erve the Honour of women and maids.

The King, with an Army of fifty thouÅ¿and men, and Å¿ixty pieces of Artillery, beÅ¿ieges Rochel both by Sea and Land. The Town was fortified Å¿trongly, nothing wanting to annoy the Enemy, and encourage valor among themÅ¿elves. In one Months time was Å¿hot no leÅ¿s than thirteen thouÅ¿and cannon, and many aÅ¿Å¿auls: But alas the Catholicks were too weak to encounter with the ProteÅ¿tants Å¿trength and Courage. Till at length having endured Å¿ome Moneths, the King, Queen Mother, Duke of Arjou, all the Nobles, with the Cavalry and all the Infantry both SwiÅ¿s and French, arrive to this famous Å¿iege the beginning of February 1572. of the French Nobility, there was the
Duke of Alancon, third Brother to the King, the Duke of MontpenÅ¿eir; the Duke of Aumale, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e and Mayen, his Brother, The Duke of Nevers, Bouillon, D' Uqes, and the Duke of Longueville, the Prince Dauphine, the Count of Manlevrier, MarÅ¿hal de CoÅ¿Å¿e, the BaÅ¿tard, De AngouleÅ¿m, the Count de Retz, MonÅ¿ieur de Moluc, and all the Catholick Commanders in the Civil Wars and MaÅ¿Å¿acre.

In Rochel there was a great number of HorÅ¿emen, and Gentlemen, eight Companies of Inhabitants, nine companies of Strangers, one Company of the Mayers, one Company of Volentiers, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of twenty MuÅ¿quetiers, twenty five armed with CoÅ¿tlets of Proof, and thirty Harquebuzeirs; Two thirds whereof were Gentlemen and Å¿uch as had command in the late wars.
